results.name: Abenakiite-(Ce)
results.description_short:

results.name: Abernathyite

results.name: Abhurite
results.description_short:
A tin hydroxychloride mineral.
This mineral is formed from the reaction of pure tin with sea water, and has exclusively been associated with tin ingots from shipwrecks. If discovered today it would be unlikely this would be accepted as a true mineral.

Aschamalmite has a monoclinically distorted structure (due to Pb-Bi ordering), unlike heyrovskýite (orthorhombic). Aschamalmite is apparently only stable <350°C.

results.name: Ashburtonite
results.description_short: Closely related to cerchiaraite group and bobmeyerite.

results.name: Ashcroftine-(Y)
results.description_short: See also "Ashcroftine-(Ce)".

results.name: Asisite
results.description_short:
The Si analogue of janchevite.

Note: Asisite from the Kombat mine has been sold as either "lorettoite" or "chubutite".

results.name: Asselbornite
results.description_short:
The arsenate analogue of Šreinite.

Unique combination of elements.

results.name: Astrocyanite-(Ce)
results.description_short: Unique combination of elements.

results.name: Astrophyllite
results.description_short:
Astrophyllite Group. 
The mineral was first found in 1844 by the Norwegian mineralogist Paul Christian Weibye (1819-1865) and later described by him, in 1848, as a brown, micaceous mineral ("brauner Glimmer") from Låven (formerly Lamöskjär), Langesund...

results.name: Atacamite
results.description_short:
Atacamite Group.

A secondary copper mineral formed through the oxidation of other copper minerals, especially in arid, saline conditions. May be confused with brochantite.

May alter to malachite and chrysocolla, creating pseudomorphs.

results.name: Atelestite
results.description_short: Atelestite Group.

results.name: Atheneite
results.description_short: The As analogue of UM1974-24-Te:Pd and (the possibly identical to the latter) UM1991-26-Te:AsPd.

results.name: Atlasovite
results.description_short:
Atlasovite-Nabokoite Series.

Unique combination of elements.

results.name: Atokite
results.description_short: Compare the chemically similar taimyrite-I.

results.name: Augite
results.description_short: Pyroxene Group, Clinopyroxene Subgroup. In the Ca-Fe-Mg (diopside-hedenbergite-augite) quadrilateral, the ideal structural formula is M2M1[Si2O6], where M2 is a distorted octahedral site which preferentially accepts large cations such as alkaline earth...

results.name: Aurichalcite
results.description_short: A secondary mineral in copper and zinc deposits, aurichalcite is typically found as blue or green crusts or mats of tiny acicular crystals, often as feathery, tufted, druzes; more rarely it is found as columnar crystal aggregates or crusts of either la...

results.name: Auricupride
results.description_short: Compare, e.g.: tetraauricupride, UM2001-05-E:AuCu, and UM2001-04-E:AgAuCu.

results.name: Aurostibite
results.description_short: Pyrite Group. Chemically similar to UM1996-36-Sb:Au. Also compare pampaloite.

results.name: Austinite
results.description_short: Adelite-Descloizite Group.  Austinite-Conichalcite Series. The zinc analogue of Cobaltaustinite and Nickelaustinite.

results.name: Autunite
results.description_short:
Autunite Group.

A secondary mineral resulting from the oxidation of primary uranium minerals in hydrothermal veins, granite pegmatites, etc.
Dehydrates (reversibly) in air to meta-autunite.

results.name: Awaruite
results.description_short: Occurs in chromitite associated with ultramafic igneous rocks, also in river placers from serpentinized peridotites and ophiolites. Awaruite is rare in meteorites.

results.name: Azurite
results.description_short:
A secondary copper mineral frequently found in the oxidized zones of Cu-bearing ore deposits.

Azurite is typically found as tabular to prismatic crystals of a deep "azure blue" color with splendent vitreous faces. There are over 45 well-known forms,...

results.name: Almandine
results.description_short:
Almandine-Pyrope Series, Almandine-Spessartine Series.

Most common garnet. Occurs in metamorphic and pegmatitic rocks.

results.name: Anandite
results.description_short:
Mica Group.
An unusual sulphur-bearing member of the mica group with three known polytypes: anandite-2M1, anandite-1M, and anandite-2O (the most common polytype at the type locality). All anandite polytypes resemble each other, nearly opaque black mica.

results.name: Barytolamprophyllite
results.description_short: The Ba analogue of UM1995-42-SiO:BaCaFeKMnNaSrTi.

results.name: Barytocalcite
results.description_short: Compare 'UM1974-03-CO:BaCaMg'.

results.name: Bariopharmacosiderite
results.description_short:
Pharmacosiderite Group.
The tetragonal-pseudocubic Ba-Fe-end member. Forms solid solutions with pharmacosiderite, natropharmacosiderite, pharmacoalumite and other members of the pharmacosiderite group.

The polymorphs bariopharmacosiderite-C (cubic)...

results.name: Babingtonite
results.description_short: Babingtonite-Manganbabingtonite Series.

results.name: Sassite
results.description_short:
As inclusions in corundum xenocrysts.

Close to being the Ti3+ analogue of berdesinskiite (V-dominant) and pseudobrookite (Fe3+-dominant), but the space groups of the latter differ.

Synthetic β-Ti3O5 has orthorhombic symmetry, Cmcm, a =3.798(2), b...

results.name: Bafertisite
results.description_short:
Closely related to Jinshajiangite and Cámaraite.
In the original description F erroneously was not determined. After the second find of F-rich samples on Verkhnee Espe, the Chinese type mineral was reinvestigated and was found F-dominant.

See also ...

results.name: Baghdadite
results.description_short: The Zr analogue of UM2002-42-SiO:CaFeTi.

results.name: Bahianite
results.description_short:
Currently the only known purely aluminium antimonate mineral. Structurally related to simpsonite.

The structure is unique and is based on hcp (hexagonal close packed) arrange of oxygen atoms, the set being parallel to {001}. There are layers consist...

results.name: Balangeroite
results.description_short: Two polytypes are known, 2M and 1A (Bonaccorsi et al., 2012).

results.name: Balkanite
results.description_short:
Compare danielsite.

Balkanite's structure is not layered, but may be desribed by (1) alternation (along a) of Cu-rich and Ag-rich layers or (2) as the one based on two alternating atomic (010) layers: [Cu4Ag3HgS4]+ and [Cu5Ag2S4]−, or (3) alternatio...

results.name: Balyakinite
results.description_short: Alters to teineite.

results.name: Banalsite
results.description_short:
Feldspar Group.
Forms a solid-solution series with stronalsite.

results.name: Bandylite
results.description_short: A water-soluble mineral. It alters readily to Eriochalcite upon exposure to air.

results.name: Bannermanite
results.description_short: Visually similar to Unnamed (Na-V Oxide) (which is more common at the Liebenbergite slag locality in Lavrion).

results.name: Bannisterite
results.description_short:
Dark brown flat platy aggregates.

A Ba analogue is known: UM1989-30-SiO:AlBaCaFeHKMgMn.

Chemically similar to tamaite (Ca-dominant member of the ganophyllite group).
Structurally related to the Stilpnomelane Group.

results.name: Baotite
results.description_short: The Ti analogue of (Nb-dominant) niobobaotite.

results.name: Bararite
results.description_short: A hexagonal polymorph (space group P63mc) is also known from synthetic material (Fábry et al. 2001).

results.name: Baratovite
results.description_short:
Note: Some mineralogists consider baratovite to be OH-dominant, which would make katayamalite the same species, with the name baratovite having priority.

The Ti analogue of Aleksandrovite.

results.name: Barberiite
results.description_short:
Formed by fumarolic activity, stable only at ground temperatures between 200 and 600°C. Decomposes in humid air.

In experimental sublimation (Mutnovsky volcano) a phase corresponding to barberiite i deposited below 180oC, together with As-bearing su...

results.name: Barbosalite
results.description_short: May be confused with its tetragonal dimorph lipscombite.

results.name: Barentsite
results.description_short: Alters superficially to a white powder in air. Slowly decomposed by water.

results.name: Bariandite
results.description_short: Compare the chemically similar bokite.

results.name: Barićite
results.description_short: Vivianite Group.

results.name: Barrerite
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group.

Compare stilbite-Na.

results.name: Barringerite
results.description_short: "The Ollague meteorite, as a whole, was artificially annealed at a temperature above 1000°C and that heating gave rise to secondary high-temperature alteration of chemical and phase compositions of this meteorite, including the formation of barringerit...

results.name: Barroisite
results.description_short:
Barroisite is defined as a barroisite-group member with Mg>Fe2+ and Al>Fe3+ in the C position. Barroisite has been redefined in the 2012 Amphibole nomenclature in that:

1) The formula is changed from ☐(NaCa)(Mg3AlFe3+)(AlSi7O22)(OH)2 to ☐(NaCa)(Mg3A...

results.name: Barstowite
results.description_short: Visually indistinguishable from Unnamed (Orthorhombic dimorph of Barstowite).

results.name: Bartelkeite
results.description_short:
Structurally related to the monoclinic non-quenchable high-pressure phase of lawsonite (lawsonite itself is orthorhombic).

Chemically related to mathewrogersite.

results.name: Bartonite
results.description_short:
Structurally related to djerfisherite and pentlandite.

See also chlorbartonite, rasvumite, gmalimite, 'Unnamed (K sulfides solid solution)', and UM1997-44-S:FeK.

results.name: Barylite
results.description_short: Barylite was first recognized in 1874 by C. W. Blomstrand (1876) in the Långban Mine, Värmland, Sweden. The mineral was originally bought from the Swedish mineral collector E. Petterson Trapp. At the time Blomstrand erronously regarded barylite as a Ba...

results.name: Baryte
results.description_short:
Note. Although frequently spelled barite in the US and some other places, the official IMA spelling is baryte.

Baryte Group. Baryte-Celestine Series.
The barium analogue of celestine and anglesite.

Typically found as thick to thin tabular crysta...

results.name: Bassanite
results.description_short:
May occur as pseudomorphs after gypsum.
Very similar to omongwaite; structurally related to chinleite-(Y).

Apparently a common precursor phase of anhydrite and gypsum (Van Driessche et al. 2012; Ossorio et al. 2014).

results.name: Bassetite
results.description_short:
An uncommon secondary mineral occurring in the oxidized zones of uranium-bearing hydrothermal mineral deposits.

Crystal structure details (Dal Bo et al., 2016): (1) autunite-type sheets, [(UO2)(PO4)]-, built of corner-sharing UO6 square bipyramids a...

results.name: Bastnäsite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
Cerium analogue of Bastnäsite-(La) and Bastnäsite-(Y).
Fluorine analogue of Hydroxylbastnäsite-(Ce). 
Bastnäsite-(Ce)-Hydroxylbastnäsite-(Ce) Series.

The most common member of the bastnäsite group.
May be intergrown with synchysite-(Ce) (syntacti...

results.name: Bastnäsite-(La)
results.description_short:
Lanthanum analogue of Bastnäsite-(Ce) and Bastnäsite-(Y).
Fluorine analogue of Hydroxylbastnäsite-(La).

results.name: Bastnäsite-(Y)
results.description_short: Yttrium analogue of Bastnäsite-(Ce) and Bastnäsite-(La).

results.name: Batisite
results.description_short:
Batisite Group.
Easily confused with Shcherbakovite and Noonkanbahite.

results.name: Argentobaumhauerite
results.description_short:
The member of the sartorite group, described, as baumhauerite, by N1,2 = 3;4 = 3.5.

The name argenobaumhauerite replaces the former "baumhauerite-2a" which was formerly thought to be a mineral similar to baumhauerite but with a doubled length of the...

results.name: Baumhauerite
results.description_short:
Compare argentobaumhauerite (formerly 'baumhauerite-2a') and bernarlottiite (Sb-rich); also 'UM1966-04-S:AsPb'.

The structure contains isolated and interconnected AsS3 pyramids, as, e.g., in case of dufrénoysite, gratonite, sartorite, and seligmannite.

results.name: Bavenite
results.description_short:
Bavenite-Bohseite Series.

The composition extends from Ca4Be2Al2Si9O26(OH)2 to Ca4Be3AlSi9O25(OH)3.

The bavenite-bohseite relation is described by the following substitution scheme: O(2)OH– + T(4)Si4+ + T(3)Be2+ ↔ O(2)O2– + T(4)Al3+ + T(3)Si4+.

results.name: Bayldonite
results.description_short: A relatively rare secondary mineral occurring in the oxidized zones of polymetallic deposits.

results.name: Bayleyite
results.description_short: After collecting, bayleyite, when stored in a drier atmosphere, becomes dull and disintegrates to a yellow powder.

results.name: Baylissite
results.description_short: A very rare carbonate; decomposes in water and in a humid ambience.

results.name: Bazhenovite
results.description_short:
A mineral with sulphide S2-, trisulphide (S3)2- and thiosulphate (S2O3)2- anions.

However, according to Bindi et al. (2005), the presence of (S2O3)2- anions in bazhenovite is doubtful. 

Compare sulfhydrylbystrite.

results.name: Bazirite
results.description_short: Benitoite Group.

results.name: Bazzite
results.description_short:
The scandium analogue of Beryl.

Typically found as small to tiny hexagonal crystals with a deep blue or blue-green color. Hard to distinguish from beryl.
The blue colour is caused by appreciable iron contents, and, more specifically, the intensity ...

results.name: Bearsite
results.description_short: The arsenic analogue of Moraesite

results.name: Beaverite-(Cu)
results.description_short:
Originally named beaverite.
Compare beaverite-(Zn).
Forms a solid solution series with its Al analogue osarizawaite.

Can be distinguished from plumbojarosite only by accurate determination of the Fe:Cu ratio.
Other Fe members of the alunite famil...

results.name: Bechererite
results.description_short:
There is a new secondary slag phase closely related to bechererite, but without SiO4 groups (U. Kolitsch, 2010; to be published). The natural analogue of this phase was discovered at the Redmond Mine by Jason B. Smith and has been named hanahanite.

...

results.name: Becquerelite
results.description_short: Highly stable in the presence of hydrogen peroxide. At intermediate H2O2 concentrations, it is second most stable phase after schoepite. At high concentrations of H2O2, the stability path is as follows: studtite, schoepite, metaschoepite, becquerelite.

results.name: Béhierite
results.description_short:
The tantalum analogue of schiavinatoite. The second mineral with essential tantalum and boron after holtite.

Possibly crystallochemically related to xenotime-(Y) (Ondrejka et al., 2022).

results.name: Beidellite
results.description_short:
A member of the Smectite Group. 
Beidellite-Saponite Series, Beidellite-Montmorillonite Series.

results.name: Bellbergite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group.

results.name: Belovite-(Ce)
results.description_short: A mineral in the Belovite Group of the Apatite Supergroup. The cerium analogue of belovite-(La). The NaSr3Ce analogue of fluorapatite. The strontium analogue of kuannersuite-(Ce).

results.name: Belyankinite
results.description_short: A mineral of questionable status. Some authors suggest that belyankinite is just a mixture of minerals (mostly anatase) which forms as a common alteration product of murmanite or lomonosovite (Yakovenchuk et. al. Khibiny. Laplandia Minerals, Apatity, 2...

results.name: Bementite
results.description_short:
Compare the very similar innsbruckite and the similar friedelite, as well as ganophyllite and parsettensite.

Raman spectroscopy or diffraction techniques are required to differentiate between bementite and innsbruckite (Krüger et al., 2014).

results.name: Benauite
results.description_short: The Sr analogue of kintoreite.

results.name: Benavidesite
results.description_short: Benavidesite-Jamesonite Series.

results.name: Benitoite
results.description_short:
Benitoite Group. The titanium analogue of Pabstite.

Related to Rogermitchellite.

results.name: Benjaminite
results.description_short:
Cu-rich and Cu-poor varieties are described by Makovicky et al. (2010).

Difficult to distinguish from pavonite; single-crystal XRD methods are necessary (Harris & Chen, 1975).

results.name: Benstonite
results.description_short: Compare the chemically very similar alstonite and its dimorphs.

results.name: Bentorite
results.description_short:
Ettringite Group.
The Cr(III) analogue of ettringite.

Not to be confused with bentonite.

results.name: Beraunite
results.description_short:
A secondary mineral found in bog iron ores and phosphate deposits, plus as a cement in clays, sands, and bone material; also as an alteration product of triphylite in granitic pegmatites.

The name beraunite is now applied only to the fully oxidised ...

results.name: Berborite
results.description_short: Three polytypes are known: berborite-1T, -2T and -2H.

results.name: Berdesinskiite
results.description_short:
Isotypic with Unnamed (Monoclinic polymorph of Pseudobrookite).

A possible Cr analogue is coded as UM1996-17-O:CrFeNbTiV.

results.name: Berlinite
results.description_short: The Al-P-analogue of quartz; ordering of Al and P atoms in the crystal structure leads to a doubled c axis.

results.name: Bermanite
results.description_short:
A late-stage secondary hydrothermal mineral replacing primary phosphate species.

The Mn2+ analogue of magnesiobermanite.

Structurally related to ercitite, mengeite and coralloite (chemically the arsenate analogue of bermanite).

results.name: Bernalite
results.description_short:
Söhngeite Group.
A highly unusual, pseudo-cubic, bottle-green iron hydroxide. In bernalite, the iron containing octahedra units only share corners, while other iron hydroxides share both corners and edges, resulting in Fe-O distances in bernalite that...

results.name: Berndtite
results.description_short:
There are two polytypes, -2T and -4H.

Not isostructural with is chemical Ge analogue, radvaniceite (not a true analogy).

results.name: Berryite
results.description_short:
An orthorhombic polytypic variant has been postulated (Topa et al., 2006).

Structurally related to litochlebite and watkinsonite. 

Visually similar to emplectite and several other sulphosalts.

results.name: Berthierine
results.description_short:
A member of the Kaolinite-Serpentine group.

Common in unmetamorphosed marine sediments; in lateritic and polar soils, rarely as a hydrothermal phase.
"Berthierine is generally considered to be a metastable phase that inverts to 14 Å Fe-rich chlorit...

results.name: Berthierite
results.description_short: Berthierite is a relatively rare ore mineral because it is only stable over extremely narrow intervals of fO2 and fS2 (Williams-Jones and Normand, 1997).

results.name: Bertossaite
results.description_short: Bertossaite-Palermoite Series. The calcium analogue of Palermoite. May be confused with amblygonite which has a more pronounced cleavage. Masses of bertossaite up to 50 kg are known from the type locality, the Buranga pegmatite, Rwanda.

results.name: Bertrandite
results.description_short: A common hydrothermal alteration product of beryl.

results.name: Beryllite
results.description_short: Hydrated counterpart of sphaerobertrandite; chemically similar to bertrandite.

results.name: Beryllonite
results.description_short: Structurally closely related to trimerite.

results.name: Berzelianite
results.description_short:
Berzelianite-Umangite Group.

A recent study showed the existence of a complete solid-solution series between high digenite [cubic, high-temperature digenite] and berzelianite (Pirard & Hatert, 2008).

Compare 'UM1983-17-Se:CuPb'.

results.name: Berzeliite
results.description_short: Berzeliite-Manganberzeliite Series.  The Mg analogue of Manganberzeliite. Structurally related to Palenzonaite and to the Garnet Group of silicates.

results.name: Paralomonosovite
results.description_short:
A Na-poor OH-bearing analogue of lomonosovite.

Betalomonosovite is a Group-IV TS-block mineral (Ti + Mg + Mn = 4 apfu). The crystal structure of betalomonosovite is an alternation of TS and I blocks of the composition Na4Ti4(Si2O7)2O2(OF) and Na2D4[...

results.name: Beudantite
results.description_short:
The arsenate analogue of corkite with which a complete solid-solution range exists. Also forms a solid solution with segnitite and plumbojarosite from which it is difficult to distinguish.

A secondary mineral occurring in the oxidized zones of polym...

results.name: Beusite
results.description_short:
Beusite-Graftonite Series.

Due to some recent finds of new species among the group this mineral is likely to be renamed to beusite-(Mn). Compare beusite-(Ca).

results.name: Beyerite
results.description_short: An uncommon secondary Ca-Bi carbonate visually indistinguishable from Bismutite and Kettnerite.

results.name: Bismutohauchecornite
results.description_short:
Hauchecornite Group.
See also the chemically related parkerite.

results.name: Bianchite
results.description_short: Hexahydrite Group.

results.name: Bicchulite
results.description_short: White to gray-white powder. Chemically very similar to gehlenite.

results.name: Bieberite
results.description_short:
Melanterite Group.

A secondary mineral formed by the oxidation of sulfide and arsenide ores containing cobalt. Often a post-mining product.

May dehydrate to moorhouseite.

results.name: Bismutoferrite
results.description_short: The bismuth analogue of Chapmanite with which it is easily confused.

results.name: Bijvoetite-(Y)
results.description_short:
It is one of four Y-UO2-minerals, and one of four Y-U natural salts, beside alwilkinsite-(Y), sejkoraite-(Y) (sulphates) and kamotoite-(Y) (also a carbonate).

As shown by a study by Plášil & Petříček (2016), the crystal structures of bijvoetite-(Y) ...

results.name: Bikitaite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group.

results.name: Bílinite
results.description_short:
Halotrichite Group

The ferric iron dominant member of the Halotrichite Group.

Other purely ferrous-ferric sulfate minerals are copiapite and römerite. Other sulfates with both Fe(II) and Fe(III) are also metavoltine, pertlikite, and voltaite.

results.name: Biphosphammite
results.description_short: The related, monohydrogen compound, occurs as phosphammite.

results.name: Birnessite
results.description_short:
Generally massive, either earthy or as a resinous to dull fine-grained deposit. Sometime is a replacing material of manganese minerals, including silicates. Occurs in some manganese oxide dendrites. Rarely as dark brown needle crystals.
See also verna...

results.name: Bischofite
results.description_short:
A relatively rare constituent of saline deposits. Secondary in origin in part. Formed by alteration of Carnallite by water.

Deliquescent and soluble in water.

results.name: Bismite
results.description_short: NOTE: Numerous localities for bismuth oxides have been reported, but modern confirmation is required, as most have proven to be carbonates, etc.

results.name: Bismoclite
results.description_short:
Matlockite Group.

Very plastic.

In contrast to many bismuth oxycompounds, this mineral does not contain the typical bismuthyl cation (BiO)+.

May be confused with the Bi carbonates bismutite, beyerite and others.

Usually white to gray. Often...

results.name: Bismuth
results.description_short:
Arsenic Group.

Although long thought to be stable, bismuth, as an element, was shown to be weakly radioactive, with an enormously long half-life period: 1.9 × 1019  years (de Marcillac et al., 2003).

results.name: Bismuthinite
results.description_short:
Aikinite-Bismuthinite Series. Bismuthinite-Stibnite Series.
The S (or sulfide) analogue of guanajuatite.

Compare 'UM1988-13-S:Bi' and 'UM1988-14-S:Bi'.

results.name: Bismutite
results.description_short: A common secondary Bismuth carbonate. Platy forms are visually indistinguishable from the Ca-Bi carbonates Beyerite and Kettnerite.

results.name: Bityite
results.description_short:
A Li member of the Mica Group.

Note: The Italian occurrences of bityite are not confirmed by probed analyses and they can be classified as margarite rich in Li and Be.

results.name: Bixbyite-(Mn)
results.description_short:
The Mn analogue of bixbyite-(Fe); newly defined in December 2021 (IMA 21-H). Belongs to the Bixbyite Series.
An orthorhombic analogue (space group Pcab) of Mn#3+#^2O^3 is known.

The Thomas Range bixbyites may bear exomorphically exsolved jacobsite ...

results.name: Blatterite
results.description_short:
First described as a new mineral by Raade et al. (1988) from Kitteln Mine, Nordmark, Sweden. The structure was solved and refined by Cooper & Hawthorne (1998).
At the type locality (Kitteln mine, Sweden), blatterite is found embedded in calcite or man...

results.name: Blödite
results.description_short:
Lower-hydrate counterpart of konyaite.

Compare UM2008-50-SO:HMgNa and uklonskovite.

results.name: Blossite
results.description_short: Dimorphous with Ziesite

results.name: Bobfergusonite
results.description_short: Wyllieite Group. The Mn analogue of ferrobobfergusonite.

results.name: Bobierrite
results.description_short: Closely related to the Vivianite Group.

results.name: Bogdanovite
results.description_short: Compare, e.g.: tetraauricupride, UM2001-05-E:AuCu, and UM2001-04-E:AgAuCu.

results.name: Boggsite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group.

results.name: Bohdanowiczite
results.description_short:
Matildite Group. Forms a solid solution with matildite.

Some material may be rich in Cu (Förster et al., 2005).

results.name: Böhmite
results.description_short:
A major constituent of the aluminium ore Bauxite.

Dimorphous with Diaspore and isostructural with Lepidocrocite.

results.name: Bokite
results.description_short: Compare the chemically similar bariandite.

results.name: Boleite
results.description_short: Closely related to pseudoboleite.

results.name: Bolivarite
results.description_short:
See also kobokoboite.

Possibly only a variety of evansite (if bolivarite was formally discredited, evansite would have priority as the species name).

results.name: Boltwoodite
results.description_short:
Rod-like to acicular yellow crystals in radial groups.

Compare also natroboltwoodite.

results.name: Bonattite
results.description_short: May form as a dehydration product of chalcanthite.

results.name: Bonshtedtite
results.description_short: Structurally related to bradleyite.

results.name: Boothite
results.description_short:
Melanterite Group.

This mineral, fully hydrated copper sulphate, is very rare. The partially hydrated copper sulphate mineral, chalcanthite, is much more common.

results.name: Boracite
results.description_short:
Boracite Group. Boracite-Ericaite Series. The magnesium analogue of Ericaite and Chambersite. The orthorhombic dimorph of Trembathite.

Boracite is found in evaporite deposits, usually associated with gypsum, anhydrite and/or halite.

results.name: Borax
results.description_short: May dehydrate to tincalconite.

results.name: Bornemanite
results.description_short: A heterophyllosilicate, related to bykovaite.

results.name: Bornhardtite
results.description_short:
Se analogue of Linnaeite.
Current status "grandfathered" but considered questionable by Bosi et al. (2019).
A mineral that appears to never have been analyzed; compare tyrrellite.

results.name: Bornite
results.description_short:
An important copper ore, typically found as massive or disseminated metallic grains and patches in sulphide ore deposits; relatively rare as good euhedral crystals.

It has a copper-reddish colour on fresh exposures which quickly tarnishes to a pinki...

results.name: Borodaevite
results.description_short: Borodaevite is questionable as a pavonite homologue; it may correspond to a homeotypic derivative of treasurite (Ilinca & Makovicky, 1997; Moëlo et al., 2008).

results.name: Boromuscovite
results.description_short: Mica Group.

results.name: Bostwickite
results.description_short: Brownish-red bronzey acicular crystals.

results.name: Botallackite
results.description_short:
A secondary copper mineral.

NOTE: May be confused with Kapellasite, which has a similar X-ray powder diffraction pattern. Some botallackites contain minor Zn, but the Zn:Cu ratio never approaches that of kapellasite (1:3).

results.name: Botryogen
results.description_short:
Chemically similar to magnesiocopiapite, mountkeithite, and slavíkite.

results.name: Boulangerite
results.description_short:
Easily confused with jamesonite.
Homeotype of lopatkaite.
May occur in intergrowths with jamesonite and meneghinite.

Boulangerite has an OD structure with the following MDO polytypes (Ventruti et al., 2012):
- MDO1 with space group P121/a1 and un...

results.name: Bournonite
results.description_short:
Bournonite Group.
Bournonite-Seligmannite Series.

results.name: Boussingaultite
results.description_short:
Picromerite Group, Boussingaultite-Mohrite Series.

May originate as an alteration (hydration) product of efremovite.

results.name: Bowieite
results.description_short: The Rh analogue of kashinite. Possibly also analogous to UM1978-17-S:IrOsPtRu and UM1993-21-S:IrOsRu.

results.name: Boyleite
results.description_short:
Rozenite Group.

Soluble in water; slowly alters to gunningite in a dry atmosphere.

results.name: Bracewellite
results.description_short: Minute prismatic crystals in vugs or intergrown in the groundmass of eskolaite masses. As with other Cr mineral species from the Merume River locality, such as grimaldiite, guyanaite, and mcconnellite, this species is not universally present in every s...

results.name: Brackebuschite
results.description_short:
Brackebuschite Group. The Pb analogue of tokyoite, Mn analogue of calderónite, and Pb-Mn analogue of gamagarite. Chemically similar to krettnichite, paseroite, and pyrobelonite.

A rare secondary mineral occurring in the oxidized zones of hydrotherma...

results.name: Bradleyite
results.description_short:
Structurally related to bonshtedtite.

May occur as fluid inclusions in chromite (Potapov et al., 2022).

results.name: Braggite
results.description_short:
Braggite-Vysotskite Series.

Braggite is stabilised by Pd (and Ni) contents, while cooperite (PtS) is not.
There is a miscibility gap between cooperite and braggite (Merkle & Verryn, 2003).

results.name: Brandtite
results.description_short:
Roselite Group.
The Mn analogue of Unnamed (Fe2+-analogue of Brandtite).

results.name: Brannerite
results.description_short:
Brannerite-Thorutite Series. 

Compare also uranopolycrase and orthobrannerite which, despite the name, is not a polymorph of brannerite.

results.name: Brannockite
results.description_short: One of two K-Li-Sn minerals (the other is aleksandrovite).

results.name: Brassite
results.description_short: May occur also as a dehydration product of rößlerite.

results.name: Braunite
results.description_short:
The Mn2+ analogue of neltnerite.

Compare also braunite-II.

results.name: Bredigite
results.description_short: Anthropogenic "Ca7MgSi4O16" is described by Žáček et al. (2005).

results.name: Breithauptite
results.description_short: Nickeline Group

results.name: Brezinaite
results.description_short:
Cr3-analogue of zolenskyite.

From Davis (1993):
- Does not occur in troilite aggregates.
- Its appearance and occurrence coincide with daubreelite.  It can even form alternating thin lamellae with daubreelite, however, the lamellae cannot be disti...

results.name: Brüggenite
results.description_short: A rare iodate species.

results.name: Brianyoungite
results.description_short: A secondary zinc carbonate-sulphate visually similar to hydrozincite.

results.name: Briartite
results.description_short:
The Fe analogue of zincobriartite.

Often associated with members of the germanite group.

See also 'Ge-stannoidite'.

results.name: Brindleyite
results.description_short:
Kaolinite-Serpentine group.
1M plus 3A and 1A polytypes assumed.

results.name: Britholite-(Ce)
results.description_short: A mineral in the Britholite Group of the Apatite Supergroup. The mineral is typically Th-bearing and often metamict.

results.name: Britholite-(Y)
results.description_short:
A mineral in the Britholite Group of the Apatite Supergroup. A britholite with predominance of Y among the M site cations and OH > F. The 
yttrian analogue of britholite-(Ce). A typically metamict mineral.

results.name: Brizziite
results.description_short: A sodium antimonate mineral.

results.name: Brochantite
results.description_short:
A common secondary copper hydroxy sulphate. Two polytypes, both monoclinic, are known (see below).

May be observed as pseudomorphs after malachite, azurite and langite, and altered to chrysocolla. Acicular varieties may be confused with acicular dio...

results.name: Brockite
results.description_short:
Compare tristramite, 'UM1979-08-PO:CCaFeHREESiTh'; 'UM1980-04-PO:CaHREETh', 'UM1979-07-PO:CaFeHREESiTh'. 

Possibly identical to grayite?
See also the dubious species smirnovskite.

Heating to 800-900oC changes the structure to monazite-like (comp...

results.name: Bromargyrite
results.description_short: Chlorargyrite Group.

results.name: Bromellite
results.description_short: A beryllium oxide mineral found in desilicated, skarn-like deposit and as a result of hydrothermal alteration of nepheline in nepheline syenites pegmatites.

results.name: Brookite
results.description_short: Brookite is one of the five forms of titanium dioxide found in nature.

results.name: Brownmillerite
results.description_short:
Brownmillerite-Srebrodolskite Series. Compare gorerite.

Compare also the related species shulamitite.

results.name: Brugnatellite
results.description_short:
As part of the recent re-evaluation of the nomenclature of the hydrotalcite supergroup (Mills et al., 2012), brugnatellite, originally a grandfathered species, was identified as a questionable species which needs further investigation.

[Possibly ide...

results.name: Brunogeierite
results.description_short:
Nesogermanate member of the ringwoodite group (Cempírek & Groat 2013).

Compare Unnamed (Iron Germanium Oxide).

results.name: Brushite
results.description_short: The phosphate analogue of pharmacolite.

results.name: Buchwaldite
results.description_short: A synthetic arsenate analogue is known.

results.name: Buckhornite
results.description_short: The AuPbS analogue of jaszczakite. Compositionally similar to 'UM1986-39-S:AuBiPbTe'.

results.name: Bukovite
results.description_short: Bukovite group.

results.name: Bukovskýite
results.description_short:
Chemically related to zýkaite.
Often associated with kaňkite.

Compare also Sanjuanite-Destinezite Group.

Bukovskýite is metastable with respect to scorodite, and represents an intermediate step in the conversion of the unstable gels to the stabl...

results.name: Bulachite
results.description_short:
A rare secondary Al arsenate hydrate.

Grey et al. (2020) show that bulachite from Cap Garonne has the formula Al6(AsO4)3(OH)9(H2O)4⋅2H2O and is intergrown with a higher hydrate with composition Al6(AsO4)3(OH)9(H2O)4⋅8H2O. The latter was later named ...

results.name: Bunsenite
results.description_short:
Periclase Group.

A rare nickel oxide.

results.name: Burangaite
results.description_short:
Burangaite-Matioliite Series. Fe2+ analogue of Matioliite. A replacement product of scorzalite.

Several "Mg-rich" burangaites reported in the literature may, in fact, be matioliite (Atencio et al., 2006).

results.name: Burbankite
results.description_short:
Compare UM1990-98-CO:BaCaNaREESr.
Sometimes a little radioactive because of a minor thorium content.

results.name: Burckhardtite
results.description_short: Minute pink to red brown crystals in white to pink dickite and other clays in quartz matrix.

results.name: Burpalite
results.description_short:
A polytype, burpalite-1M2, earlier described as "orthorombic låvenite" (by Portnov et al. 1966, Portnov and Siderenko 1975) is recognized (Dal Bo et al. 2022).

A distinctly monoclinic (låvenite-type cell) apparent polytype of burpalite has been repo...

results.name: Burtite
results.description_short: Schoenfliesite Group.

results.name: Bustamite
results.description_short:
The Mn analogue of ferrobustamite. Compare the closely related dalnegorskite.
Bustamite is the high-temperature polymorph of CaMnSi^2O^6 and johannsenite is its low-temperature polymorph.

May appear visually similar to schizolite (also temporarily ...

results.name: Butlerite
results.description_short: Compare the anhydrous counterpart: 'Unnamed (Fe Sulphate Hydroxide)'.

results.name: Isselite
results.description_short:
The Cu analogue of guarinoite in terms of chemistry and chemically related to montetrisaite and redgillite.

"The actual role of Ni in stabilising this phase deserves further study" (Biagioni  et al., 2020).

results.name: Buttgenbachite
results.description_short:
Connellite-Buttgenbachite Series.

A very rare secondary copper mineral.

results.name: Byelorussite-(Ce)
results.description_short: The Fe analogue of dutkevichite-(Ce).

results.name: Bystrite
results.description_short: Cancrinite Group. The formula may be changed, as the presence of pentasulphide anion in the losod cage was recently confirmed (Sapozhnikov et al., 2016). The third polysulphide-containing mineral, by sulfhydrylbystrite and bazhenovite (this does not co...

results.name: Byströmite
results.description_short: Byströmite Group. The Mg analogue of tredouxite.

results.name: Stöfflerite
results.description_short: A high-pressure polymorph of anorthite, found in shock veins in meteorites.

results.name: Benleonardite
results.description_short: Chemically somewhat similar to stibiogoldfieldite.

results.name: Fluor-buergerite
results.description_short:
Originally named buergerite, but renamed as part of a nomenclature revision, because the type material is F-dominant (Henry et al., 2011).

Buergerite, i.e. the OH-dominant analogue, is currently not known to occur.

results.name: Beryl
results.description_short:
May be confused with apatite.

The largest beryl crystal reported was 18 m long and 3.5 m wide from Malakialina, Madagascar, but in the absence of anything more than a personal communication, the report is doubtful.

Microporous beryl (and cordieri...

results.name: Brucite
results.description_short: Brucite Group

results.name: Bütschliite
results.description_short: A poorly studied material that should probably not be afforded species status.

results.name: Calcioaravaipaite
results.description_short:
Closely related to Aravaipaite (which is Pb-dominant and contains an additional water molecule).

Chemically and structurally related to manuelarossiite.

See also Unnamed (Ba-analogue of Calcioaravaipaite).

results.name: Calciohilairite
results.description_short: Compare UM2002-43-SiO:CaHNaZr.

results.name: Calcioferrite
results.description_short: A phosphate mineral found as nodules and otherwise in phosphatic clay.

results.name: Calciotantite
results.description_short: See also the discredited ungursaite.

results.name: Cacoxenite
results.description_short: A secondary mineral found in oxidized zones of phosphatic magnetite deposits, in novaculites, in phosphate-rich pegmatites, and rarely in iron-rich sediments and soils.

results.name: Cadmoselite
results.description_short: A cubic HP polymorph is already known (see the above link).

results.name: Cadwaladerite
results.description_short: It was demonstrated that cadwaladerite and lesukite are the same mineral species. Because cadwaladerite has historical precedence, it is recognized as a valid mineral species, whereas lesukite is discredited (IMA proposal 18-H), see Peterson et al. (20...

results.name: Cahnite
results.description_short: Related to Moydite-(Y).

results.name: Calaverite
results.description_short:
Closely related to krennerite.

Calaverite has no cleavage. The perfect cleavage on krennerite is parallel to {001}. Sylvanite has a cleavage parallel to {010} along the length of the crystal.

results.name: Calciborite
results.description_short:
Calcium metaborate.

Compare the hydrated calcium borate korzhinskite.

results.name: Calcioancylite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
The calcium analogue of Ancylite-(Ce). The cerium analogue of Calcioancylite-(Nd) and Unnamed (La-analogue of Calcioancylite-(Ce)).

Note: The precise type locality is unknown - the mineral was found at an unspecified place in "Western Lands" (Wester...

results.name: Calcioancylite-(Nd)
results.description_short: The Nd analogue of Calcioancylite-(Ce). The Ca analogue of gysinite-(Nd).

results.name: Calcite
results.description_short:
Calcite Group. Calcite-Rhodochrosite Series.

A very common and widespread mineral with highly variable forms and colours. Calcite is best recognized by its relatively low Mohs hardness (3) and its high reactivity with even weak acids, such as vinega...

results.name: Calciocatapleiite
results.description_short: The calcium analogue of catapleiite.

results.name: Calcjarlite
results.description_short: The Ca analogue of jarlite.

results.name: Calclacite
results.description_short:
Calcium chloride acetate pentahydrate.

A mineral which forms on calcareous rock and fossil specimens and pottery shards through the interaction of acetic acid derived from oak museum storage cabinets (anthropogenic).

results.name: Caledonite
results.description_short: The carbonate analogue of viskontite.

results.name: Moëloite
results.description_short: A sulphosalt with a trisulphide anion.

results.name: Calomel
results.description_short: Calomel-Kuzminite Series

results.name: Camérolaite
results.description_short:
Cyanotrichite Group.
Closely related to carbonatecyanotrichite, less so to cyanotrichite.

The Sb:S ratio appears to be variable (Walenta, 1995). Type camérolaite has S:Sb = 1:1.44; material from the Clara mine has 1:0.64 (Walenta, 1995), although b...

results.name: Caminite
results.description_short: Not to be confused with carminite.

results.name: Campigliaite
results.description_short:
Devilline Group.

The manganese analogue of devilline and lautenthalite.

Unique combination of elements: the only Mn-Cu sulfate mineral.

results.name: Canaphite
results.description_short:
A representative of the very rare (among the minerals) class of pyrophosphates. Compare anastasenkoite, wooldridgeite; 'pyrophosphite', 'pyrocoproite', and 'arnhemite'.

See also UM1991-10-PO:BaCaHMgSr.

See https://www.mindat.org/mesg-627852.html ...

results.name: Cancrinite
results.description_short:
Cancrinite Group. Also classed as a feldspathoid. 

In the structure there are large channels closed by 12-membered tetrahedra rings. The channels are surrounded by cages set in columns. In the members of "cancrinite subgroup" the cages contain [Na(H...

results.name: Cancrisilite
results.description_short: Cancrinite Group.

results.name: Canfieldite
results.description_short: Note that most "canfieldite" specimens from the type locality turn out on analysis to be Sn-bearing argyrodite. Caveat emptor.

results.name: Cannizzarite
results.description_short:
Wittite may be identical with cannizzarite.

Compare Unnamed (Cd-Pb-Bi Sulphide Selenide II) and so-called "cannizzarite-B" (UM1975-13-S:BiPb).

results.name: Cannonite
results.description_short: Compare an unnamed, monoclinic Bi2O2(SO4) described by Capitani et al. (2014).

results.name: Carboborite
results.description_short: This mineral has been reported from an undisclosed salt lake on the Qinghai-Tibet plateau (Xie et al., 1964), a huge area that includes northern Tibet and northwestern Qinghai provinces. According to Yang (1991), Da Qaidam salt lake in Qinghai Province...

results.name: Carbocernaite
results.description_short:
Represents a solid solution between two hypothetical end members CaSr(CO3)2 and NaREE(CO3)2. Crystals with midline composition are monoclinic.

Structurally related to paratooite-(La).

results.name: Carboirite
results.description_short: Carboirite-Chloritoid Series.

results.name: Carbonatecyanotrichite
results.description_short:
Cyanotrichite Group.
A mineral closely related to Cyanotrichite, but often misidentified (old published X-ray powder diffraction data of both species are unreliable; much improved data were recently given by Hager et al. (2009)). 

Although the mine...

results.name: Carletonite
results.description_short:
The OH analogue of fluorcarletonite.

The colour is caused by (CO3)•– hole defects.

results.name: Carlfriesite
results.description_short: The first mixed-valence tellurate mineral with a crystal structure.

results.name: Carlosruizite
results.description_short:
Carlosruizite-Fuenzalidaite Series. The Se analogue of fuenzalidaite. Unique combination of elements; the only selenate-iodate mineral known. The first Se-bearing material among the Chilean nitrate ores.

Leached from 'Caliche Amarillo'.

The struc...

results.name: Carlosturanite
results.description_short: See also Unnamed (Mg Silicate).

results.name: Carlsbergite
results.description_short: The Cr analogue of both the Ti-dominant osbornite and V-dominant uakitite. The only currently known Cr-N mineral.

results.name: Carminite
results.description_short:
The lead analogue of Sewardite. The orthorhombic dimorph of Mawbyite.

A rare secondary mineral formed as an alteration product of (mainly) arsenopyrite in the oxidized zones of lead-bearing deposits.
Structurally related to palermoite.

May be co...

results.name: Carnallite
results.description_short:
Chemically and structurally related to novograblenovite.

A metastable monoclinic dimorph has been prepared as a synthetic phase (Pannach et al., 2020).

results.name: Carnotite
results.description_short:
Carnotite Group.

A secondary mineral resulting from the alteration of Uraninite, Montroseite, or Davidite. Occurs in sandstones, especially in paleochannels, near fossil carbonaceous matter, in calcretes and near playas.

Chemically close to vande...

results.name: Carobbiite
results.description_short:
Very rare water-soluble fluoride mineral. 
The K analogue of villiaumite.

results.name: Carpholite
results.description_short:
Carpholite-Ferrocarpholite Series.

Structurally related to magbasite.
Pale varieties are visually similar to davreuxite.

results.name: Carrboydite
results.description_short: As part of the recent re-evaluation of the nomenclature of the hydrotalcite supergroup (Mills et al., 2012), carrboydite was identified as a questionable species which needs further investigation.

results.name: Carrollite
results.description_short:
Thiospinel Group. Copper in carrollite was recently shown to be monovalent (Pattrick et al., 2008), confirming an earlier study (Nakai et al., 1978).

Natural samples commonly contain Ni; in samples from the Siegerand ore province, a solid solution e...

results.name: Caryinite
results.description_short:
Alluaudite Group.

Chemically very similar to manganberzeliite.
Compare also the chemically similar piccoliite.

results.name: Caryopilite
results.description_short: Note: A "caryopilite-like mineral", with an X-ray powder diffraction pattern "closer to that of lizardite than to that of caryopilite", was described by Nambu et al. (1981).

results.name: Cascandite
results.description_short:
A triclinic pyroxenoid with dreier tetrahedral chains (Mellini & Merlino 1982). It is structural related to sérandite and pectolite.
At the Heftejern pegmatite, Norway it occurs as intimate intergrowns with scandiobabingtonite (Raade & Erambert 1999)

results.name: Cassedanneite
results.description_short: A very likely V analogue of embreyite.

results.name: Cassidyite
results.description_short:
Fairfieldite Group.

Compare lisanite and shasuite; and yakubovichite.

results.name: Cassiterite
results.description_short: The primary ore of Tin. This mineral is found in hydrothermal veins and pegmatites associated with granite intrusions. Because of its durability, it is also frequently found concentrated in alluvial placer deposits, sometimes in large enough quantities...

results.name: Catapleiite
results.description_short: The monoclinic dimorph of gaidonnayite. The sodium analogue of calcium-catapleiite.

results.name: Cattierite
results.description_short: Pyrite Group. Cattierite-Pyrite Series and the Cattierite-Vaesite Series.

results.name: Cavansite
results.description_short:
Ishida et al. (2009) suggest that cavansite is a low-temperature form and pentagonite a high-temperature form. 

To distinguish pentagonite and cavansite one can compare the two under light with a strong blue component, like halogen or sunlight. The ...

results.name: Cebollite
results.description_short:
Low-temperature mineral formed by the deuteric altera­tion of melilite or plagioclase. 
Often intergrown with natrolite.

Christie (1964) studied the type material by X-ray powder diffration. The obtained pattern was mainly that of a phase correspon...

results.name: Čechite
results.description_short:
Adelite-Descloizite Group.
The Fe2+ analogue of pyrobelonite.

results.name: Celadonite
results.description_short:
Mica Group.

The Mg analogue of ferroceladonite.

Some celadonites may be of hydrothermal origin.

results.name: Celestine
results.description_short:
Baryte Group. Baryte-Celestine Series. The strontium analogue of baryte,anglesite and hashemite.

By far the most common strontium mineral.

results.name: Celsian
results.description_short:
Feldspar Group. Celsian-Hyalophane Series; Celsian-Orthoclase Series. 
The distinctly monoclinic (115.2°) dimorph of Paracelsian; the latter is considered a metastable modification (Lin & Foster, 1968).

Chemically very similar to cymrite.

See al...

results.name: Cerianite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
The Ce analogue of uraninite and thorianite. The most simple Ce mineral known. Cerianite generally forms as an oxidation product of Ce3+-bearing minerals. Formation under hydrothermal oxidative conditions is rare.

One of three currently recognized m...

results.name: Cerite-(CeCa)
results.description_short:
The cerium analogue of Ferricerite-(LaCa). Apparently the OH analogue of taipingite-(CeCa). 
Isostructural with phosphates of the Whitlockite Subgroup.

A possible Mn analogue is mentioned by Holtstam et al. (2020). 
Compare other possible analogue...

results.name: Ceruleite
results.description_short: Incorrect spelling is céruléite (Burke, 2008).

results.name: Cerussite
results.description_short:
Aragonite Group.

Cerussite is a lead carbonate mineral, usually found in the oxidized zone of lead ore deposits. It is a very common weathering product of galena and other lead ore minerals.

results.name: Cervelleite
results.description_short:
The Te analogue of aguilarite.

A Cu-rich variety (up to 6 wt.% Cu) has been reported (Helmy, 1999; see also Novoselov et al., 2006; Voudouris et al., 2011; Kubač et al., 2018).
Novoselov et al. (2006) assume the existence of several new cervelleite...

results.name: Cesàrolite
results.description_short:
A rare, but inconspicuous secondary Pb(II)-Mn(IV)-oxide.
Chemically related to (the Pb-poorer) coronadite.

results.name: Cesbronite
results.description_short:
Redefined in September 2017 as containing Te6+ not Te4+ (Missen et al., 2018). The originally assumed formula was Cu^5(Te#4+#O^3)^2(OH)^6.2H^2O. 

Note: consequently its current placement within the Strunz and Dana tables is now incorrect.

results.name: Chalcosiderite
results.description_short:
Turquoise Group. Chalcosiderite-Turquoise Series.

An uncommon mineral occurring in the oxidized zone of some hydrothermal deposits.

Compare the chemically similar but Cu-richer hentschelite.

results.name: Chlorophoenicite
results.description_short: Manganese (or rather Mn3) analogue of magnesiochlorophoenicite and peterchinite. Although the original chlorophoenicite was named because of an alexandrite-like effect, the colour change under various light sources was observed on rarely encountered pr...

results.name: Chalcophanite
results.description_short: Frequently in thin platy crystals in open rosettes, also isolated tablets. Pseudo-octahedral habits may be confused with hetaerolite with which it is often associated.

results.name: Chlorophaeite
results.description_short:
This material is of uncertain status. It was considered "possibly a chlorite" by Hey (1955) and Clark, 1993 - "Hey's Mineral Index". 

However a study by Srodo et al (2019) indicated it to vary optically from isotropic to birefringent and to have XRD...

results.name: Chalconatronite
results.description_short:
Rare secondary copper mineral.

Note: Chalconatronite can crystallise on the surface of archaeological Cu objects (artefacts) which have been treated with an aqueous Na2CO3 solution in order to stabilise them (Pollard et al., 1990).

results.name: Chalcopyrite
results.description_short:
Chalcopyrite Group. Chalcopyrite-Eskebornite Series.

A major ore of copper. Common in sulfide veins and disseminated in igneous rocks.
Weathering may lead to the formation of malachite, azurite, brochantite, langite and numerous other secondary cop...

results.name: Chabournéite
results.description_short:
Homeotype of protochabournéite.

Sb-dominant analogue of dalnegroite. Compare 'UM1982-10-S:AsSbTl'.

Structurally related to the Sartorite Group.

results.name: Chaidamuite
results.description_short: The lower hydrate counterpart of zincobotryogen.

results.name: Chalcanthite
results.description_short:
Chalcanthite Group.
Copper analogue of siderotil and pentahydrite.

Chalcanthite is natural, water-soluble copper sulphate pentahydrate. It is a secondary mineral that is formed in arid climates or in rapidly oxidizing copper deposits. It is usually...

results.name: Chalcoalumite
results.description_short:
Chalcoalumite Group.

Compare also the chemically similar woodwardite.

A chalcoalumite-related, Sb-bearing mineral is described by Kolitsch et al. (2012). Its X-ray powder diffraction pattern is somewhat similar to that of chalcoalumite. The miner...

results.name: Chalcocite
results.description_short:
Chalcocite-Yarrowite Series.

Easily confused with djurleite.
Chalcocite easily converts to djurleite under the electron beam t...

results.name: Chalcocyanite
results.description_short:
Soluble in H2O and very hygroscopic, altering to chalcanthite.

Chemically and structurally related to dravertite.

results.name: Chambersite
results.description_short: Boracite Group. The manganese analogue of Boracite and Ericaite.

results.name: Chamosite
results.description_short:

A fairly common member of the chlorite group, but less common than clinochlore.

Easily confused with berthierine.

results.name: Chapmanite

The antimony analogue of Bismutoferrite with which it is easily confused.

results.name: Charlesite
results.description_short:

results.name: Chatkalite
results.description_short: The Cu ('UM1981-18-S:CuSn') and Zn ('UM1981-19-S:CuSnZn') analogues are known.

results.name: Chayesite
results.description_short: Osumilite Group.

results.name: Chrysotile
results.description_short:
Polytypes are clinochrysotile, orthochrysotile, and parachrysotile.  Clinochrysotile represents almost all of the known chrysotile specimens. Orthochrysotile is rare and parachrysotile is very rare.

Lizardite and antigorite are closely related serpe...

results.name: Chalcophyllite
results.description_short:
An uncommon secondary mineral occurring in the oxidised zones of some arsenic-bearing hydrothermal polymetallic deposits.
Can be partially dehydrated.

The arsenate analogue of Unnamed (P analogue of chalcophyllite) and of tiberiobardiite.

Relate...

results.name: Chalcostibite
results.description_short: The S analogue of příbramite.

results.name: Chenevixite
results.description_short:

results.description_short:
Childrenite-Eosphorite Series. 
The Fe2+ analogue of eosphorite.

See also the related lefontite.

results.name: Chladniite
results.description_short:
The Mg analogue of fillowite and johnsomervilleite.

Chemically close minerals (also anhydrous) include czochralskiite, brianite, and merrillite - all known from meteorites.

Originally found as a single grain (975 x 175 micrometers) with chlorapat...

results.name: Chloraluminite
results.description_short: A deliquescent, hydrated chloride mineral.

results.name: Chlorapatite
results.description_short:
A chlorine-rich calcium phosphate that belongs to the apatite group. It is the chlorine analogue of fluorapatite and hydroxylapatite, the phosphate analogue of turneaureite, the Ca5 analogue of phosphohedyphane and the calcium analogue of alforsite.
C...

results.name: Chlorargyrite
results.description_short: Chlorargyrite Group.

results.name: Chlorellestadite
results.description_short: The Cl-end member of the ellestadite group. It  forms in xenoliths of calcium-silicate composition when they are exposed to Cl-bearing volcanic exhalations at about 1000 °C under low pressure conditions.

results.name: Chlorocalcite
results.description_short:
The Ca analogue of javorieite. 

Note: possibly isostructural with javorieite (if the synthetic KCaCl3 analogue is indeed structurally identical to chlorocalcite).

results.name: Chloromagnesite
results.description_short:
Lawrencite Group.

A doubtful species. Natural magnesium chloride is regarded as very unlikely.

results.name: Chondrodite
results.description_short: Chondrodite is a mineral in the humite group. It is closely related to clinohumite, humite and norbergite, and it is often found with one or more of these minerals. Chondrodite forms a continuous series with hydroxylchondrodite. Alleghanyite and kumtyu...

results.name: Chrisstanleyite
results.description_short: Silver analogue of jagüéite.

results.name: Christite
results.description_short: The Hg analogue of richardsollyite.

results.name: Chromatite
results.description_short:

Isotypic with zircon and xenotime.

Compare 'UM2011-01-CrO:CaH' - a dihydrate counterpart; and the compositionally similar 'Unnamed (Calcium Chromium Oxide Postspinel)'. Also chemically similar to ellinaite.

results.name: Chromferide
results.description_short: Possibly an analogue of ferchromide. Compare chemically similar 'UM1981-05-E:CrFe' and 'UM1981-06-E:CrFeNiSi'.

results.name: Chromite
results.description_short:

It forms a complete solid solution series with many other members of the group, eg. in the Chromite-Hercynite Series, Chromite-Spinel Series, Chromite-Magnetite Series and the Chromite-Magnesiochrom...

results.name: Chrysoberyl

The Cr-analogue is called mariinskite.

results.name: Chrysocolla

results.name: Chudobaite
results.description_short: The Mg analogue of geigerite.

results.description_short: Gypsum Supergroup

results.description_short:
Dark red-brown nearly black bright rectangular plates to 1 mm or less. An extremely rare mineral.

results.name: Cinnabar
results.description_short: The α phase of HgS. Trimorphous with metacinnabar (the β phase) and hypercinnabar.

results.name: Clarkeite
results.description_short: Clarkeite is a waxy to resinous dark brown replacement of uraninite. It is very uncommon, but is frequently misidentified with brown gummite that is dominated by schoepite-group minerals. Frondel (1956) warned: "Clarkeite is best identified by its X-ra...

Galena Group. Clausthalite-Galena Series.

Easily confused with the closely related paratacamite. 
Note that "anatacamite", originally considered a triclinic dimorph, was later recognised as twinned clinoatacamite and discredited.

results.description_short: A beryllium hydroxide. Formed by hydrothermal alteration of earlier formed beryllium minerals.

results.description_short: Pyroxene Group - Clinopyroxene Subgroup.

Pyroxene Group - Clinopyroxene Subgroup

results.description_short: The Mg (or rather Mg5) analogue of UM1993-24-SiO:CaHMg.

A high-pressure modification of SiO2.

Lovozerite Group.

results.name: Comblainite
results.description_short: Chemically related to UM1998-10-CO:CoHNi.

results.name: Compreignacite
results.description_short: Crystals tend to be small (< 1mm), platy, and translucent and occur on fracture surfaces with black uraninite. The color is yellow to orange-yellow and the luster grades from waxy to dull, rarely bright.

A natural Na analogue may exist (see 'UM1969-13-SiO:Al...

Mn-analogue of zussmanite.

Cooperite is different from braggite and contains only negligible admixtures of Pd and Ni - in contrast, braggite is stabilised by Pd (and Ni) contents.

Copiapite Group.

Some 'copiapite' may in fact be ferricopiapite or other members of the copiapite group.

One of 3 purely ferrous-ferric sulfate minerals beside bí...

The Mg analogue of sekaninaite. Cordierite-Sekaninaite Series.

The arsenate analogue of pseudomalachite.

results.name: Coronadite
results.description_short:
Mn3+ analogue of (the much rarer) ferricoronadite.

results.description_short:
The aluminum analogue of Eskolaite, Hematite, and Karelianite.

Compare willyamite.

results.description_short: In the experimental volcanic gas condensation by Africano et al. (2002) it deposits below 325°C.

results.description_short: Initially described from Bihar, India in 1936 as vanado-magnetite, renamed the following year as coulsonite (these specimens contain up to 4.84% vanadium). Species was redefined in 1962 on Nevada material.

results.name: Cronstedtite

results.description_short:
A curiosity mineral. Colourless samples of this sodium-aluminium-fluoride mineral seemingly disappear in water due to the proximity of their refractive indices.

results.name: Copper
results.description_short:
Copper Group.

Copper was one of the first metals to be worked into implements and the first metal to be smelted from ores. Its excellent ductility and high conductivity assure its use in modern society.

results.name: D'Ansite
results.description_short:
The Mg analogue of d'ansite-(Fe) and d'ansite-(Mn).

First found in a paleogene salt deposit in central China, but first described from Austria.

results.name: Dadsonite
results.description_short: A Cl-free homeotype is disulfodadsonite. Rare example of lead chlorosulfoantimonite. Chemically related to ardaite; compare also 'UM1980-08-S:ClPbSb', 'UM1980-09-S:ClPbSb', and 'UM1980-10-S:ClPbSb'.

results.name: Dalyite
results.description_short: Dalyite from Terceira ignimbrites contains some Na and minor Hf and Ti, but does not readily incorporate Fe, Mg and Ba.

results.name: Damaraite
results.description_short: Chemically similar to mendipite.

results.name: Danbaite
results.description_short:
Danbaite group.

Compare zhanghengite and α-Brass.

results.name: Danburite
results.description_short:
The calcium analogue of Maleevite and Pekovite.

The paracelsian topology might invoke alternatively grouping - "paracelsian group" - also comprising danburite, pekovite, maleevite, hurlbutite and strontiohurlbutite.

results.name: Danielsite
results.description_short: Compare balkanite.

results.name: Daqingshanite-(Ce)
results.description_short: Ce analogue of Unnamed (La analogue of Daqingshanite-(Ce)).

results.name: Darapiosite
results.description_short:
Osumilite Group. The Li-dominant analogue of dusmatovite, which is chemically similar. Also the Mn analogue of sugilite. Chemically somewhat similar to manganoneptunite and watatsumiite.

Structural characteristics: (1) dominance of Li at the T2 site...

results.name: Darapskite
results.description_short: Often occurs in cavities or crevices in massive nitrate rock or as a surficial concentration (Chile).

results.name: Daubréeite
results.description_short: Compare the Cl analogue bismoclite, BiOCl.

results.name: Daubréelite
results.description_short: Linnaeite Group; Thiospinel Group.

results.name: Davanite
results.description_short: Compare UM1989-35-SiO:KTi.

results.name: Davidite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
Unique combination of elements. Ce analogue of davidite-(La). Y analogue of UM2006-09-O:CaFeMnREESrTiZr.

Much rarer than its La-analogue Davidite-(La).

results.name: Davidite-(La)
results.description_short: The La analogue of davidite-(Ce). Unique combination of elements not including the hypothetical 'davidite-(Y)').

results.name: Davyne
results.description_short:
Cancrinite Group.

In the structure there are large channels closed by 12-membered tetrahedra rings. The channels are surrounded by cages, that are set in columns. In the "davyne subgroup" the cages contain [CaCl]+ lusters.

results.name: Dawsonite
results.description_short:
A low-temperature hydrothermal mineral.

Compare the anthropogenic 'UM1989-06-CO:AlHNa'.

results.name: Deerite
results.description_short: The Mn analogue is known as 'UM1987-19-SiO:FeHMgMnTi'.

results.name: Delafossite
results.description_short:
A not too uncommon member of the Delafossite Group.
Often associated with cuprite, copper and limonite.

results.name: Delhayelite
results.description_short: Easily hydrothermally altered to hydrodelhayelite. Chemically somewhat similar  to steudelite and sacrofanite.

results.name: Dellaite
results.description_short: Related to killalaite.

results.name: Deloryite
results.description_short: Structure is similar to that of markascherite in terms of topology.

results.name: Delrioite
results.description_short: The CaSr analogue of calciodelrioite.

results.name: Delvauxite
results.description_short: Grandfathered, but doubtful amorphous phase. A name applied to an ill-defined hydrous ferric phosphate. See also the related minerals Diadochite (amorphous) and Destinezite (triclinic).

results.name: Denisovite
results.description_short: The currently accepted formula, K14+x(Ca,Na,Mn,Fe)48[Si60O162]F16(Ox,OH4−x)·2H2O, places the mineral among the most structurally complex ones.

results.name: Denningite
results.description_short: The structure of denningite contains chains of (MnO6) and (CaO8) polyhedra, which are cross-linked into a framework by Te4+ cations. A similar motif is found in the structure of spiroffite group minerals, where Te4+ cations are cross-linking sheets of ...

results.name: Derbylite
results.description_short:
Homeotypic with graeserite, its As analogue. Both crystallize in the same point group, but different space group.

Also the Fe-Sb analogue of tomichite.

Compare batisivite.

results.name: Dervillite
results.description_short: R. Weil found the type specimen in 1936 and Ungemach made the crystallographic study, also in 1936. When the war was declared, the ULP was transferred to Clermont-Ferrand, the study was completed in 1941. Pierrot and Schubnel were able to validate it a...

results.name: Desautelsite
results.description_short:
Hydrotalcite Group.
Mn3+-analogue of pyroaurite.

results.name: Descloizite
results.description_short:
Adelite-Descloizite Group. Descloizite-Mottramite Series. The zinc analogue of Mottramite, vanadate analogue of Arsendescloizite.

A secondary mineral often found in the oxidation zones of base metal deposits.

Crystal structure details (Effenberge...

results.name: Despujolsite
results.description_short: Fleischerite Group.

results.name: Devilline
results.description_short:
Devilline Group.

The calcium analogue of lautenthalite and campigliaite. 
A dimorph (Unnamed (Dimorph of Devilline)) has been found in both a slag and a mine dump.

Visually very similar to orthoserpierite and bladed serpierite.

results.name: Dewindtite
results.description_short: A rare secondary mineral derived from the alteration of uraninite or predecessor secondary uranium minerals.

results.name: Diaboleite
results.description_short: May be confused with cumengeite.

results.name: Diadochite
results.description_short:
An amorphous ferric iron phosphate-sulphate. Visually similar to destinezite, with which it was often confused, until destinezite was (re)defined as the crystalline equivalent of the amorphous diadochite. (IMA decision 00-E)

results.name: Diamond

results.name: Diaoyudaoite
results.description_short:
NOTE: There is strong suspicion that diaoyudaoite, from all its known localities, is an INDUSTRIAL WASTE product (from chromium refining, corundum synthesis, etc.) and not a natural mineral.

Compare chukochenite.

results.name: Diaphorite
results.description_short: Compare the chemically similar freieslebenite.

results.name: Diaspore
results.description_short: Beware! Certain dealers (especially on eBay) have been offering samples of a whitish-metallic feathery material as "diaspore". It appears to be metallic aluminium plumes formed from metal dripping from smelters, and is neither diaspore nor a mineral.

results.name: Dickinsonite-(KMnNa)
results.description_short:
Arrojadite Group. Arrojadite-(KFe)-Dickinsonite-(KMnNa) Series. First group member with essential Mn (compare manganoarrojadite-(KNa)).

Dickinsonite group.

Note: Mücke & Keck describe "Dickinsonite-(NaMn)" and "Dickinsonite-(KMn)" from Hagendorf-...

results.name: Dickite
results.description_short:
Kaolinite-Serpentine Group.

A secondary mineral usually of hydrothermal origin in conjunction with veins, derived in part from the alteration of aluminosilicate minerals; also occurs as an authigenic sedimentary phase.

results.name: Dienerite
results.description_short:
Originally reported from Radstadt, Salzburg, Austria, with the formula Ni3As. Revalidated by IMA in 2019.

Isotypic with domeykite.

results.name: Dietrichite
results.description_short: Halotrichite Group Found as bright white fibrous efflorescences. Usually a product of surface weathering.

results.name: Digenite
results.description_short:
Note: Many of the reported associations of digenite and djurleite, identified by powder diffraction, could be anilite and djurleite, as anilite transforms to digenite during grinding.

results.name: Diopside

Pyroxene Group - Clinopyroxene Subgroup; see also the Diopside-Hedenbergite Series, and the Diopside-Johannsenite Series.

One of the most common members of the pyroxene group. Often occurs in metamorphosed limestones (marbles) as generally pale gree...

results.name: Dioptase
results.description_short: Bright emerald-green modified rhombohedral usually elongated crystals, usually less than 0.75 cm in size.

results.name: Dissakisite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
Chemically related to dollaseite-(Ce), gatelite-(Ce), manaevite-(Ce), västmanlandite-(Ce), and somewhat to khristovite-(Ce).

Dissakisite-(Ce) often contain a significant portion allanite-(Ce), intermediate compositions and zoned crystals are common.

results.description_short:

Somewhat chemically comparable with klajite and monteneroite.

results.name: Djurleite

results.name: Dollaseite-(Ce)

Usually found as druzes or clusters of small rhombohedral crystals with a somewhat "saddle"-like shape, white to tan to pink in color.

results.name: Dozyite
results.description_short: A 1:1 regular interstratification of trioctahedral serpentine and trioctahedral chlorite units. The formula is halfway between the compositions of the closely associated discrete chlorite (clinochlore) and the discrete serpentine (amesite).

results.name: Dravite

Green-to-red color change in Cr-bearing dravite is caused by the Usa...

results.description_short: Visually similar to hydrodresserite, which has the same chemistry except for more water.  Hydrodresserite forms coarser crystals, resulting in rougher spheres than dresserite, and dresserite spheres are less translucent than hydrodresserite.

results.description_short: The tetragonal polymorph of Pucherite and Clinobisvanite. The rarest of the three polymorphs of BiVO4.

Dugganite Group.

results.description_short: A secondary uranium mineral.

results.description_short: Closely related to holtite.

Layered structure, related to that of arsenolamprite. The unit cell has 8 As and 2 S atoms. There are two types of corrugated layers - As2 and As2S - stacked along [010].

results.description_short: Related to stützite. Compare UM2006-33-Te:AgBiNiPdPt.
