results.name: Fayalite
results.description_short:
Olivine Group. Fayalite-Forsterite Series, and the Fayalite-Tephroite Series. The Fe2+ analogue of Forsterite, Tephroite, and Calcio-Olivine.

Uncommon in nature, but common in man-made (metallurgy) iron slags.
See also laihunite.

results.name: Axinite-(Fe)
results.description_short: Axinite Group. The Fe2+ analogue of Axinite-(Mg) and Axinite-(Mn).

results.name: Ferro-anthophyllite
results.description_short: Forms a series with anthophyllite.

results.name: Fedorite
results.description_short:
A white micaceous mineral. 

Structurally related to Reyerite Group.

results.name: Fedorovskite
results.description_short: Fedorovskite-Roweite Series. The magnesium analogue of Roweite.

results.name: Fedotovite
results.description_short: Structurally related to euchlorine and puninite.

results.name: Feitknechtite
results.description_short: Black replacement of pyrochroite that yielded a mixture of hausmannite and feitknechtite. A specimen of black pyrochroite from the type locality was submitted to the RRUFF Project for Raman spectroscopic examination. Pyrochroite was detected, but not h...

results.name: Felsőbányaite
results.description_short:
A hydrated aluminium sulfate first described by Kenngott in 1853 (as felsöbányite). However, the mineral was earlier observed around 1841/42 by Haidinger in the collection of the Imperial and royal Chamber of Mining, Vienna (Papp, 2004).
Later Bannist...

results.name: Fenaksite
results.description_short: The iron analogue of manaksite.

results.name: Ferberite
results.description_short:
Ferberite-Hübnerite Series.

Occurs in high-temperature hydrothermal veins, greisens, and granitic pegmatites; in alluvial and eluvial deposits.

In a unique situation ferberite may (experimentally) precipitate from volcanic fumarole gas, at temper...

results.name: Ferchromide
results.description_short: Possibly an analogue of chromferide. Compare chemically similar 'UM1981-05-E:CrFe' and 'UM1981-06-E:CrFeNiSi'.

results.name: Fergusonite-(Y)
results.description_short: Compare also the chemically similar euxenite-(Y) and nioboaeschynite-(Y).

results.name: Fernandinite
results.description_short: Similar to corvusite.

results.name: Feroxyhyte
results.description_short:
Compare vernadite.

Determination is likely exclusively based on a comparison (PXRD pattern and other physical properties) with synthetic material.

results.name: Ferrarisite
results.description_short: Ferrarisite dehydrates very slowly in dry air at room temperature and turns from colourless to white; dehydrated crystals were also found in nature in Sainte Marie aux Mines and in Wittichen  (Catti & Ivaldi, 1981). Fresh ferrarisite is visually very s...

results.name: Ferricopiapite
results.description_short:
Copiapite Group.

Difficult to distinguish from copiapite or other members of the copiapite group.

results.name: Ferrihydrite
results.description_short:
The Fe analogue of akdalaite.

A poorly crystalline nanomineral built up of about 20% (FeO4) and 80% (FeO6) polyhedra. It forms by rapid oxidation and hydrolysis, and exists in varying degrees of structure disorder; the two extremes are the so-called...

results.name: Ferro-ferri-katophorite
results.description_short: Relation to katophorite can be described in the form of Fe2+ + Fe3+ → Mg2+ + Al3+ substitution.

results.name: Ferrimolybdite
results.description_short: A rare secondary mineral occurring in the oxidized zones of hydrothermal vein and porphyry-type molybdenum-bearing deposits, or in breccia pipe deposits containing molybdenum. Commonly formed from the alteration of molybdenite.

results.name: Ferripyrophyllite
results.description_short:
Pyrophyllite-Talc Group.
The ferric iron analogue of pyrophyllite.
Compare also minnesotaite.

results.name: Ferrisymplesite
results.description_short: Can be considered an oxidised symplesite/parasymplesite.

results.name: Ferro-actinolite
results.description_short: Note: Tremolite is defined as having an Mg/(Mg+Fe2+) ratio ≥ 0.9; Actinolite has a ratio of 0.5–0.9 and Ferro-Actinolite has a ratio of less than 0.5.

results.name: Ferroalluaudite
results.description_short:
Alluaudite Group.  Alluaudite-Ferroalluaudite Series.

A confusing change of nomenclature occurred regarding the species in this series. Ferroalluaudite was formerly Alluaudite and the present day Alluaudite was formerly Mangan-Alluaudite.

Occurs ...

results.name: Ferrobustamite
results.description_short: The Fe analogue of bustamite.

results.name: Ferrocarpholite
results.description_short: Carpholite-Ferrocarpholite Series and the Ferrocarpholite-Magnesiocarpholite Series.

results.name: Columbite-(Fe)
results.description_short:
Columbite-(Fe)-Tantalite-(Fe) Series and the Columbite-(Fe)-Columbite-(Mn) Series.
Formerly known as columbite and ferrocolumbite.

Compare also ixiolite.

results.name: Ferro-gedrite
results.description_short: Forms a series with gedrite.

results.name: Ferro-hornblende
results.description_short: Forms a series with magnesio-hornblende.

results.name: Ferrokësterite
results.description_short:
Stannite Group. The iron analogue of kësterite.
Easily confused with its dimorph stannite.

results.name: Ferronickelplatinum
results.description_short: Forms series with tulameenite. Compare 'UM1984-18-E:FeNiPt'.

results.name: Ferro-pargasite
results.description_short: Compositionally similar to (Na-free) ferro-tschermakite.

results.name: Pyrosmalite-(Fe)
results.description_short:
Pyrosmalite-(Fe)-Pyrosmalite-(Mn) Series.

"The mineral was originally named pyrodmalith (Hausmann 1808), then shortly after changed to pyrosmalite by Karsten (1808). History, crystallography and chemistry was discussed by Zambonini (1901, Zeitschrif...

results.name: Ferroselite
results.description_short: Marcasite Group.

results.name: Ferrosilite
results.description_short:
Enstatite-Ferrosilite Series

Note: The name has been used in the past to describe the monoclinic dimorph clinoferrosilite, with the orthorhombic dimorph having the name orthoferrosilite so be careful when reading older texts.

results.name: Ferrostrunzite
results.description_short:
Compare also the related iron(II,III) phosphates ferrolaueite and stewartite and the related iron arsenates symplesite and ferrisymplesite.

Not to be confused with ferristrunzite.

results.name: Tantalite-(Fe)
results.description_short:
Tantalite-(Fe)-Tantalite-(Mn) Series and Columbite-(Fe)-Tantalite-(Fe) Series. 
Tantalite-(Fe) is fairly rare and many specimens are actually misidentified Tapiolite-(Fe).

Formerly known as ferrotantalite.

results.name: Tapiolite-(Fe)
results.description_short:
Tapiolite-(Fe)-Tapiolite-(Mn) Series.

Much more common than tapiolite-(Mn).

results.name: Ferro-tschermakite
results.description_short:
Ferro-tschermakite is defined as a Tschermakite-Group member with Fe2+ >Mg and Al>Fe3+ in the C position. Ferro-tschermakite has been redefined in the 2012 Amphibole nomenclature in that:

1) The formula is changed from ☐(Ca2)(Fe2+3AlFe3+)(Al2Si6O22)...

results.name: Ferrotychite
results.description_short: Northupite Group. Ferrotychite-Tychite Series. The Fe2+ analogue of Tychite and Manganotychite.

results.name: Ferrowyllieite
results.description_short: Wyllieite Group. Ferrowyllieite-Wyllieite Series.

results.name: Ferruccite
results.description_short: Also isostructural with NaClO4 and KMnO4.

results.name: Fersmite
results.description_short:
Fersmite (similar to Fergusonite) is one of the most low-titanoan niobates.
Compare Vigezzite.

results.name: Feruvite
results.description_short:
Tourmaline Group.
The Fe2+-analogue of uvite.

Note: The material studied by Selway et al. (1998) is very F-rich on the W site [(F0.49(OH)0.51)] and thus grades into the hypothetical "Fluor-feruvite."

results.name: Fettelite
results.description_short:
The Hg analogue of ferrofettelite.

Easy to confuse with polybasite.

Structurally related to the members of the Pearceite Group.

results.name: Fichtelite
results.description_short: Chemically identical to Dimethyl-isopropyl-perhydrophenanthrene (also known as norabietane, or more specifically 18-norabietane).

results.name: Fiedlerite
results.description_short: Two polytypes exist, Fiedlerite-1A and Fiedlerite-2M.

results.name: Filipstadite
results.description_short:
The Fe3+ analogue of tegengrenite.

Chemically somewhat similar to manganoschafarzikite, and melanostibite, garpenbergite.

Crystal structure details:
- ions occupy ⅛ of the octahedral and ½ of the tetrahedral holes of the spinel-type ccp oxygen l...

results.name: Fillowite
results.description_short: Fillowite Group. The Mn analogue of chladniite and johnsomervilleite.

results.name: Fingerite
results.description_short: black grains up to 150 micrometers

results.name: Fischesserite
results.description_short: Black equant crystals and grains, frequently as microscopic intergrowths.

results.name: Fizélyite
results.description_short:
Compositionally close to ramdohrite.

Compare 'UM1979-14-S:AgPbSb'.

results.name: Flagstaffite
results.description_short: Possibly identical to terpine hydrate.

results.name: Fleischerite
results.description_short:
Fleischerite Group. The Pb analogue of schaurteite. Also the Pb-Ge analogue of genplesite.

Note: most "fleischerite" from Tsumeb is in fact dundasite (see http://www.mindat.org/mesg-7-50534.html).

results.name: Fletcherite
results.description_short: See also Unnamed (Fe3+-analogue of Fletcherite).

results.name: Fülöppite
results.description_short:
Fülöppite is a rare mineral in a homologous series with heteromorphite, plagionite and semseyite. Their structures differ by the thickness of a galena sheet in the structure. Fülöppite has the thinnest such sheet.

May be confused with plagionite.

results.name: Florensovite
results.description_short: Thiospinel Group

results.name: Fluoborite
results.description_short: Fluoborite-Hydroxylborite Series. The fluorine analogue of Hydroxylborite.

results.name: Fluocerite-(Ce)
results.description_short: The cerium analogue of fluocerite-(La) and (orthorhombic) waimirite-(Y).

results.name: Fluocerite-(La)
results.description_short: The lanthanum analogue of Fluocerite-(Ce).

results.name: Fluorapatite
results.description_short:
Apatite Group.
The fluorine analogue of chlorapatite and hydroxylapatite, phosphate analogue of svabite. The Ca5 analogue of belovite-(Ce), belovite-(La), and kuannersuite-(Ce). Note that the five cation sites are non-equivalent and substituents in th...

results.name: Fluorapophyllite-(K)
results.description_short:
Fluorapophyllite-(K) - Hydroxyapophyllite-(K) Series.

The name was revised from apophyllite-(KF) to fluorapophyllite-(K) (Hatert et al. 2013).

results.name: Fluorbritholite-(Ce)
results.description_short: A mineral in the Britholite Group of the Apatite Supergroup. The fluorine-dominant analogue of britholite-(Ce).

results.name: Fluorellestadite
results.description_short:
A mineral in the Ellestadite Group of the Apatite Supergroup. Formerly called ellestadite-(F).  It is a relatively rare mineral found in calcsilicate skarns or metamorphosed limestones. It is also known from burned coal dumps.

The fluorine analogue ...

results.name: Fluorite
results.description_short:
Fluorite Group.

Fluorite is found as a common gangue mineral in hydrothermal veins, especially those containing lead and zinc minerals. It is also found in some greisens, granites, pegmatites and high-temperature veins, and as a component of some ma...

results.name: Foitite
results.description_short:
A vacancy-dominant member of the Tourmaline Group. The Fe2Al-OH-analogue of oxy-foitite.

Correct identification is only possible by suitable analytical methods.

Relatively common among low-temperature (authigenic) tourmalines (Henry & Dutrow, 2012).

results.name: Foordite
results.description_short:
Foordite-Thoreaulite Series.
The niobium analogue of Thoreaulite.

Not to be confused with Froodite, a palladium bismuthide from Sudbury, Ontario.

results.name: Formanite-(Y)
results.description_short:
See also iwashiroite-(Y) and yttrotantalite-(Y). 

According to single-crystal studies of both untreated and heated formanite-(Y) by Shi & Peng (1981), the mineral equals the M' polymorph of synthetic YTaO4 (Wolten, 1967).

Nishio-hamane et al. (20...

results.name: Fornacite
results.description_short:
Fornacite-Vauquelinite Series. The arsenate analogue of vauquelinite.

Related to the Brackebuschite Supergroup.

results.name: Forsterite
results.description_short:
Olivine Group. Fayalite-Forsterite Series, and the Forsterite-Tephroite Series. 
The magnesium analogue of Fayalite, Tephroite, and Calcio-Olivine.

results.name: Fraipontite
results.description_short:
Compare sauconite and zincsilite.

See also Unnamed (Cu analogue of Fraipontite).

results.name: Francevillite
results.description_short:
Curienite-Francevillite Series.

Compare also the Carnotite Group.

results.name: Franckeite
results.description_short: Forms a homologous pair with cylindrite.

results.name: Frankdicksonite
results.description_short: The solubility is much higher than that of fluorite (CaF2).

results.name: Franklinfurnaceite
results.description_short: Intergrown clusters or rosettes of dark red brown plates implanted on hodgkinsonite crystals in open cavities. A second much more uncommon find occurred as nearly black filamentous crystals associated with nelenite in open cavities. Franklinfurnaceite ...

results.name: Franklinphilite
results.description_short: Compare the chemically and stoichiometrically very similar coombsite.

results.name: Freboldite
results.description_short: The Co analogue of achávalite, klockmannite, and sederholmite. Chemically similar to trogtalite and bornhardtite.

results.name: Freieslebenite
results.description_short: Compare the chemically similar diaphorite.

results.name: Fresnoite
results.description_short: The Ba analogue of alfredcasparite.

results.name: Freudenbergite
results.description_short: A possible Fe2+ analogue is known: 'UM1983-07-O:FeNaTi'.

results.name: Friedelite
results.description_short:
May be regarded as a disordered equivalent of mcgillite (Ozawa et al., 1983).
Chemically very similar to pyrosmalite-(Mn) (trigonal).

The possible As3+-equivalent is coded as 'UM1986-06-AsO:HMn'.

Compare the similar bementite.

results.name: Friedrichite
results.description_short:
Aikinite-Bismuthinite Series.

Compare 'UM1984-23-S:BiCuPb'.

results.name: Frohbergite
results.description_short: Frohbergite-Mattagamite Series.

results.name: Frondelite
results.description_short:
Rockbridgeite Group. Frondelite-Rockbridgeite Series. 
The Mn2+-analogue of rockbridgeite and plimerite.

A secondary mineral resulting from the alteration of primary phosphates in complex granitic pegmatites.

results.name: Froodite
results.description_short: Chemically related to 'UM1961-03-Bi:Pd' and 'UM1968-01-Bi:Pd'.

results.name: Fuenzalidaite
results.description_short:
Carlosruizite-Fuenzalidaite Series. The S analogue of carlosruizite.

Occurs in veins and veinlets of the white nitrate ore ("Caliche Blanco").

The structure is based on two complex slabs, normal to the c axis; each slab consists of a double layer...

results.name: Fukalite
results.description_short: OD structure; six MDO polytypes are possible (Bonaccorsi et al., 2009).

results.name: Fukuchilite
results.description_short:
Perhaps the same species as the earlier named villamaninite.
Bayliss (1989) thinks fukuchilite may be a ferroan villamaninite.

results.name: Furongite
results.description_short:
The first natural uranyl phosphate with a U:P ratio of 2:3.

The structure is described as containing:
* infinite uranyl phosphate sheets, [(UO2)4(PO4)6]10-, || (101), which comprise "UrO5" pentagonal bipyramids and PO4 tetrahedra which share edges ...

results.name: Faustite
results.description_short: Turquoise Group. The zinc analogue of Turquoise.

results.name: Gabrielsonite
results.description_short:
IMA proposal 17-G was accepted and the former formula, PbFe(AsO4)(OH), was changed. It makes the mineral an arsenite containing trivalent Fe instead of - as originally assumed - an arsenate containing divalent Fe.

Related to the Adelite-Descloizite ...

results.name: Gadolinite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
The cerium analogue of Gadolinite-(Y) and  Gadolinite-(Nd).
At the type locality, gadolinite-(Ce) often occurs with an orange or yellow alteration rim (up to 0.5 mm).

The Italian occurrences of gadolinite-(Ce) are not probed by analyses and most co...

results.name: Gadolinite-(Y)
results.description_short:
The yttrium analogue of gadolinite-(Ce) and Gadolinite-(Nd).
Difficult to distinguish from hingganite-(Y).

results.name: Gagarinite-(Y)
results.description_short:
Y-analogue of gagarinite-(Ce) and CaY-analogue of polezhaevaite-(Ce).

Possibly isostructural with (or identical to?) UM1993-06-F:CaNaREEY.

results.name: Gageite
results.description_short: Two polytypes are known, gageite-1A and gageite-2M, and are often present in the same "crystal".

results.name: Gahnite
results.description_short: Gahnite-Hercynite Series, and the Gahnite-Spinel Series.

results.name: Gaidonnayite
results.description_short:
The orthorhombic dimorph of Catapleiite.

Compare UM1991-24-SiO:CaKNaZr.

results.name: Gainesite
results.description_short: Minute steeply pyramidal, pale lilac to slightly blue purple crystals usually about 0.1-0.2 mm.

results.name: Gaitite
results.description_short: Fairfieldite Group. Gaitite-Talmessite Series.

results.name: Galeite
results.description_short:
Forms polycrystals with schairerite in the type material.

Can be treated as a 5H antiperovskite polytype, while schairerite - a 7H one.

results.name: Galena
results.description_short:
Galena Group.

Galena is the primary ore mineral of lead. Worked for its lead content as early as 3000 BC, it is found in ore veins with sphalerite, pyrite, chalcopyrite, tennantite-tetrahedrite, etc. and in skarns, as well as in sedimentary rocks wh...

results.name: Galenobismutite
results.description_short:
One of the more common lead-bismuth sulphides, along with cosalite.

Structurally related to ángelaite.

results.name: Galkhaite
results.description_short: The Cs analogue of vorontsovite and Cs-Hg analogue of ferrovorontsovite.

results.name: Gallite
results.description_short: Chalcopyrite Group.

results.name: Gamagarite
results.description_short: The Fe3+ analogue of tokyoite.

results.name: Ganomalite
results.description_short:
The Mn (or rather Ca5Mn-) analogue of wayneburnhamite.
Fresh ganomalite displays a high lustre but surfaces turn dull white with time.

results.name: Ganophyllite
results.description_short:
Ganophyllite Group. The potassium analogue of Eggletonite. Compare UM1990-61-SiO:AlCaHKMnNa.

May be visually similar to bannisterite and parsettensite.
Compare also coombsite.

results.name: Garrelsite
results.description_short: Minute dipyramidal crystals.

results.name: Garronite-Ca
results.description_short: Forms a series with Garronite-Na

results.name: Gartrellite
results.description_short:
Tsumcorite Group.

Easily confused with thometzekite.

results.name: Garyansellite
results.description_short:
Forms a series with kryzhanovskite. Structurally close to other members of the phosphoferrite–reddingite series (or phosphoferrite group).

Small (<1 mm) nearly colorless, zones, fringes, or patches in olive phosphosiderite.

The structure is layer...

results.name: Gasparite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
The arsenate analogue of monazite-(Ce).
The Ce-analogue of gasparite-(La) and Unnamed (Nd-dominant Gasparite).

results.name: Gaspéite
results.description_short:
Calcite Group. 
Gaspéite-Magnesite Series.

results.name: Gaudefroyite
results.description_short: Opaque, but transparent in thin slivers.

results.name: Gaultite
results.description_short: Currently the only natural zeolite with essential zinc.

results.name: Gaylussite
results.description_short:
Dehydrates with efflorescence in dry air (compare the lower hydrate pirsonnite). 
Slowly decomposes in H2O leaving CaCO3 as calcite or aragonite.

results.name: Gearksutite
results.description_short:
A complex aluminium salt mineral, structurally similar to artroeite.

One of the last formed secondary fluorides at the cryolite deposit of Ivigtut, Greenland.

A summary of the early work on the mineral is given by Simpson (1920).

results.name: Gedrite
results.description_short:
Widespread in medium- to high-grade metamorphic rocks; in metasomatized contact metamorphic rocks.

Forms a series with ferro-gedrite.

results.name: Geerite
results.description_short:
May be partly or completely replaced by spionkopite.

Structurally closely related to digenite.

Compare UM1976-15-S:CuSe.

results.name: Gehlenite
results.description_short:
Gehlenite-Åkermanite Series.

Chemically very similar to bicchulite and kamaishilite.

results.name: Geigerite
results.description_short: The manganese analogue of chudobaite.

results.name: Geikielite
results.description_short:
Ilmenite Group. Geikielite-Ilmenite Series. The magnesium analogue of Ilmenite, Pyrophanite, and Ecandrewsite. The titanium analogue of Akimotoite.
May be confused with Hematite.

results.name: Geminite
results.description_short:
Visually similar and chemically and structurally close to krupičkaite.

"For some unknown reason, some geminite specimens turn blue and opaque. This occurred on 4 of my specimens from Cap Garonne and 3 from the Khder mine in the Bou Azzer district, a...

results.name: Genkinite
results.description_short: The Pt analogue of ungavaite. Possibly the Pt-Sb analogue of 'UM1984-07-As:Pd'.

results.name: Genthelvite
results.description_short: Helvine Group. Danalite-Genthelvite Series, Danalite-Helvine Series, and the Genthelvite-Helvine Series.

results.name: Geocronite
results.description_short: Geocronite-Jordanite Series. Substitution of As is preferentially at the Sb4 site (Biagioni et al., 2016).

results.name: Georgeite
results.description_short:
Kondrat et al. (2016) report georgeite as a stable precursor to methanol-synthesis and LTS catalysts.

Redefined in 2023 as "an amorphous alpha-phase hydroxide".

results.name: Gerhardtite
results.description_short:
An uncommon secondary copper nitrate.

Easy to confuse with its dimorph rouaite (both have very similar X-ray powder diffraction patterns).

results.name: Germanite
results.description_short: Compare renierite.

results.name: Germanocolusite
results.description_short: Colusite Group.

results.name: Gersdorffite
results.description_short:
Cobaltite-Gersdorffite Series.

See also UM1989-01-AsS:CoFeNi.

Three polytypes, which are probably temperature-dependent, with P213 being the low form (gersdorffite), Pca21 (orthogersdorffite) the intermediate (metastable?) form, and Pa3 (paragers...

results.name: Gerstleyite
results.description_short:
Homeotypic with gerstleyite and gillulyite.

Occurs as red spherules with fibrous to platy structure up to 2.5 cm in clay with borates. This was the first known sodium sulfosalt.

results.name: Geversite
results.description_short: Compare UM1975-17-Sb:PdPt. A possible Pd analogue is known as 'UM1978-21-Sb:Pd'.

results.name: Gianellaite
results.description_short:
Although somewhat chemically similar to kleinite and mosesite, gianellaite has a unique combination of dominant elements.

In the structure there are: (1) nitrogen-centered (NHg4)5+ tetrahedra, that have all corners common; (2) interstitial sulfate t...

results.name: Gibbsite
results.description_short: Commonly as nodular white masses in laterite.

results.name: Giessenite
results.description_short:
Giessenite-Izoklakeite Series.

"There is apparently a quasi-continuous solid solution from giessenite to izoklakeite with increasing Sb/Bi ratio, which is nevertheless always < 1 except for izoklakeite of the type locality (∼ 1.04). The main differe...

results.name: Gillulyite
results.description_short:
OD structure; several possible polytypes have been proposed (Makovicky & Balić-Žunić, 1999).

Homeotypic with ambrinoite and gerstleyite. 

Also compare jankovićite, rebulite, gillulyite, pierrotite; and gungerite.

Gillulyite is very light sensi...

results.name: Ginorite
results.description_short: The calcium analogue of strontioginorite.

results.name: Giorgiosite
results.description_short:
Inadequately described. 
Compare hydromagnesite (lower hydrate), dypingite (similar), and 'UM1973-06-CO:MgH' (higher hydrate).

results.name: Gismondine-Ca
results.description_short:
Nearly all gismondines found and studied over almost two centuries are calcium-dominant.

In 2001, a barium-dominant gismondine, "gismondine-Ba" has been discovered in slag material (of course not approved, as valid species, by IMA CNMNC).
The Ca an...

results.name: Nitroplumbite
results.description_short:
The most simple approved natural lead nitrate. Chemically somewhat similar to lislkirchnerite. Also compare 'Unnamed (Pb2(OH)3(NO3))' and 'Unnamed (Pb13O8(OH)6(NO3)4)'.

Known synthetic analogue.

results.name: Giuseppettite
results.description_short: Cancrinite Group.

results.name: Glaucophane
results.description_short: The Mg analogue of ferro-glaucophane.

results.name: Gladite
results.description_short: Aikinite-Bismuthinite Series.

results.name: Glaucocerinite
results.description_short: Compare also Woodwardite Group. Compare 'UM1985-07-OH:AlCuSZn' - corresponding to the alleged cotype specimen of glaucocerinite.

results.name: Glaucochroite
results.description_short: Olivine Group.

results.name: Glaucodot
results.description_short: See also the chemically similar Cobaltite (ideally CoAsS) and Alloclasite (richer in Co than glaucodot). Compare 'UM1966-01-As:CoNiS'.

results.name: Glaukosphaerite
results.description_short: Rosasite Group.

results.name: Glucine
results.description_short: Spherical clusters of white plates

results.name: Glushinskite
results.description_short:
The Fe analogue of lindbergite, andreybulakhite, humboldtine, and katsarosite.

Both alpha and beta forms are known as synthetic compounds.

Glushinskite is identical to the beta form.

The unnamed alpha form has been reported from the Lake Huleh...

results.name: Calciojohillerite
results.description_short:
The Ca analogue of johillerite. Chemically similar to berzeliite and paraberzeliite; also somewhat resembling anatolyite and currierite.

Known as a synthetic phase.

results.name: Gobbinsite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group.

results.name: Godlevskite
results.description_short:
Stoichimetrically similar to millerite.
Compare also the chemically related pentlandite and heazlewoodite.

results.name: Godovikovite
results.description_short:
The Al analogue of sabieite and the NH4 analogue of steklite.

Hydrates to tschermigite at room temperature. Slightly hygroscopic; dissolves slowly in water.
May occur in burning coal dumps as a dehydration product of tschermigite.

results.name: Goedkenite
results.description_short:
Originally found as small (< 1 mm) colorless crystals growing epitaxially and perpendicularly on palermoite crystals.

The PO4 analogue of Grandaite.

results.name: Goethite
results.description_short:
The most common simple iron oxide mineral. A weathering product of numerous iron-bearing minerals.

Goethite may crystallize from a precursor - a not approved species called 'proto-goethite'. May also form due to mineralization of lichen (Parmelia co...

results.name: Gold
results.description_short:
Copper Group. Gold-Silver Series and Gold-Palladium Series.

A native element and precious metal, gold has long been prized for its beauty, resistance to chemical attack and workability. As it is found as a native element, has a relatively low meltin...

results.name: Goldfieldite
results.description_short:
Related to stibiogoldfieldite by the substitution of 2Te4+ for 2Sb3+, charge-compensated by the development of two vacancies from the loss of two M2-site Cu+.

A temperature of formation between 350 and 450 °C was suggested based on an experimental s...

results.name: Goldmanite
results.description_short: Garnet Group

results.name: Gonnardite
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group. Natrolite Subgroup.
Most gonnardites have a disordered natrolite framework.

The compositions of and structural relationships between gonnardite and tetranatrolite remain controversial (Artioli and Galli 1999; Evans et al. 2000; Ross ...

results.name: Gonyerite
results.description_short: Compare also pennantite, a chemically similar, but Al-bearing, Mn-member of the chlorite group.

results.name: Goosecreekite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group.

results.name: Gorceixite
results.description_short: The Ba analogue of goyazite and crandallite.

results.name: Gordonite
results.description_short:
The magnesium analogue of Mangangordonite.

A rare secondary mineral formed from the alteration of variscite in nodules in limestone or as a late-stage hydrothermal mineral in complex granitic pegmatites.

results.name: Gormanite
results.description_short: Gormanite-Souzalite Series. The Fe2+ analogue of Souzalite.

results.name: Goslarite
results.description_short:
Epsomite Group; Epsomite-Goslarite Series

A complete series exists between goslarite and its Mg analogue epsomite in artificial material. There is apparently only limited substitution of Zn for Mg in natural material.

results.name: Goudeyite
results.description_short:
Mixite Group. 
Visually indistinguishable from other members of the mixite group.

results.name: Graftonite
results.description_short:
Beusite-Graftonite Series.

A primary phosphate mineral found in complex granitic pegmatites.
Chemically related to sarcopside.

Tait et al. (2013) observed that Ca may be dominant at M(1) in graftonite-like compositions and suggested a possible n...

results.name: Grandidierite
results.description_short: The Mg analogue of Ominelite. Chemically close to kornerupine.

results.name: Grandreefite
results.description_short:
A rare secondary lead sulphate fluoride.

Structurally related to Unnamed (Ba Thiosulphate Fluoride).

The higher indices of refraction, smaller 2V, and weaker dispersion are useful in distinguishing grandreefite from pseudograndreefite.

results.name: Graphite
results.description_short: Graphite usually occurs in flakes in metamorphosed rocks rich in carbon, but it can also be found in veins and in pegmatites. Where large deposits are found, it is mined and used as an industrial lubricant and for 'lead' in pencils. The crystallinity d...

results.name: Gratonite
results.description_short:
Compare baumhauerite, liveingite, sartorite, 'UM1966-04-S:AsPb'.

The structure contains isolated and interconnected AsS3 pyramids, as, e.g., in case of baumhauerite, dufrénoysite, sartorite, and seligmannite.

Chemically related to, and sometimes ...

results.name: Gravegliaite
results.description_short: Stoichiometry similar to that of albertiniite, an iron sulfite trihydrate, but different structure.

results.name: Grayite
results.description_short:
Originally powdery or cryptocrystalline. Rarely in subhedral resinous crystals.
Possibly identical to brockite? See also the dubious smirnovskite.

Compare 'UM1979-08-PO:CCaFeHREESiTh'; 'UM1980-04-PO:CaHREETh', 'UM1979-07-PO:CaFeHREESiTh'.

results.name: Greenalite
results.description_short: Kaolinite-Serpentine Group.

results.name: Greenockite
results.description_short: Typically found as yellow to red hemimorphic pyramidal crystals and earthy coatings. Caution should be used in sight identifying yellow cadmium sulfide coatings as hawleyite (dimorph of greenockite) is not a very rare species and occurs in identical ap...

results.name: Greigite
results.description_short:
Linnaeite Group and Thiospinel Group.
Strongly magnetic.

Iron thiospinel occurs always in small crystals to 0.03 mm and as an X-ray amorphous colloidal precipitate from an iron sulfide gel known as the melnikovite of Doss.
Greigite is metastable w...

results.name: Grimaldiite
results.description_short:
As with other Cr mineral species from the Merume River locality, such as bracewellite, guyanaite, and mcconnellite this species is NOT universally present in every specimen and verification of each specimen is required.

The structure may rather be r...

results.name: Grischunite
results.description_short: Wicksite Group. Chemically similar to manganohatertite.

results.name: Grossite
results.description_short: Grossite is the natural counterpart of the synthetic compound Ca-dialuminate (CaAl4O7).

results.name: Grossular
results.description_short:
Garnet Group. 
Andradite-Grossular Series, Grossular-Katoite Series, Grossular-Uvarovite Series, Pyrope-Grossular Series.

results.name: Groutite
results.description_short:
Diaspore Group.

Final product of laser-induced degradation of "groutellite" (a variety of ramsdellite), with hausmannite as a possible intermediate.

results.name: Grunerite
results.description_short:
Cummingtonite-Grunerite Series.

The original description of the mineral in 1847 incorrectly determined it to be a pyroxene.

results.name: Gruzdevite
results.description_short: Sb analogue of aktashite. HgSb-analogue of nowackiite and zhengminghuaite.

results.name: Guanajuatite
results.description_short:
The Se (or selenide) analogue of bismuthinite.

Easily distinguishable from the more common (in Guanajuato) paraguanajuatite if macroscopic as the latter has platy/foliated aggregates with perfect cleavage whereas guanajuatite resembles minerals of t...

results.name: Guanine
results.description_short:
Aromatic heterocycle (an organic cyclic carbon compound with additional, non-carbon atom(s)); a nucleobase and an important constituent of both DNA and RNA.

Spacing change of guanine crystals in the skin of chameleons is responsible for their showca...

results.name: Guarinoite
results.description_short: The Zn analogue of Unnamed (Co-analogue of Guarinoite). Chemically the Zn analogue of isselite.

results.name: Gudmundite
results.description_short: Arsenopyrite Group

results.name: Guérinite
results.description_short:
Acicular, bladed, or tabular crystals.

May be intergrown with jeankempite.

results.name: Guettardite
results.description_short: Related to twinnite (Sb:As ~ 13:8, bit variable) and hyršlite (Sb:As = 6:10).

results.name: Gugiaite
results.description_short: See also hydroxylgugiaite, related to gugiaite by a complex atomic exchange mechanism coupled with protonation.

results.name: Guildite
results.description_short: This mineral was formed under anthropogenic conditions (mine fire; Lausen, 1928) and would not be approved as a mineral species under current international rules.

results.name: Guilleminite
results.description_short: The Ba analogue of borzęckiite. Compare 'UM1966-05-SeO:BaHPbU'.

results.name: Gunningite
results.description_short:
Kieserite Group.

Soluble in water. May originate as a dehydration product of boyleite.

results.name: Gupeiite
results.description_short: One of many natural Fe-Si phases; beside the approved species (listed below) you may want to compare Unnamed (Fe silicide I), Unnamed (Fe silicide II) and UM2000-60-Si:Fe.

results.name: Gustavite
results.description_short:
Gustavite-Lillianite Series.

Natural gustavite appears to be monoclinic (Harris & Chen, 1975; Makovicky & Karup-Møller, 1977) due to Ag-Bi ordering, while synthetic gustavite was found to be orthorhombic (Bente et al., 1993).
An Sb-rich, monoclinic...

results.name: Guyanaite
results.description_short:
The β phase of CrO(OH). As with other Cr mineral species from the Merume River locality, such as bracewellite, grimaldiite, and mcconnellite, this species is NOT universally present in every specimen and verification of each specimen is required.

A ...

results.name: Gypsum
results.description_short:
The most common sulphate mineral.
Found as both massive material, including the alabaster variety; and clear crystals, the selenite variety; and, parallel fibrous, the satin spar variety. Typically colourless to white, transparent crystals, thick tabu...

results.name: Gyrolite
results.description_short: Gyrolite Group.

results.name: Gysinite-(Nd)
results.description_short: The lead analogue of calcioancylite-(Nd). The Nd analogue of gysinite-(La) and gysinite-(Ce).

results.name: Goyazite
results.description_short:
The strontium analogue of crandallite and plumbogummite, and the phosphate analogue of arsenogoyazite.

Compare svanbergite.

results.name: Haapalaite
results.description_short: Valleriite Group.

results.name: Hafnon
results.description_short:
Zircon Group. 

The hafnium analogue of Thorite and Zircon. Its physical properties are similar to those of zircon, so without an analysis it is not possible to positively identify a specimen as hafnon.
An isomorphous series exists between ZrSiO4-Hf...

results.name: Hagendorfite
results.description_short:
Alluaudite Group,  Hagendorfite-Varulite Series.

Note: Mücke & Keck (2011) propose a new formula: (Na,Ca,Mn)2Mn(Fe2+,Fe3+)2(PO4)3.

results.name: Haidingerite
results.description_short:
White crystals in brushy sprays.

The mineral has been confused with gypsum.

results.name: Hainite-(Y)
results.description_short:
Chemically close to fogoite-(Y).

Long regarded as a doubtful species, said to be related to rosenbuschite, but an independent species after all (Christiansen et al., 2003). The crystal structure of the type material has been determined by Giester et...

results.name: Hakite-(Hg)
results.description_short:
Tetrahedrite Group. Compare the chemically very similar pošepnýite, which may be its Hg4Cu2 analogue.

Renamed from hakite due to the acceptance of the IMA 18-K proposal.

results.name: Halite
results.description_short:
Natural sodium chloride (also named rocksalt; water-soluble). Occurs both as evaporite deposits in saline lakes and watercourses, or as bedded sedimentary deposits, or as salt domes.

Experimental volcanic gas condensation by Africano et al. (2002) s...

results.name: Hallimondite
results.description_short:
Hallimondite-Parsonsite Series.
The arsenate analogue of Parsonsite.

results.name: Cubo-ice
results.description_short:
Cubo-ice is better known as ice-VII.

Found as inclusion in a diamond from Orapa, Botswana.
Cubo-ice is structurally closely related to cuprite Cu2O.

results.name: Halloysite
results.description_short:
Typically found as earthy to somewhat waxy looking extremely fine-grained clayey masses, white to tan and also occasionally bluish or greenish. 

Metahalloysite is dehydrated halloysite and characterised by a reduced interlayer spacing.

Originally...

results.name: Halotrichite
results.description_short:
Halotrichite Group; Halotrichite-Pickeringite Series.
Fe(II) analogue of Pickeringite.

At least a partial series extends toward Apjohnite.

results.name: Hambergite
results.description_short: A pegmatite mineral often occurring with beryl.

results.name: Hammarite
results.description_short:
Aikinite-Bismuthinite Series.

Compare 'UM1984-23-S:BiCuPb'.

results.name: Hancockite
results.description_short: Clinozoisite Subgroup of the Epidote Group.

results.name: Haradaite
results.description_short: Haradaite Group.

results.name: Hardystonite
results.description_short: In daylight, natural hardystonite is a very non-descript massive ashen white mineral distinguished from massive calcite by a lack of cleavage and a somewhat greasy luster. (Note: Many photographers over-expose images of hardystonite to accentuate the b...

results.name: Harkerite
results.description_short:
White to tannish brown pseudo-octahedral crystals.

Structurally related to sakhaite with which it forms a solid solution (Sakhaite-Harkerite solid solution).

Compare UM1990-59-SiO:AlBCHMg.

Seems to be (in particular) a hydrochloride (chlorhydr...

results.name: Harmotome
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group. Harmotome-Phillipsite-Ca Series.

Less common than phillipsite, but often confused with the latter.

results.name: Harrisonite
results.description_short:
The material from Czech pegmatites is manganese- and phosphorus-bearing. The latter substitution is related to Si deficiency.

The pegmatitic occurrence suggests the mineral to be stable lower P–T conditions than these reported for the holotype (Vách...

results.name: Hashemite
results.description_short: Ba-analogue of tarapacáite. Stoichiometrically related to crocoite and chromatite. One of three minerals with essential Ba and Cr, the other two being hawthorneite and redledgeite.

results.name: Hastingsite
results.description_short: The hastingsite-group minerals are defined with 0.5 < A(Na+K+2Ca)<1.5 where Na or K is dominant and with the C position occupied by Mg or Fe2+ as dominant divalent ions and 0.5 < C(Al+Fe3+ +Cr+2Ti) < 1.5 where Fe3+ is dominant. W may contain (OH),F or ...

results.name: Hatchite
results.description_short:
Hatchite-Wallisite Series.

Small gray equant complex crystals.

results.name: Hatrurite
results.description_short:
An important phase in cement clinker (Alite, C3S).

Seven polymorphs of Ca3SiO5 are known; some are stabilised by impurities.

results.name: Hauchecornite
results.description_short: Hauchecornite Group.

results.name: Hauckite
results.description_short: Chemically somewhat similar to magnesioalterite.

results.name: Hauerite
results.description_short: Pyrite Group.

results.name: Hausmannite
results.description_short:
Forms a series with hetaerolite.

Hausmannite has a tetragonal distorted spinel structure (due to the Jahn-Teller distortion of the Mn3+-centred polyhedron). When heated above 1473 K, a cubic high-temperature phase appears (Frenzel 1980).

Hausmann...

results.name: Haüyne
results.description_short:
Sodalite Group. 
Also classed in the Feldspathoid Supergroup.

Ideally, the two sodalite cages in haüyne's unit cell contain Na^3CaSO^4.
Pale-coloured varieties are easily confused with nosean and darker, opaque blue ones, usually sulphide-bearing,...

results.name: Hawleyite
results.description_short: Yellow powdery coatings that also look like greenockite. Much that is attributed to greenockite is actually hawleyite.

results.name: Hawthorneite
results.description_short:
Unique combination of elements, although somewhat chemically similar to mathiasite and haggertyite.

The supposed Ti analogue (actually its Ti5Mg2Cr analogue) is IMA-coded as UM1994-07-O:BaCrFeMgTi.

results.name: Haycockite
results.description_short: Talnakhite group

results.name: Heazlewoodite
results.description_short: Compare also the chemically similar godlevskite. Possible analogues: 'UM2007-30-S:Fe', 'UM1978-15-S:IrOsPtRhRu', 'Unnamed (Ir-Os Sulphide; no. 2)' and 'Unnamed (Pt-Pd Sulphide)'.

results.name: Hectorfloresite
results.description_short:
Second sulphate-iodate mineral, the other being fuenzalidaite. One of two double salts in the NaIO3-Na2SO4-H2O system (at least at the time of the original publication). 

The structure is based on tha of the type I Na2SO4 phase, with 10 times its vo...

results.name: Hectorite
results.description_short: Smectite Group.

results.name: Hedenbergite
results.description_short:
Pyroxene Group - Clinopyroxene Subgroup.  See also the Hedenbergite-Johannsenite Series, Diopside-Hedenbergite Series, and the Hedenbergite-Petedunnite solid solution. 

Compare UM2004-50-SiO:AlFeGd.

results.name: Hedleyite
results.description_short:
Relatively common member of the tetradymite group (Ciobanu et al., 2009).

Tin white metallic plates with perfect basal cleavage, mm thick to cm in width. Crystals have hexagonal outline, often with trigonal growth features. 
Impossible to visually ...

results.name: Hedyphane
results.description_short:
A relatively rare mineral of the Apatite Supergroup found in metamorphosed manganese deposits. The Pb3Ca2 analogue of Turneaureite and Mimetite. The arsenate analogue of Phosphohedyphane. Also the chlorine analogue of hydroxylhedyphane.

Pb and Ca at...

results.name: Heinrichite
results.description_short:
Autunite Group.

Unstable at room temperature and dehydrates fairly rapidly to metaheinrichite (Walenta, 1965) which may be fully transparent. Most of the specimens shown on the photos here are probably metaheinrichite.

results.name: Hejtmanite
results.description_short:
The Mn analogue of bafertisite (redefined as so basing on the Mbolve Hill material). 

Previously reported to be monoclinic, which was proved wrong. 

Chemistry is somewhat similar to that of perraultite. Compare UM1989-33-SiO:BaHMnTi.

Hejtmanit...

results.name: Tilkerodeite
results.description_short:
The Pd analogue of jacutingaite. Not chemically unique among the approved minerals: compare tischendorfite.

Note: not to be confused with 'tilkerodite (of Haidinger)'.

results.name: Hellyerite
results.description_short: Hellyerite is relatively unstable and, if not kept in an air-tight environment, the (originally) blue mineral decomposes in time to an X-ray amorphous, zaratite-like green phase, and other secondary nickel minerals  (Anderson et al., 2002; Bottrill & B...

results.name: Helmutwinklerite
results.description_short: Tsumcorite Group.

results.name: Helvine
results.description_short:
Helvine Group. Danalite-Helvine Series, and the Genthelvite-Helvine Series.
The IMA officially recognized name (2012 IMA list) is helvine, not helvite, although the synonym "helvite" may be more common in the literature.

The largest crystals known ...

results.name: Hematite
results.description_short:
Hematite Group. The iron analogue of Corundum, Eskolaite, and Karelianite.

Hematite is rather variable in its appearance - it can be in reddish brown, ocherous masses, dark silvery-grey scaled masses, silvery-grey to black crystals, and dark-grey ma...

results.name: Hematolite
results.description_short: Dark blood-red platy crystals (< 1 mm) and crusts.

results.name: Hemihedrite
results.description_short:
Hemihedrite-Iranite Series. The zinc analogue of Iranite.

A reinvestigation of type material showed that the original F determination was erroneous and the mineral is in fact clearly OH-dominant (Lafuente et al., 2017).

results.name: Hemimorphite
results.description_short:
Fake Blue Hemimorphite Crystals
Coated hemimorphite
In 2020 a number of electric-blue crystals of hemimorphite crystals came to market, from the Ojuela mine, Mapimi, Mexico. These have been proven to be deceptively stained using the artificial compou...

results.name: Hemusite
results.description_short: The Mo analogue of kiddcreekite.

results.name: Hendricksite
results.description_short: Mica Group. The zinc analogue of phlogopite, annite, and shirozulite. The only Zn-dominant mica currently known.

results.name: Heneuite
results.description_short: As cleavable, pale blue-green, nodular masses several cms across. The nodules are rimmed by a thin layer of althausite, which in turn is surrounded by massive apatite.

results.name: Hennomartinite
results.description_short: Sr analogue of noelbensonite.

results.name: Henritermierite
results.description_short: Garnet Group. The Mn(III) analogue of Holtstamite.

results.name: Hentschelite
results.description_short: May be confused with the chemically similar chalcosiderite (which, however, has a Cu:Fe ratio of 1:6).

results.name: Hercynite
results.description_short: Spinel Group, Al series. Chromite-Hercynite Series. Gahnite-Hercynite Series, Spinel-Hercynite Series.

results.name: Herderite
results.description_short:
Herderite-Hydroxylherderite Series. The fluorine-dominant analogue of Hydroxylherderite. Herderite is isotypic with Datolite.

Found usually as a pegmatite mineral formed during late-stage hydrothermal deposition.

Warning: Most specimens labeled "...

results.name: Herzenbergite
results.description_short:
Herzenbergite-Teallite Series.

Discovered by Roberto Herzenberg, who named it "kolbeckine". A better description was later published by Ramdohr, who renamed it after Herzenberg.

results.name: Hessite
results.description_short: Above 155°C hessite is cubic, and on cooling below this temperature it develops fine phase transformation lamellae.

results.name: Hetaerolite
results.description_short:
Forms a series with hausmannite.
See also the poorly characterised hydrohetaerolite.

Often associated with chalcophanite.

results.name: Heterogenite
results.description_short:
Abstract from Burlet et al. (2016):
"Heterogenite is commonly referred in mineralogy literature as a cobalt oxy-hydroxide CoO(OH). However, detailed analysis of Raman and infrared spectra acquired on particularly well-crystallized natural samples of h...

results.name: Heteromorphite
results.description_short:
This mineral is an intermediate member of a homologous series. The thickness of a galena sheet in the structure determines the series member. A very rare mineral.

Feather ores ("plumosite" = jamesonite, boulangerite etc.) have often been mislabeled ...

results.name: Heterosite
results.description_short:
Triphylite Group, Heterosite-Purpurite Series.

The species of this series are secondary minerals formed by oxidation of iron and or manganese with the simultaneous leaching of lithium from primary phosphates (precursors), lithiophilite or triphylite...

results.name: Hewettite
results.description_short:
A secondary mineral resulting from the alteration of patronite (TL), or from the alteration of less-oxidized vanadium minerals.

May reversibly dehydrate to metahewettite.

results.name: Hexahydrite
results.description_short:
Hexahydrite Group. 
May dehydrate to starkeyite (Chou, 2005).

results.name: Heyite
results.description_short: Identical with calderonite (U. Kolitsch, unpublished data; discreditation proposal to be submitted to IMA).

results.name: Hibbingite
results.description_short: Hibbingite-Kempite series. Soluble in water and in ethanol.

results.name: Hibonite
results.description_short: Magnetoplumbite Group.

results.name: Hidalgoite
results.description_short:
The arsenate analogue of hinsdalite and the Al analogue of beudantite.
Forms solid solutions with the arsenate member philipsbornite.

results.name: Hilgardite
results.description_short:
Hilgardite Group.

Several polytypes are known, as well as Sr-bearing varieties.

results.name: Hillebrandite
results.description_short: White fibrous crystals typical. Compare 'UM1977-14-SiO:CaH'.

results.name: Hingganite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
The Ce analogue of Hingganite-(Y).

The existence of a Ce-analogue was known for a long time and the name hingganite-(Ce) was in rather common use in the mineralogical literature, but it was only accepted as a valid species in 2004 (IMA2004-004) from...

results.name: Hingganite-(Y)
results.description_short:
Y analogue of hingganite-(Yb) and hingganite-(Ce). Also the vacancy analogue of Unnamed (OH-analogue of gadolinite-(Y)).
Difficult to distinguish from gadolinite-(Y).

Nd-dominant analogue is also known.

results.name: Hingganite-(Yb)
results.description_short: The Yb analogue of hingganite-(Y), hingganite-(Ce), and hingganite-(Nd). One of a very few Yb-dominant approved minerals, the others being keiviite-(Yb), samarskite-(Yb), xenotime-(Yb) and the (rather not approved) hellandite-(Yb). Compare also ytterbium.

results.name: Hinsdalite
results.description_short:
The Al analogue of corkite and the phosphate analogue of hidalgoite.
Distinguishable from plumbogummite, with which it forms a complete solid-solution series, only by determination of the P:S ratio.

An uncommon secondary mineral occurring in the ox...

results.name: Hiortdahlite
results.description_short:
A sorosilicate mineral belonging to the Wöhlerite Group with crystal structure containing two topologically independent ochtahedral walls.

Originally reported by Brøgger (1888, 1890) from "Mittel-Arø", Langesundsfjorden, Norway. He referred to a 10 ...

results.name: Hisingerite
results.description_short:
Hisingerite-Neotocite Series.
Amorphous to poorly crystalline hydrated iron(III) layer silicate.
Probably has a curved, kaolinite-like structure.

Compare the visually similar siderogel.

Often partly altered to nontronite.

Note on the type lo...

results.name: Hocartite
results.description_short: Stannite Group. Hocartite-Pirquitasite Series.

results.name: Hochelagaite
results.description_short: Probably the lower-hydrate counterpart of 'Unnamed MSH UK56'.

results.name: Hodrušite
results.description_short: Structurally closely related to cuprobismutite and kupčíkite.

results.name: Hoelite
results.description_short: Chemically 9,10-anthraquinone (also known as anthracene-9,10-dione) - a diketone derivative of the polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon anthracene.

results.name: Hohmannite
results.description_short: Rapidly dehydrates to metahohmannite on exposure to air. Decomposes in hot water.

results.name: Hollandite
results.description_short:
In 2012, the IMA revised the nomenclature of the Hollandite Supergroup (Biagioni et al., 2013). 
Hollandite is now redefined as the (more widespread) Ba-Mn3+ end-member of the coronadite group; concurrently, type hollandite is redefined as ferrihollan...

results.name: Hollingworthite
results.description_short:
Hollingworthite-Irarsite Series. 

An Sb analogue may be known (UM1976-16-S:IrRhSb).

results.name: Holmquistite
results.description_short: Holmquistite is the most common of the lithium amphiboles. It is almost exclusively formed in the reaction zone between Li-pegmatites and their host rock, predominantly as a metasomatic alteration product of pre-existing amphiboles. It generally occurs...

results.name: Holtedahlite
results.description_short: Occurs as irregular masses and patches. It's difficult to visually distinguish between holtedahlite and the associated apatite. It typically contains inclusions of small magnetite grains which may impart a greyish color to it (Raade & Mladeck 1979)

results.name: Holtite
results.description_short:
Note: Groat et al. (2008) give the formula (Ta,[],Al)Al6(BO3)(Si,Sb,As)3O12(O,OH,[])3. 

Closely related to dumortierite.

results.name: Homilite

results.name: Honessite

Often occurs as pseudomorphs after acicular millerite.
May convert readily into hydrohonessite, depending on humidity and temperature.

results.name: Hörnesite
results.description_short:

results.name: Hotsonite
results.description_short: White, chalk-like incrustations.

results.name: Howardevansite
results.description_short: Structurally related to grigorievite and koksharovite.

results.name: Howlite

results.name: Huanghoite-(Ce)

Note: This species is misclassified in Dana 8th.  There are...

results.name: Huemulite
results.description_short: Easily soluble in water.

results.name: Hulsite
results.description_short: The Fe2+ analogue of Magnesiohulsite.

results.name: Humboldtine
results.description_short:
The Fe analogue of lindbergite, glushinskite, andreybulakhite, and katsarosite.

results.name: Humite

results.name: Huntite
results.description_short: Huntite forms compact fibrous chalky masses. It is found in caverns in magnesian rocks.

results.name: Huttonite
results.description_short:
Appears to be the high-temperature modification of ThSiO4 (synthetic crystals form at 1225 +/- 10°C whereas thorite forms below this temperature; Finch et al. 1964).

results.name: Hydroxylbastnäsite-(Ce)
results.description_short: The hydroxyl analogue of Bastnäsite-(Ce); the cerium analogue of Hydroxylbastnäsite-(La) and Hydroxylbastnäsite-(Nd). Bastnäsite-(Ce)-Hydroxylbastnäsite-(Ce) Series.

results.name: Hyalotekite
results.description_short: The Ba analogue of khvorovite. The Ca2SiB analogue of kapitsaite-(Y). The crystal structure is very closely related to that of itsiite - its B2[] (B2-vacancy-) analogue.

results.name: Hydroxylherderite
results.description_short:
Herderite-Hydroxylherderite Series. The hydroxyl-dominant analogue of Herderite. Hydroxylherderite is isotypic with Datolite.

results.name: Hydrobasaluminite
results.description_short:

results.name: Hydrobiotite
results.description_short:
A 1:1 regular interstratification of Biotite and Vermiculite layers. 
Compare the chemically similar stilpnomelane.

See also hydromuscovite.

results.name: Hydrocalumite
results.description_short:
The range of composition currently ascribed to hydrocalumite may represent more than one species (Mills et al., 2012). 
Several hydrocalumite-related species have been described as synthetic compounds ('AFm phases' in cement mineralogy).

results.name: Hydrocerussite
results.description_short: Hydrocerussite is a secondary mineral usually found in oxidized lead ore deposits. It it less common than cerussite (anhydrous lead carbonate). Also reported as a mycobiont of the Stereocaulon vesuvianum lichen found in a ruined Pb-smelting mill (vide ...

results.name: Hydrodresserite
results.description_short: Visually similar to dresserite.  In contrast to dresserite, hydrodresserite's characteristic features are that it forms coarser crystals, resulting in rougher spheres, and hydrodresserite crystals are more translucent than dresserite.

results.name: Hydroglauberite
results.description_short:
An uncommon alteration product of glauberite.

Chemically related to eugsterite, antofagastaite, omongwaite, and partially to cesanite.

results.name: Hydrohalite
results.description_short:
Often found in fluid inclusions.
Melts under its own vapor pressure at –0.1 °C, converting to halite.

results.name: Hydrohonessite
results.description_short:
May convert readily into honessite, depending on humidity and temperature.

Appears to be stable between pH 6 and 7.

results.name: Hydromagnesite
results.description_short:

results.name: Hydrombobomkulite
results.description_short: See also mbobomkulite.  Dehydrates rapidly (hours) to mbobomkulite.

results.name: Hydroniumjarosite
results.description_short:
Typically ocherous, amber to dark brown granular masses or crystalline to earthy crusts.

May be confused with ammoniojarosite, natrojarosite, jarosite and other visually similar member of the alunite supergroup.

results.name: Hydroscarbroite
results.description_short:

See also Scarbroite.

results.name: Hydrotalcite
results.description_short:
Is a member of the hydrotalcite group and  hydrotalcite supergroup.

results.name: Hydroxycancrinite

results.name: Hydroxylapatite

results.name: Hydrozincite

results.name: Hypercinnabar
results.description_short:
The high-temperature phase of mercury sulphide, HgS. It shows a slight deficiency in Hg [Clark, 1993 - "Hey's Mineral Index"]. 
Structurally related to the Wurtzite Group.

Intimately associated with metacinnabar, which it generally resembles.
