results.name: Kamiokite
results.description_short: The iron analogue of iseite and majindeite.

results.name: Kamotoite-(Y)
results.description_short: One of 4 currently known yttrium-uranium(uranyl) minerals of the natural salts class; the other representatives of this group are bijvoetite-(Y) (carbonate), alwilkinsite-(Y) and sejkoraite-(Y) (sulphates). Kamotoite-(Y) is thus the second natural Y-U ...

results.name: Kamphaugite-(Y)
results.description_short: Related to tengerite-(Y) and similar minerals. A result of  low-temperature hydrothermal alteration of yttrium-bearing minerals in granitic rocks, often found in cavities and cracks. At the TL kamphaugite-(Y) may have a coating of montmorillonite.

results.name: Kanemite
results.description_short:
Cleaved aggregates may appear similar to gypsum.

May dehydrate to Unnamed (Kanemite-related mineral).

results.name: Kaňkite
results.description_short:
Related to and easily confused with hilarionite. Compare 'UM1979-03-AsO:Fe' and 'UM1979-04-AsO:Fe'.
Often associated with bukovskýite.

Crystal structure not yet solved, as the mineral decomposes in vacuum to Fe2(AsO4)(HAsO4)(OH)(H2O), that equals F...

results.name: Kanoite
results.description_short: Pyroxene Group - Clinopyroxene Subgroup.

results.name: Kanonaite
results.description_short: Andalusite-Kanonaite Series.

results.name: Kaolinite
results.description_short: Mineral used in pre-historic times. Presumably the most important mineral in clay used in pre-historic pottery. The photo http://www.mindat.org/photo-620484.html shows the Sumerian symbol for clay. חלבנהπη in Hebrew. λός in Greek. Lutum in Latin. Kaoli...

results.name: Karelianite
results.description_short:
Hematite Group. The vanadium analogue of Corundum, Eskolaite, and Hematite.

A metastable polymorph with a bixbyite-type structure is known as a synthetic compound (Weber et al., 2011; Lüdtke et al., 2017).

results.name: Karibibite
results.description_short:
A rare iron arsenite. So far, it always originated as a weathering product of löllingite.
Visually similar to ludlockite.
Compare also 'UM1971-02-AsO:Fe'.


The structure seems to have been solved just recently (Mugnaioli, 2016; Colombo et al., 20...

results.name: Carpathite
results.description_short: Chemically identical to coronene, a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH).

results.name: Karpinskite
results.description_short:
Possibly a Ni-rich antigorite or a Ni-rich interstratification of a talc-group mineral and a chlorite-group mineral.

Status needs to be confirmed.

results.name: Kashinite
results.description_short: The Ir analogue of bowieite. Possibly also analogous to UM1978-17-S:IrOsPtRu and  UM1993-21-S:IrOsRu.

results.name: Kasolite
results.description_short:
Possibly the Pb analogue of unnamed phase 'UM1956-02-SiO:CaHU'. The only accepted Pb-U silicate mineral. Chemically similar to 'orlite'.

Crystal structure details:

- uranyl silicate layers of the uranophane sheet anion-topology
- Pb atoms and wa...

results.name: Katoite
results.description_short:
Grossular-Katoite Series. Compare also the tetragonal-pseudocubic Holtstamite.
Ungrouped member of the Garnet Supergroup.

For x = 3, i.e. the end member, the species is also known as C3AH6 ("Tricalcium aluminate hydrate") in hydrated cement.
See a...

results.name: Kawazulite
results.description_short: Tetradymite Group.

results.name: Kazakovite
results.description_short: Lovozerite Group

results.name: Keckite
results.description_short:
A member of the jahnsite group which contains trivalent iron not only at the C site but also at the B site.

Note: According to Hochleitner & Fehr (2010), keckite from Hagendorf forms golden-yellow to orange fibrous crusts which are intimately associ...

results.name: Keithconnite
results.description_short: Compare UM1991-26-Te:AsPd.

results.name: Keiviite-(Y)
results.description_short: Keiviite-(Y)-Keiviite-(Yb) Series.

results.name: Keiviite-(Yb)
results.description_short: Keiviite-(Y)-Keiviite-(Yb) Series.

results.name: Kemmlitzite
results.description_short:
The Sr analogue of hidalgoite.
The Al analogue of oberwolfachite.
The As analogue of svanbergite.

results.name: Kempite
results.description_short: Hibbingite-Kempite Series. The second purely-manganese chloride mineral after scacchite.

results.name: Kentrolite
results.description_short:
Kentrolite-Melanotekite Series.

A synthetic aluminium analogue is known.

results.name: Kermesite
results.description_short: Crusts and coatings may be confused with metastibnite.

results.name: Kësterite
results.description_short: Stannite Group. The zinc analogue of ferrokësterite. Compare 'UM1981-19-S:CuSnZn'.

results.name: Kettnerite
results.description_short:
A rare secondary Ca-Bi carbonate visually indistinguishable from bismutite and beyerite. 

The possible Cl analogue is known as UM1991-05-CO:BiCaCl.

results.name: Keyite
results.description_short: The Cd-dominant analogue of erikapohlite.

results.name: Keystoneite
results.description_short:
Ni-analogue of kinichilite and zemannite. The Ni-Fe-analogue of ilirneyite.

Chemically and structurally related to wortupaite.

results.name: Khademite
results.description_short: Compare also jurbanite and rostite.

results.name: Khamrabaevite
results.description_short:
Possibly the V analogue of 'UM1989-04-C:TiV'.

Synthetic titanium carbide is a very important high-performance ceramic.

results.name: Khinite
results.description_short: Two polytypes are known, khinite-4O (orthorhombic) and khinite-3T (trigonal). The two polytypes have different stackings of otherwise identical layers of composition [Cu3(TeO6)(OH)2]2-, with Pb2+ cations between the layers.

results.name: Khristovite-(Ce)
results.description_short: Chemically related to dissakisite-(Ce), dollaseite-(Ce), manaevite-(Ce), gatelite-(Ce), and västmanlandite-(Ce).

results.name: Kiddcreekite
results.description_short: The W analogue of hemusite.

results.name: Kidwellite
results.description_short:
Occurs as replacement of rockbridgeite and beraunite. 
Dufrénite or natrodufrénite may overgrow, in an epitaxial way, kidwellite, and vice-versa.

May be confused with meurigite-Na.

results.name: Kieserite
results.description_short:
Kieserite Group.
Forms a complete solid solution with szomolnokite (Talla and Wildner, 2019).

A solid solution with cobaltkieserite is known at least in the synthetic state, lacking miscibility gap and cation ordering (Bechtold and Wildner, 2016).

results.name: Killalaite
results.description_short: Related to dellaite and trabzonite.

results.name: Kimzeyite
results.description_short:
Garnet Group.
Aluminium analogue of Kerimasite.

results.name: Kingsmountite
results.description_short: Fe(II) analogue of Montgomeryite. Also ferrous iron analogue of fanfaniite.

results.name: Kinichilite
results.description_short: Mn-analogue of zemannite and keystoneite. Also Mn(2+)-Fe-analogue of ilirneyite.

results.name: Kinoite
results.description_short: According to the published type description (Anthony, John W., Laughton, Robert B. (1970) Kinoite, A new hydrous copper calcium silicate mineral from Arizona. The American Mineralogist, 55(5-6), 709-713.) the type locality is https://www.mindat.org/loc...

results.name: Kintoreite
results.description_short:
The phosphate analogue of segnitite. Forms a solid-solution series with corkite and segnitite (Kintoreite-Segnitite Series).

Related to kolitschite.

results.name: Kipushite
results.description_short:
The phosphate analogue of philipsburgite ("partial" analogy) and fully phosphate analogue of goldhillite. 
Chemically related to veszelyite and zincolibethenite.

The Zn site, of tetrahedral coordination, in the kipushite-philipsburgite solid soluti...

results.name: Kirschsteinite
results.description_short:
Olivine Group. Kirschsteinite-Monticellite Series.

Not too uncommon in Fe-rich slags.
Also a significant accessory mineral in the angrite group of achondrites (meteorites).

results.name: Kittatinnyite
results.description_short: One specimen only known.

results.name: Kladnoite
results.description_short: Chemically identical to phthalimide (phthalic acid imide, systematically named isoindole-1,3-dione; also known as 1,3-dioxoisoindole - a derivative of the heterocyclic compound, i.e., non-carbon-containing carbon cyclic organic compound, indole).

results.name: Klebelsbergite
results.description_short: The Sb analogue of tavagnascoite.

results.name: Klockmannite
results.description_short:
The Se analogue of covellite. The Cu analogue of achávalite, freboldite, and sederholmite.

Three structural modifications are analyzed by Milman (2002). Unstable under compression (will decompose to umangite and krut'aite).

results.name: Knorringite
results.description_short: Garnet Group. Knorringite-Pyrope Series.

results.name: Koashvite
results.description_short: Lovozerite Group. A possible trigonal polymorph is known as 'UM1980-20-SiO:CaFeHMnNaTi'.

results.name: Kobeite-(Y)
results.description_short: A metamict member of the euxenite group.

results.name: Kobellite
results.description_short: The bismuth analogue of tintinaite.

results.name: Kochkarite
results.description_short: Aleksite Group.

results.name: Koechlinite
results.description_short:
A rare secondary mineral occurring in the oxidation zones of Bi-Mo deposits.

The molybdate analogue of russellite.

results.name: Kogarkoite
results.description_short: Has low solubility at high temperatures in the presence of water vapor.

results.name: Kolbeckite
results.description_short:
Metavariscite Group. The P analogue of bonacinaite.

A very rare secondary mineral in phosphate deposits and some hydrothermal veins.

results.name: Kolfanite
results.description_short: An insufficiently described Ca-Fe-arsenate; possibly identical to arseniosiderite (unit cell and PXRD pattern are fairly similar).

results.name: Kolicite
results.description_short: Kolicite is rare at the type locality, the Sterling Mine, Ogdensburg. Only one specimen has been identified from the Franklin Mine, Franklin to date.

results.name: Kolovratite
results.description_short:
According to Jambor & Lachance (1962), kolovratite is a hydrous zinc-nickel vanadate, or perhaps silico-vanadate, rather than a nickel vanadate as originally reported.

Probably needs a reinvestigation with modern methods.

Occurs in quartz schists...

results.name: Kolwezite
results.description_short: Probably Rosasite Group.

results.name: Komarovite
results.description_short: See also natrokomarovite.

results.name: Kombatite
results.description_short: Chemically similar to erikjonssonite, hereroite, janchevite, and vanadinite.

results.name: Komkovite
results.description_short: Possibly formed (type material) by alteration of catapleiite.

results.name: Konderite
results.description_short: May be the Pb analogue of (the Fe-dominant) UM2004-40-S:CuFeIrPbPdRh.

results.name: Konyaite
results.description_short:
Higher-hydrate counterpart of blödite.

A water-soluble mineral that occurs as a component of salt efflorescences on saline soils, formed between 30°C and 50°C by evaporation of ground and surface waters.

Related to the Picromerite Group.

Compa...

results.name: Koritnigite
results.description_short: Compare cardite.

results.name: Kornerupine
results.description_short: Kornerupine-Prismatine Series.

results.name: Potassic-mangani-leakeite
results.description_short: Forms a solid solution with eckermannite.

results.name: Korzhinskite
results.description_short: Compare the anhydrous calcium borate calciborite.

results.name: Kosmochlor
results.description_short:
Pyroxene Group - Clinopyroxene Subgroup.
Jadeite-Kosmochlor Series.

A rare, bright green pyroxene, found in some jade deposits and meteorites.
Also a colouring component of the decorative rock Maw Sit Sit.

Compare UM2003-36-SiO:CaNa.

results.name: Kotoite
results.description_short: Type locality has white to colorless masses in dolomite.

results.name: Köttigite
results.description_short:
Vivianite Group. Köttigite-Parasymplesite Series. 
The zinc analogue of parasymplesite and erythrite.

results.name: Kotulskite
results.description_short: Member of isomorphic series Kotulskite-Sobolevskite and  Kotulskite-Sudburyite. Compare, e.g., michenerite and UM1997-55-Te:BiPd.

results.name: Kratochvílite
results.description_short:
Organic compound formed in burning pyritic shale or coal fires. It is uncertain whether kratochvíllite is the chemical fluorene (more specifically: 9H-fluorene) (C13H10) or anthracene (C14H10) - further study of type material needed.

Note (04.04.202...

results.name: Krautite
results.description_short: A synthetic triclinic polymorph of MnHAsO4(H2O), which does not show a direct group-subgroup relation with monoclinic krautite, is closely related with other triclinic M(II)HAsO4(H2O) (M = Co, Cu, Zn, Mg) mineral phases (Weil et al., 2022).

results.name: Kremersite
results.description_short:
Very deliquescent, survives only under favourable ambient conditions. 

Usually as tiny crystals, sometimes fibrous. Relatively large, deep red crystals, up to ca. 3 mm in size, were found coalesced in a single block from a burning heap in Radlin, Po...

results.name: Krennerite
results.description_short:
Closely related to calaverite.

See also sylvanite. Maximal contents of silver in krennerite are 5-7 wt.%.

Krennerite, Sylvanite, and Calaverite can be easily distinguished by their cleavage or its absence. Krennerite has a perfect cleavage on {00...

results.name: Kribergite
results.description_short: Related to sanjuanite.

results.name: Kröhnkite
results.description_short: The anhydrous phase is saranchinaite which may form after heating kröhnkite to 200°C.

results.name: Krupkaite
results.description_short: Aikinite-Bismuthinite Series.

results.name: Krut'aite
results.description_short: Krut'aite-Trogtalite Series.

results.name: Krutovite
results.description_short: Probably a member of the Pyrite Group (Strunz and Nickel, 2001). Synthetic NiAs^2 has a pyrite-type structure (Munson, 1968).

results.name: Kryzhanovskite
results.description_short:
Garyansellite-Kryzhanovskite Series.

Can be derived from phosphoferrite by oxidation.

results.name: Ktenasite
results.description_short:
Rare secondary copper-zinc sulphate with typical pseudo-orthorhombic habit.
The Zn analogue of gobelinite and fehrite.

Mg- or Cd-bearing varieties are also known (U. Kolitsch & G. Giester, unpublished results), as well as a Zn-dominant (on one of t...

results.name: Kukisvumite
results.description_short:
The Zn analogue of manganokukisvumite and (the Zn0.5-analogue of) lintisite. AM-4 family of natural titanosilicates.

Compare the other two group members: eliseevite and punkaruaivite.

results.name: Kuksite
results.description_short:
Dugganite Group.

Forms a solid solution (and is isostructural) with joëlbruggerite and dugganite.

results.name: Kulanite
results.description_short: Kulanite-Penikisite Series.

results.name: Kulkeite
results.description_short: A 1:1 regular interstratification of a trioctahedral chlorite and talc.

results.name: Kupletskite
results.description_short: Kupletskite-Kupletskite-(Cs) Series. The potassium analogue of Kupletskite-(Cs). Alters easily to porous black manganese oxides.

results.name: Kuramite
results.description_short:
Stannite group.

Compare also the varieties, stannoenargite and stannoluzonite, and other Cu-Sn sulphides: erazoite and 'UM1981-18-S:CuSn'.

results.name: Kurchatovite
results.description_short: Hayashi et al. (2017) report a Fe(II) analogue (Mg-rich).

results.name: Kurilite
results.description_short: It was published in 1989, abstracted in Am. Min. in 1992, is in the ICDD PDF database as 00-45-1399. "It was not submitted to the New Minerals Commission of the IMA at that time, although it was formally discredited (Burke 2006), as being possibly syno...

results.name: Kurnakovite
results.description_short: Inderite Group.

results.name: Kurumsakite
results.description_short: Needs reinvestigation.

results.name: Kutinaite
results.description_short: Restudy of the type material is necessary (Bindi & Makovicky, 2015).

results.name: Kutnohorite
results.description_short:
Dolomite Group. Ankerite-Kutnohorite Series.

The cation ordering is temperature-dependent: Unpublished studies cited by Goldsmith and Graf (1960) indicate that cation disordering in synthetic CaMn(CO3)2 begins at approximately 450°C. CaMn(CO3)2 form...

results.name: Kuzminite
results.description_short: Calomel-Kuzminite Series.

results.name: Kuznetsovite
results.description_short: According to Borisov et al. (2003) it might be possible that kuzetsovite - as terlinguaite - contains the [Hg3]4+ polycation.

results.name: Kyanite
results.description_short:
Common metamorphic silicate mineral.
The generally bluish colour is caused by Fe(II)-Fe(III) charge transfer (Faye and Nickel, 1969).

results.name: Kyzylkumite
results.description_short: Compare Unnamed (Complex Be-V-Ti Oxide).

results.name: Kinoshitalite
results.description_short:
Mica Group.

The hydroxyl analogue of fluorokinoshitalite.

results.name: Labuntsovite-Mn
results.description_short: This is the original labuntsovite. It is now designated labuntsovite-Mn for the dominance of manganese among the divalent cations.

results.name: Lacroixite
results.description_short: Frequently occurs as grains and rods in the altered margins of blocky crystals and grains of amblygonite or montebrasite embedded in granite pegmatite matrix. Not usually found in montebrasite crystals extending into cavities. Pure grains of lacroixite...

results.name: Laffittite
results.description_short: As analogue of UM1993-09-S:AgHgSb.

results.name: Laihunite
results.description_short:
Olivine Group.
Corresponds to a strongly oxidised, vacancy-bearing fayalite.
The "polytypes" 1M, 2M and 3M seem to be distinct intermediate phases (between laihunite and fayalite) with defined stoichiometries (Xu et al., 2014): 2M has a 1:1 ratio and...

results.name: Laitakarite
results.description_short: A continuous solid-solution series with ikunolite, Bi4S3, probably exists (Schramm et al., 2023).

results.name: Lammerite
results.description_short: May form a solid solution with its possible P (phosphate) analogue, 'UM1984-21-PO:AsCu'.

results.name: Lamprophyllite
results.description_short: Two polytypes are known, Lamprophyllite-2M and Lamprophyllite-2O.

results.name: Lanarkite
results.description_short: White to greyish-white or greenish-white prismatic crystals, often in clusters or sprays, usually tiny to microscopic.

results.name: Landauite
results.description_short: Member of Crichtonite Group. ~Na analogue of almeidaite and ~NaZn-analogue of senaite (without considering the Fe valency).

results.name: Landesite
results.description_short:
Occurs as an alteration product of reddingite.

Compare the chemically closely related correianevesite.

results.name: Langbeinite
results.description_short: The Mg analogue of calciolangbeinite.

results.name: Langisite
results.description_short: Nickeline Group.

results.name: Langite
results.description_short:
A secondary copper mineral formed from the oxidation of copper sulphides. 
Often forms pseudohexagonal twins. Some habits are easily confused with posnjakite and wroewolfeite. 

May be altered to brochantite.

results.name: Lansfordite
results.description_short: Stable for several months at RT (Nestola et al., 2017), but may slowly dehydrate, ultimately altering to nesquehonite.

results.name: Lanthanite-(La)
results.description_short:
Note on TL:
Lanthanite that was first described from Bastnäs, Sweden by Berzelius (1824). In the mid-80s Bastnäs lanthanite was assumed to be La-dominant, and thus named as lanthanite-(La). However Atencio et al. (1989) reexaminates lanthanite from Ba...

results.name: Laphamite
results.description_short:
The Se analogue of orpiment. Compare kalgoorlieite - the chemical (Te) analogue, but not isostructural with laphamite.

Caveat: Some (or all?) of the photographs showing yellow acicular material might depict Se-bearing orpiment rather than laphamite....

results.name: Larnite
results.description_short:
The high-temperature, monoclinic polymorph of Calcio-Olivine.

Larnite crystallizes at high temperatures. It occurs in limestones or chalk zones in contact with molten basaltic rocks. Larnite is stable in the range of 520° to 670° C; otherwise, it is...

results.name: Larosite
results.description_short: Note: Electron microbe analyses of larosite from Norway (Cook et al., 2010) gave Cu20.47Ag3.68Fe0.22Pb1.01Bi1.06S15.00 calculated on the basis of 15 S atoms.

results.name: Larsenite
results.description_short: A very rare lead silicate found on fracture surfaces and in cavities in massive ore. It occurs in bright colorless to cloudy white, usually free-standing groups of acicular to bladed crystals, and has a very high luster. Chlorophoenicite has been frequ...

results.name: Latiumite
results.description_short: A 2D-zeolite that - alongside with the related tuscanite - may be considered a prototype of advanced ion-exchange & ion/proton conductivity materials.

results.name: Latrappite
results.description_short: The status of latrappite has been questioned. Following Mitchell et al. 2016, the significant Fe3+ content was not considered by Nickel (1964) and the material investigated by Nickel (1964) and Nickel and McAdam (1963) was found to be a complex quatern...

results.name: Laueite
results.description_short: The Mn2+ analogue of ferrolaueite.

results.name: Laumontite
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group. Laumontite Subgroup.

Normally it dehydrates in air to form a white powder. Specimens should be kept moist to prevent decomposition.

results.name: Laurionite
results.description_short: Matlockite Group.

results.name: Laurite
results.description_short: Pyrite Group. Erlichmanite-Laurite Series. Compare 'UM1965-11-S:IrOsRu', 'UM1978-15-S:IrOsPtRhRu' and 'UM1978-18-S:IrOsRu'.

results.name: Lausenite
results.description_short: The only "natural" occurrences of this species are mine fires; therefore, by the current rules, it would not be eligible for consideration as a species in view of its anthropogenic origin (05.03.2020 edit: no longer a case due to new IMA proposal appro...

results.name: Lautenthalite
results.description_short:
Devilline Group.

The lead analogue of devilline and campigliaite.
Difficult to distinguish from both without analytical methods. 

Found at several slag localities, and in mine waste dumps

results.name: Lavendulan
results.description_short:
Lavendulan Group.

A polymorph of Lemanskiite, the Ca analogue of Zdenekite and the arsenate analogue of Sampleite.

Compare also the chemically and visually similar mahnertite.
May appear visually similar to slavkovite.

Data regarding this spe...

results.name: Lavrentievite
results.description_short: Forms a series with arzakite.

results.name: Lawrencite
results.description_short: Lawrencite Group.

results.name: Lawsonbauerite
results.description_short: The manganese analogue of Torreyite.

results.name: Lawsonite
results.description_short: The Al analogue of cortesognoite.

results.name: Lazulite
results.description_short:
The magnesium analogue of Scorzalite.

Not to be confused with the similarly named lazurite.

results.name: Lazurite
results.description_short: Lazurite is the blue component of the 'gemstone' (or, more usually, decorative rock) Lapis Lazuli, which is a lazurite-calcite-pyrite rock that has been mined as a gem material for some 9,000 years. Dana (System of Mineralogy, 1868) considered lapis-la...

results.name: Lead
results.description_short: Native lead is rare; lead is far more commonly found and mined as the lead sulphide mineral galena. The Romans named the refined metal 'plumbum' and used it for pipes in plumbing. Its major use today is in lead-acid batteries and for radiation shields....

results.name: Leadhillite
results.description_short: A rare monoclinic lead sulphate carbonate hydroxide, polymorphous with susannite (Trigonal) and macphersonite (Orthorhombic). Typically these minerals are all found as small to microscopic clear to white tabular pseudohexagonal crystals (trillings for ...

results.name: Lechatelierite
results.description_short:
A natural fused, X-ray amorphous silica. 

It can form when lightning strikes sand or other very silica-rich sediments and rocks, creating structures called fulgurites, hollow tubes that are often irregular and branched.

It also forms by the impac...

results.name: Legrandite
results.description_short:
A secondary mineral occurring in the oxidized zones of arsenic- and zinc-bearing deposits.

The structure of legrandite (and paradamite) is characterized by the occurrence of proton transfer tunnels along crystal axes. Stability of legrandite is due ...

results.name: Lehnerite
results.description_short: Meta-autunite Group.

results.name: Leifite
results.description_short:
Leifite Group. 
The sodium analogue of Telyushenkoite and Eirikite.

Note on the formula: the minor water content is located on a specific site ("B" site), not on the Na site ("A" site).

results.name: Leightonite
results.description_short: Closely related to polyhalite.

results.name: Lenaite
results.description_short:
Chalcopyrite Group.

Compare argentopyrite and, e.g., 'UM1987-10-S:AgFe'.

results.name: Leonite
results.description_short:
The magnesium analogue of Mereiterite.
May occur as a dehydration product of Picromerite.

results.name: Lepersonnite-(Gd)
results.description_short:
Used to be a unique species in terms of gadolinium dominance. Currently third such (named; unnamed species are not considered here) species after approval of monazite-(Gd) and xenotime-(Gd).

The Gd analogue of lepersonnite-(Nd).

Not approved phas...

results.name: Lepidocrocite
results.description_short:
Dimorphous with Goethite.

May be a component of limonite.

Note: The red inclusions in many quartz crystals, often labelled by sellers as "lepidocrocite", are in fact normally hematite. We are unaware of any analytically confirmed red translucent ...

results.name: Letovicite
results.description_short: This species was described and named based on an anthropogenic origin (burning coal mine dumps) but has since been identified in nature.

results.name: Leucophoenicite
results.description_short: Brown massive “hydrotephroite” was already known by Igelsten (1871) from the Harstigen mine, where it occurred with other Mn silicates and hausmannite ore. His description of the massive, brown hydrotephroite was very brief, thus indicating that this m...

results.name: Leucophosphite
results.description_short:
Leucophosphite Group.
The Fe#3+# analogue of tinsleyite.

Originally phosphate formed by the action of solutions derived from bird or bat guano upon serpentine (TL), or earlier iron-bearing minerals, also formed from the hydrothermal alteration of e...

results.name: Lévyclaudite

results.description_short: The Fe#2+#-analogue of zigrasite.

results.description_short: The V analogue of arsenmedaite.

results.name: Medenbachite
results.description_short: Copper analogue of neustädtelite and cobaltneustädtelite.

results.name: Meionite
results.description_short: Scapolite (Marialite-Meionite Series).

results.name: Meixnerite
results.description_short:
Easily confused with hydrotalcite and quintinite.
Reinvestigation would be desirable.

results.name: Melanocerite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
Probably a Ca-REE borosilicate within the apatite supergroup. 
"To be potentially discredited [= tritomite-(Ce)]" according to Pasero et al. (2010).

results.name: Melanophlogite
results.description_short: First recognized natural clathrasil (or silica clathrate); compare bosoite and chibaite - the other natural clathrasils.

results.name: Melanostibite
results.description_short:
Melanostibite is an homeotypic derivative of pyrophanite.

Chemically similar to manganoschafarzikite. Also compare manganostibite, filipstadite, tegengrenite, and garpenbergite.

results.name: Melanotekite
results.description_short:
Kentrolite-Melanotekite Series.

A synthetic aluminium analogue is known.

results.name: Melanterite
results.description_short:
Melanterite Group.
Iron analogue of boothite and zincmelanterite.

Melanterite is a hydrated iron sulphate formed after the decomposition of pyrite or other (metal-)iron sulphide minerals due to the action of surface waters. It is often found in min...

results.name: Melkovite
results.description_short: Compare UM1990-22-MoO:CaHP.

results.name: Mellite
results.description_short:
Aluminium mellitate (benzene hexacarboxylate) hydrate.

A rare secondary mineral in lignite deposits.

results.name: Melonite
results.description_short:
Melonite-Merenskyite Series. The Te2 analogue of ognitite.

May incorporate Bi, with the limit at <0.5 Bi apfu, as observed for natural (Kingash and Kuskanak complexes) and synthetic materials (Barkov et al., 2017).

results.name: Mélonjosephite
results.description_short: Structurally related to kapundaite.

results.name: Mendipite
results.description_short: Chemically similar to damaraite. Compare UM1990-25-O:ClPbS.

results.name: Mendozavilite-NaFe
results.description_short: Formerly called mendozavilite; redefined in 2010 (IMA 10-E).

results.name: Mendozite
results.description_short: Closely related to the members of the Alum Group.

results.name: Meneghinite
results.description_short:
Synthetic meneghinite may be Cu-free but is much less stable by comparison to Cu-bearing meneghinite.

May occur in intimate intergrowths with boulangerite.

results.name: Mercury
results.description_short: Mercury is officially classed as a mineral species for historical reasons, and also because it is distinctive in its chemical and physical properties. However, because it occurs as a liquid, it does not satisfy the normal criteria to be a valid mineral...

results.name: Mereheadite
results.description_short: Related to symesite.

results.name: Mereiterite
results.description_short:
The iron analogue of Leonite. 

May possibly appear as a dehydration product of the (unstable at room temperature) picromerite-type hexahydrate (a Tutton salt).

results.name: Merenskyite
results.description_short:
Melonite-Merenskyite Series.

One of many Pd-Te species, that also include, e.g., 'UM1976-33-Te:Pd', kotulskite, keithconnite, telluropalladinite and 'Unnamed (Pd Telluride)'; compare also 'UM1974-20-Te:BiPdSb'.

results.name: Merlinoite
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group. Compare UM1990-82-SiO:AlBaCaHKNaSr, UM1990-83-SiO:AlBaCaHKNaSr, UM1990-84-SiO:AlBaCaHKNaSr, and UM2010-05-SiO:AlCaHK.

May be confused with phillipsite-K.

Possibly an analog of UM1999-33-SiO:AlHKNa.

results.name: Merrihueite
results.description_short: Osumilite Group.

results.name: Mertieite

Isostructural with vadlazarenkovite and may be understood as its (SbAs)-analogue.

results.name: Mesolite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group. Natrolite Subgroup.

results.name: Messelite
results.description_short: Can easily be confused with anapaite.

results.name: Meta-alunogen
results.description_short: The lower hydrate counterpart of alunogen. Compare also Unnamed (Al Sulphate-Hydrate), 'UM1987-13-SO:AlH' and 'UM1976-22-SO:AlFeH'.

results.name: Meta-ankoleite
results.description_short: Meta-autunite Group. Chemically the P analogue of abernathyite (also the same point group).

results.name: Meta-autunite
results.description_short:
Meta-autunite Group.

results.name: Metasaléeite
results.description_short: A member of the Meta-autunite group. The lower hydrate of Saléeite.

results.name: Metauranocircite
results.description_short:
Meta-autunite Group. 
Rapid dehydration of uranocircite in dry atmospheres at normal temperature results in metauranocircite (metauranocircite-I of Walenta, 1963).
Metauranocircite may be more common than realized because of its similar appearance to...

results.name: Metauranopilite
results.description_short: Alteration product (lower hydrate) of uranopilite.

results.name: Metauranospinite
results.description_short:
Meta-autunite Group.
Dehydration product of uranospinite.

results.name: Metaborite
results.description_short: Dimorph of clinometaborite.

results.name: Metacinnabar
results.description_short: Forms a series with tiemannite (HgSe) and perhaps partially with sphalerite.

results.name: Metaheinrichite
results.description_short:
Meta-autunite Group.

results.name: Metahewettite
results.description_short: A tertiary mineral resulting from the dehydration of Hewettite as impregnations in sandstone.

results.name: Metakahlerite
results.description_short: Meta-autunite Group.

results.name: Metaköttigite
results.description_short: Formed by both oxidation and dehydrogenization of ferroan kottigite.

results.name: Metalodèvite
results.description_short: Meta-autunite Group.

results.name: Metamunirite
results.description_short: May form by dehydration of munirite.

results.name: Metanováčekite
results.description_short:
Meta-autunite Group.

Can be considered a strongly dehydrated "nováčekite" (= either nováčekite (nováčekite I) or hydronováčekite (nováčekite II)).
Reversibly dehydrates from "nováčekite" under ambient conditions.

results.name: Metarossite
results.description_short: A secondary mineral resulting from the dehydration of Rossite.

results.name: Metaschoderite
results.description_short: Dehydration product of schoderite.

results.name: Metaschoepite
results.description_short: May occur as a dehydration product of schoepite, and may itself dehydrate to paulscherrerite.

results.name: Metasideronatrite
results.description_short:

Reversibly rehydrates to sideronatrite depending on relative humidity and exposure to sunlight.

results.name: Metastibnite
results.description_short: Possibly also polymorphous with UM1996-35-S:Sb.

results.name: Metastudtite
results.description_short: Forms on dehydration of studtite.

results.name: Metaswitzerite
results.description_short:

Structurally related to castellaroite.

results.name: Metatorbernite
results.description_short:
Meta-autunite Group.

A secondary mineral resulting from the weathering/dehydration of Torbernite. Forms also directly above 75° C.
Crystals can be either cloudy and dull or translucent and glassy.

results.name: Metatyuyamunite
results.description_short: Visually indistinguishable from tyuyamunite or similar uranyl vanadates. May spontaneously dehydrate in dry atmosphere from tyuyamunite.

results.name: Metavanuralite
results.description_short: Apparently a dehydration product of vanuralite.

results.name: Metavariscite
results.description_short: Metavariscite Group. The monoclinic dimorph of Variscite.

results.name: Metavivianite
results.description_short:

results.name: Metavoltine
results.description_short:
Unique combination of elements. Belongs to a small group of ferrous-ferric sulfate minerals, that also contains bílinite, copiapite, römerite (purely Fe minerals), pertlikite and voltaite.

Structurally related to carlsonite and scordariite.

results.name: Metazeunerite
results.description_short:
Meta-autunite Group.

A rare secondary mineral in the oxidized zones of arsenic-bearing hydrothermal uranium deposits. Commonly originates due to dehydration of zeunerite.

results.name: Meyerhofferite
results.description_short:
Inderite Group.
Occurs principally as an alteration product of Inyoite.

* two BO2(OH)2 tetrahedra,

* distorte...

results.name: Meymacite
results.description_short: An amorphous hydrated tungsten oxide.

results.name: Mgriite
results.description_short: See also Chaméanite.

results.name: Miargyrite
results.description_short:

Black blocky, often striated crystals with dark red internal reflections to a cm. The crystals are difficult to orient and often form balls...

results.name: Michenerite
results.description_short: Chemically similar to unnamed species: 'UM1961-11-Te:BiPd', 'UM1970-27-Te:BiPd', 'UM1976-31-Te:BiPdSb'. See also kotulskite, Unnamed (Rh-Analogue of Michenerite), and UM1997-55-Te:BiPd.

results.name: Microcline
results.description_short:
Feldspar Group.
K-feldspar with fully ordered Al and Si distribution.

A fully ordered member of the K-feldspar structural series, which extends between disordered, monoclinic sanidine through partially ordered orthoclase to completely ordered, tric...

results.name: Microsommite
results.description_short: Cancrinite Group.

results.name: Miersite
results.description_short: Marshite-Miersite Series.

results.name: Mikasaite
results.description_short:

results.name: Milarite
results.description_short: May be confused with beryl and apatite.

results.description_short:

results.name: Millisite

results.name: Mimetite
results.description_short:
Apatite Group.
Apatite Supergroup.
Mimetite-Pyromorphite Series and Mimetite-Vanadinite Series.
The arsenate analogue of Pyromorphite and Vanadinite.
The Pb5 analogue of Hedyphane. 
The hexagonal polymorph of Mimetite-M and Mimetite-2M.
The Cl an...

results.name: Minehillite
results.description_short: Crystal structure related to that of gyrolite.

results.name: Minium
results.description_short:
A usually bright red lead oxide.
May be confused with litharge (red PbO) and powdery cinnabar.

results.name: Minnesotaite
results.description_short: Compare also ferripyrophyllite.

results.name: Minrecordite
results.description_short: Dolomite Group.

results.name: Mirabilite

results.description_short: Soluble in H2O; solution has a bitter and acid taste.

results.name: Miserite
results.description_short: Structure was determined on Kipawa specimen.

results.name: Mitridatite
results.description_short: The structure is presented by Moore & Araki (1977).

results.name: Mixite
results.description_short:
Mixite Group.

A rare secondary mineral in the oxidized zones of copper-bismuth deposits.

results.description_short: Compare also olsacherite.

results.name: Molybdofornacite
results.description_short:

Related to the Brackebuschite Group.

results.name: Molybdophyllite
results.description_short:
Molybdophyllite has an OD (order-disorder) structure. A trigonal and a monoclinic polytype have been derived by the OD approach. The crystal structure of the latter (C2) has been determined.

Closely related to britvinite.

results.name: Moctezumite
results.description_short: Structurally related to Schmitterite.

results.name: Mogánite
results.description_short:

results.description_short:
The S analogue of okruginite.

results.name: Mohrite
results.description_short: Picromerite Group, Boussingaultite-Mohrite Series.

results.name: Molybdenite
results.description_short:
Molybdenite is the most important ore of the metal molybdenum. Molybdenite is currently being researched as a possible replacement semiconductor for silicon in transistors in electronic chips.

Two polytypes are known: molybdenite-2H (very common) an...

results.name: Molybdite
results.description_short: Anhydrous counterpart of tianhuixinite, raydemarkite (monohydrate) and sidwillite (dihydrate).

results.name: Monazite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
The overwhelmingly most common member of the monazite group. Monazite-(Ce) is a widely distributed mineral, as an accessory in granitic igneous rocks and gneissic metamorphic rocks, and in detrital sands derived from them.

results.description_short: Monazite Group.

results.name: Monazite-(Nd)
results.description_short: Monazite Group

results.description_short:

An alteration product of Tetradymite.

results.description_short: Zeolite Group.

results.name: Montgomeryite
results.description_short:
The Mg analogue of kingsmountite and fanfaniite.

A secondary mineral in sedimentary phosphate nodules and as a late-stage mineral in highly oxidized phosphate nodules in granitic pegmatite.

results.name: Monticellite
results.description_short: Olivine Group. Kirschsteinite-Monticellite Series.

results.name: Montroseite
results.description_short: Diaspore Group.

results.name: Montroyalite
results.description_short: Probably related to the dresserite group.

results.description_short:
Hexahydrite Group.

May occur as dehydration product of bieberite.

results.name: Mopungite
results.description_short: Stottite Group.

results.name: Mordenite
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group. 

An unnamed K-dominant "mordenite" seems to exist in nature (e.g., Lo et al., 1991; Lo & Hsieh, 1991; Coombs et al., 1997; Sun et al., 2003). It is well-known as a synthetic compound.

results.name: Morelandite
results.description_short: Apatite Group. The barium analogue of Mimetite.

results.name: Moschelite
results.description_short: See also the other known natural mercury iodide, coccinite.

results.name: Moschellandsbergite
results.description_short: Intermetallic compound of silver and mercury.

results.name: Mosesite
results.description_short: The iodine analogue is likely known as CCUK-18.

results.name: Motukoreaite
results.description_short:
Partial dehydration readily occurs.

results.name: Mounanaite
results.description_short: The Fe3+ analogue of krettnichite.

results.description_short: Closely related to cryptophyllite and shlykovite.

results.name: Mountkeithite
results.description_short: Usually found as a white to pink coating in vughs in weathered serpentine.

results.description_short: See also the visually similar ilsemannite.

results.name: Munirite
results.description_short: May dehydrate to metamunirite.

results.name: Murdochite
results.description_short:

results.name: Murunskite
results.description_short: Bukovite group

results.name: Muscovite

results.name: Nacareniobsite-(Ce)

results.description_short: Not to be confused with natrotitanite.

results.name: Naujakasite
results.description_short: The Fe2+ analogue of Manganonaujakasite.

results.name: Naumannite
results.description_short:
Compare the chemically similar aguilarite.

Compare 'UM1988-21-Se:AgBiHg'.

results.name: Nealite
results.description_short: Bladed yellow brown to orange brown crystals.

results.name: Neighborite
results.description_short: Related to the K analogue, parascandolaite.

results.name: Nekrasovite
results.description_short: May grade into stibiocolusite.

results.name: Nelenite
results.description_short: Formerly known as ferroschallerite (note: "ferroschallerite" with Mn>Fe is Fe-bearing schallerite).

results.name: Neltnerite
results.description_short: Black pyramidal crystals, also complex elongated crystals.

results.name: Nenadkevichite
results.description_short: Labuntsovite Group, Nenadkevichite Subgroup.

results.name: Neotocite
results.description_short:
Hisingerite-Neotocite Series.
An amorphous to poorly crystalline, hydrated Mn silicate.
Mn is assumed to be divalent (Brusnitsyn and Egorov, 2023).

results.name: Nepheline
results.description_short: A very important change concerning nepheline is found in the recent (42nd) IMA Newsletter: potassium is essential in nepheline and the formula is changed to that recognized by Mindat. See https://www.mindat.org/mesg-437726.html for details, and CNMNC N...

results.name: Népouite
results.description_short: Lizardite-Népouite Series.

results.name: Neptunite
results.description_short:
The Fe(II) analogue of manganoneptunite.
Minor rock forming mineral. Probably best know as an associated mineral with benitoite.

results.name: Nesquehonite
results.description_short: May exist as a dehydration product of lansfordite. Compare UM1997-28-CO:CaHMg (a possible polytype).

results.name: Newberyite
results.description_short: A synthetic Mn analogue is known (Y. Cudennec, A. Riou, Y. Gerault, Acta Crystallogr. C45 (1989) 1411.).

results.name: Neyite
results.description_short: Ag analogue of cuproneyite.

results.name: Nickelhexahydrite
results.description_short: Hexahydrite Group.

results.name: Nickelaustinite
results.description_short:
The Ni-analogue of Austinite and Cobaltaustinite.

Chemically similar to nickeltalmessite and nickellotharmeyerite.

results.name: Nickelbischofite
results.description_short:
Compare droninoite, muonionalustaite; akaganeite and paratacamite-(Ni).

Deliquescent and soluble in water.

results.name: Niahite
results.description_short: Note: Artificially grown "niahite" is sold on the market. It is in fact ammonium dihydrogen phosphate (ADP), also called mono ammonium phosphate (MAP), formula NH4H2PO4. These fakes can be either colored bright green by doping with chromium or in any c...

results.name: Nickel
results.description_short:
See also awaruite, kamacite and taenite. Compare 'UM1981-07-E:FeIrNiOsRu'.

NB: Quite likely many of the listed localities for "native" nickel in reality just refer to nickel-bearing ores and not the native element. Caveat emptor!

results.name: Nickelskutterudite
results.description_short:
Skutterudite Group. Nickelskutterudite-Skutterudite Series. 
The nickel analogue of Ferroskutterudite and Skutterudite.

results.name: Nickelalumite
results.description_short:
Chalcoalumite Group. The Ni analogue of chalcoalumite.

Originally reported from Mbobo Mkulu Cave, Nelspruit District, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa.

results.name: Nickeline
results.description_short:
The most common member of the nickeline group. An important nickel ore mineral.

Compare, e.g, rammelsbergite, pararammelsbergite, and (now approved/redefined) dienerite.

results.name: Niggliite
results.description_short:
There was confusion in the early literature, starting with the original description suggesting the mineral was PtTe, which has similar XRD and optical properties.

NiAs-type crystal structure.

results.name: Ningyoite
results.description_short: A potential Fe-Th-REE analogue is known as 'UM1979-10-PO:FeHREETh'. Also comparable to 'UM1980-04-PO:CaHREETh'.

results.name: Niningerite
results.description_short: Galena Group.

results.name: Nioboaeschynite-(Ce)
results.description_short: The niobium analogue of aeschynite-(Ce).

results.name: Niobophyllite
results.description_short: Astrophyllite Group.

results.name: Nitratine
results.description_short:
Nitratine, sodium nitrate, is found as an efflorescence in hot dry regions. 

Chemically it is the Na-analogue of niter.

results.name: Niter
results.description_short:
Niter, potassium nitrate, is found as an efflorescence in hot, dry regions. Also known as saltpeter.

Chemically it is the K-analogue of nitratine.

results.name: Noelbensonite
results.description_short: Ba analogue of Hennomartinite

results.name: Nontronite
results.description_short: Smectite Group.

results.name: Norbergite
results.description_short: Norbergite is a mineral in the humite group. It forms a polysomatic series with chondrodite, humite and clinohumite and it is often found with one or more of these minerals. To reflect the common structure of these minerals, the formula of the humite-g...

results.name: Nordite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
The zinc analogue of ferronordite-(Ce) and manganonordite-(Ce). The cerium analogue of nordite-(La). Also the Sr analogue of illoqite-(Ce).

Related to meieranite.

results.name: Nordite-(La)
results.description_short: The zinc analogue of Ferronordite-(La). The lanthanum analogue of Nordite-(Ce).

results.name: Norrishite
results.description_short: Mica Group.

results.name: Norsethite
results.description_short: Compare also Unnamed (Ba-Mn Carbonate).

results.name: Northupite
results.description_short:
Northupite Group.

A complete series between northupite and tychite exists in artificial material.

May occur as fluid inclusions in chromite (Potapov et al., 2022).

results.name: Nosean
results.description_short:
Sodalite Group. The two sodalite cages in Nosean's unit cell contain Na^4SO^4 and Na^4H^2O.

May be confused with pale-coloured haüyne. Bright blue nosean is easily mistaken for lazurite.

Also classed as a feldspathoid.

results.name: Hydronováčekite
results.description_short:
Autunite Group.

Note: the use of the name nováčekite is inconsistent in the literature. There are two differently hydrated species (Walenta, 1964), one with 12 water molecules (nováčekite-I), the other with 10 water molecules (nováčekite = nováčekit...

results.name: Nowackiite
results.description_short: Chemically related to tennantite. Zn analogue of aktashite and zhengminghuaite; ZnAs-analogue of gruzdevite.

results.name: Nuffieldite
results.description_short: Compare argentonuffieldite.

results.name: Nukundamite
results.description_short:
Nukundamite is stable within a highly limited range of a(Fe2+)/a(H+) activity ratio, S2 and O2 fugacities, at temperatures between 501° and 224°C at very high sulfidation states (Seal et al., 2001; Esra Inan and Einaudi, 2002). 
It may be replaced by ...

results.name: Nullaginite
results.description_short: Probably Rosasite Group (crystallographic data need reinvestigation).

results.name: Nybøite
results.description_short: See also miyashiroite, an obsolete name for this species.

results.name: Nyerereite
results.description_short:
May be "a possible messenger from the deep Earth" (Zucchini et al., 2022).

May occur as fluid inclusions in chromite (Potapov et al., 2022).

results.name: Natrolite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group, Natrolite subgroup.

results.name: Nakauriite
results.description_short: The originally reported sulphate content appears to be questionable according to several literature sources; the crystal structure is unknown. Palenzona & Martinelli (2007) suggest a formula (Mg,Cu)x(CO3)y(OH)z•nH2O (x, y, z unknown).

results.name: O'Danielite
results.description_short:
Alluaudite Group. A synthetic Mg analogue is known: 'Unnamed (Na-Mg Arsenate Hydroxyarsenate)'.

Ðorðević et al. (2015) published data on the crystal structure of a few synthetic alluaudite-like protonated arsenates, that include the NaZn3(AsO4)(AsO3...

results.name: Obradovicite-KCu
results.description_short: Formerly called obradovicite; redefined in 2010 (IMA 10-E). Both obradovicite-NaCu and obradovicite-KCu was found on the type specimen of "obradovicite".

results.name: Odinite
results.description_short:
Kaolinite-Serpentine Group.

Note: odinite can also refer to a basaltic dyke rock with primarily anorthite (labradorite) and some augite in a groundmass of fine grained hornblende and minor quartz.

results.name: Offretite
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group.

A zeolite difficult to distinguish from erionite.

NOTE: The zeolite mineral species epitaxially overgrown on lévyne in all cases is identified as erionite (Passaglia et al., 1998).

results.name: Ogdensburgite
results.description_short: Found as somewhat earthy looking thin coatings usually on willemite-franklinite "black ore" at the type locality. Many ogdensburgite and yukonite specimens have been confused and are incorrectly labeled. At the type locality, ogdensburgite formed with ...

results.name: Ohmilite
results.description_short: The Ti- (or rather Ti-O)-analogue of yuzuxiangite.

results.name: Ojuelaite
results.description_short: Arthurite Group.

results.name: Okanoganite-(Y)
results.description_short: A rare-earth borofluorosilicate first described by Boggs (1980) from the peralkaline arfvedsonite granite from the Golden Horn batholith near Washington Pass, Okanogan County, U.S.A.  The crystal structure was established by Boiocchi (2004).

results.name: Okenite
results.description_short: WARNING: Many colourful specimens of Okenite, said to be from China or India, are currently available for sale. These are fake, the bright colours are artificial dyes added to the okenite.

results.name: Okhotskite
results.description_short:
Pumpellyite Group. 
Forms a solid solution series with pumpellyite-(Al).

results.name: Oldhamite
results.description_short:
Galena Group.

Known from several meteorites.

Terrestrial oldhamite is associated with pyrometamorpism (especially with coal fires). Quite unstable in air: hydrolysis makes it pass into portlandite.

Also occurs in anthropogenic blast furnace sl...

results.name: Olekminskite
results.description_short:
Olekminskite-Paralstonite Series.

Compare 'UM1989-07-CO:CaSr'.

results.name: Olenite
results.description_short:
A very Al-rich member of the Tourmaline Group.
Forms solid solutions with elbaite and schorl, also with alumino-oxy-rossmanite.

results.name: Olgite
results.description_short: ("Olgite" may perhaps in future become a series name, with Ba- and Sr- endmembers.) See also http://www.mindat.org/mesg-14-95789.html

results.name: Olivenite
results.description_short:
Olivenite Group. Adamite-Olivenite Series. Libethenite-Olivenite Series.
The copper analogue of Adamite.

May be confused with Zincolivenite which is a chemically and structurally distinct species with a defined ratio of Zn:Cu.
Note: The designatio...

results.name: Olkhonskite
results.description_short:
The chromium-dominant analogue of schreyerite.

Chemically related to 'UM1996-17-O:CrFeNbTiV'.

results.name: Olmsteadite
results.description_short: The Fe analogue of johnwalkite.

results.name: Olsacherite
results.description_short:
An alteration product of penroseite. 
Closely related to molybdomenite.

results.name: Omeiite
results.description_short: Anduoite-Omeiite Series.

results.name: Omphacite
results.description_short: A clinopyroxene intermediate between jadeite and augite, with solid solution towards aegirine-augite. There is a solvus between omphacite (P2/n) and jadeite (C2/c) and also between omphacite and augite/diopside (C2/c), below about 500C. Above this temp...

results.name: Opal
results.description_short: Although it is still (2007) regarded as a mineral species for historical reasons, opal is not a true mineral in the accepted sense of the word as it is variably composed of poorly crystalline material related to cristobalite and/or tridymite and/or com...

results.name: Oregonite
results.description_short: Oregonite has a high reflectivity, about 65%, in both air and oil.

results.name: Orlite
results.description_short: Possibly identical with kasolite. Needs restudy.

results.name: Orlymanite
results.description_short: Gyrolite Group.

results.name: Orpiment
results.description_short: May be visually similar to uzonite and wakabayashilite.

results.name: Orthobrannerite
results.description_short:
Orthobrannerite-Thorutite Series. Compare 'UM1982-19-SiO:TiU'.

"First found in the weathering residue of a biotite pyroxene syenite in Yunan, China. It was later also identified, from its heat-treatment product, in an alkalic lamprophyre in Szechuan...

results.name: Orthoclase
results.description_short:
Feldspar Group. K Feldspar subgroup. Celsian-Orthoclase Series.

An intermediate, partially ordered member of the K-feldspar structural series, between disordered, monoclinic sanidine and completely ordered microcline. Because of its intermediate nat...

results.name: Orthopinakiolite
results.description_short: The orthorhombic dimorph of Pinakiolite.

results.name: Orthoserpierite
results.description_short:
A species very hard to distinguish from devilline and bladed serpierite.
The crystal structure has not been determined yet.

results.name: Orthowalpurgite
results.description_short:
Dimorphous with walpurgite.
Probably formed by weathering of an earlier bismuth-bearing sulfide.

results.name: Osarizawaite
results.description_short:
Forms a solid solution series with its Fe(III) analogue beaverite-(Cu).

Note: Visual identification is impossible; many members of the alunite supergroup can have similar appearances.

results.name: Osarsite
results.description_short: Arsenopyrite Group.

results.name: Osbornite
results.description_short:
A very rare natural nitride, originally formed in star dust and now almost exclusively found in meteorites. The Ti analogue of both carslbergite and uakitite. The only approved Ti-N mineral to date.

Synthetic titanium nitride is a very important hig...

results.name: Osmium
results.description_short: The Os analogue of hexaferrum, hexamolybdenum, garutiite, and ruthenium.

results.name: Osumilite-(Mg)
results.description_short:
The Mg analogue of Osumilite.
Mg-dominant (at the octahedral site) analogues of osumilite have been described several times (Armbruster and Oberhänsli, 1988; Balassone et al., 2008; Seryotkin et al., 2008), but published without approval by the CNMNC....

results.name: Osumilite
results.description_short:
Osumilite Group.

Difficult to distinguish from Osumilite-(Mg).

Compare 'UM1984-35-SiO:AlCaFeKMg'. 


From Belakovskiy (2013), summarizing Chukanov et al. (2013):
"Chemical data for osumilite in original paper (Miyashiro 1956) show that it is ...

results.name: Otavite
results.description_short:
Calcite Group.

A secondary mineral found in oxidized zones of ore bodies.

results.name: Ottemannite
results.description_short: See also the similar suredaite. Compare stangersite.

results.name: Ottrélite
results.description_short: Mn analogue of chloritoid. Ottrélite was originally described as a Mn-rich, but not necessarily Mn-dominant chloritoid, consequently many "ottrélites" are in reality Mn-rich chloritoids, see Chloritoid best minerals article and references therein for f...

results.name: Otwayite
results.description_short: A mineral closely related to paraotwayite.

results.name: Oulankaite
results.description_short:
Unique combination of elements. The Cu analogue of UM2004-32-S:AgCuFePdPtSnTe.

Also compare 'argentian oulankaite'.

results.name: Overite
results.description_short:
Overite Group.

A secondary phosphate mineral found in altered phosphate nodules in sediments and in granitic pegmatites.

results.name: Owyheeite
results.description_short:
Belongs to a broad family of rod-based sulphosalt structures with the chess-board arrangement of the rods. Crystallizes as a 2-fold superstructure. Rod-polytype character induces systematic twinning.

Compare sterryite, parasterryite, meerschautite, ...

results.name: Oxammite
results.description_short: An organic mineral derived from guano; in sub-fossil bird eggs and on sub-fossil birds.

results.name: Oyelite
results.description_short: Related to tobermorite. Chemically related to shinichengite.

results.name: Naalasite
results.description_short: The Al analogue of nafeasite (even though they differ in not just the space groups but even the crystallographic system).

results.name: Örebroite
results.description_short: Mineral is close to franciscanite and welinite. Chemically resembles scorticoite and UM2003-37-SiO:HMnSbZn.

results.name: Pabstite
results.description_short: Benitoite Group. The tin analogue of Benitoite.

results.name: Padmaite
results.description_short: Compare UM1990-55-Se:BiCuPbPdS and 'Unnamed (Pd-Bi-Cu Selenide)'.

results.name: Pahasapaite
results.description_short: Zeolitic structure. A natural Be- and P-bearing zeolite and in these terms related to weinebeneite, wilancookite, and probably limousinite.

results.name: Palermoite
results.description_short:
Bertossaite-Palermoite Series. The strontium analogue of bertossaite. The lithium analog of natropalermoite.

Structurally related to carminite and pilawite-(Y).

results.name: Palladium
results.description_short:
Platinum Group. Gold-Palladium Series, Palladium-Silver Series and Palladium-Platinum Series.

Natural Palladium always contains some Platinum.

(Pd,Cu) alloys, some with the approximate composition PdCu4, are reported by Kapsiotis et al. (2010).

results.name: Palladoarsenide
results.description_short:
Compare 'UM1974-01-As:PdSb', most likely an antimonian variety.

Also compare UM1975-07-As:PdSn, UM1976-01-As:BiPd, UM1976-03-As:NiPd, UM1974-01-As:PdSb, and very similar palladobismutharsenide.

results.name: Palladobismutharsenide
results.description_short: Compare very similar palladoarsenide and UM1976-01-As:BiPd; also similar: UM1975-07-As:PdSn, UM1974-01-As:PdSb, and UM1976-03-As:NiPd.

results.name: Palladseite
results.description_short: Chemically related to verbeekite and UM1995-39-Se:Pd.

results.name: Palmierite
results.description_short:
The lead analogue of Kalistrontite. Compare eleomelanite.

In experimental volcanic gas condensation by Africano et al. (2002) it deposited in the range of ca. 600-400oC.

Commonly found as an alteration product in man made pigments and smelting re...

results.name: Palygorskite
results.description_short:
May be confused with sepiolite. 

Results of García-Romero & Suárez (2010) indicate that no compositional gap exists between sepiolite and palygorskite.

results.name: Panasqueiraite
results.description_short:
Tilasite Group, OH-analogue of isokite.

Extremely rare; most of samples are in fact triplite or other visually similar phosphates (Mila et al., 2014).

results.name: Panunzite
results.description_short: See also the closely related kalsilite and kaliophilite.

results.name: Para-alumohydrocalcite
results.description_short:
Related to alumohydrocalcite.

The crystal structure and the correct stoichiometry are unknown. Kolitsch (2018) measured a Ca:Al ratio of about 1:1.2, unlike the ratio in the originally proposed formula (1:2).

results.name: Parabrandtite
results.description_short:
Fairfieldite Group.
The Mn analogue of Unnamed (Fe2+-analogue of Parabrandtite).

Only 3 co-type specimens exist. The material was discovered by Fred Parker, American collector of Franklin Minerals, and a local mineral dealer in Maryland, in a singl...

results.name: Paracelsian
results.description_short:
Feldspar Group. The pseudo-orthorhombic (the monoclinic angle is 90.01°) dimorph of Celsian.

Paracelsian appears to be a metastable phase; it changes monotropically through hexacelsian to celsian at temperatures at least as low as 500°C and possibly...

results.name: Paracoquimbite
results.description_short: Note: Al is not essential in paracoquimbite (but is essential in coquimbite), as derived from the IMA redefinition.

results.name: Paracostibite
results.description_short:
Appears to be the high-temperature polymorph of CoSbS (Cabri et al., 1970).

Compare willyamite.

results.name: Paradamite
results.description_short: Tarbuttite Group. The triclinic dimorph of Adamite.

results.name: Paradocrasite
results.description_short: A very rare, natural Sb-rich alloy.

results.name: Paragonite
results.description_short:
Mica Group.

An uncommon Na-member of the mica group.
Occurs in low- to medium-grade metamorphic schists and phyllites, in muscovite-biotite gneisses, quartz veins, fine-grained sediments, and glaucophane-bearing rocks.

2M^1; 3A polytypes.

results.name: Paraguanajuatite
results.description_short: Compare guanajuatite and 'UM1987-16-Se:BiPbTe'.

results.name: Parahopeite
results.description_short: The P analogue of davidlloydite. Also the Zn3-analogue of reaphookhillite.

results.name: Paralaurionite
results.description_short: Matlockite Group.

results.name: Paralstonite
results.description_short:
Olekminskite-Paralstonite Series.

Morphologically and physically indistinguishable from alstonite.  Optics, PXRD, or single crystal XRD are needed to distinguish the two species. Alstonite is biaxial negative with 2V=7deg, while paralstonite is unia...

results.name: Paranatrolite
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group. Natrolite Subgroup.

Paranatrolite is another natrolite analog with a high water content (Chao 1980; Ross et al. 1992). 
Paranatrolite is reported to transform to tetranatrolite upon exposure to the atmosphere after removal from its a...

results.name: Paraotwayite
results.description_short: A mineral closely related to otwayite.

results.name: Parapierrotite
results.description_short: Prismatic crystals, also laths and grains.

results.name: Pararammelsbergite
results.description_short:
The low-temperature polymorph of NiAs2.

The crystal structure is transitional between the marcasite and pyrite structures (Fleet, 1972).

Compare, e.g, the (now approved / redefined) dienerite.

Peacock (1940) gives a summary of the early histor...

results.name: Pararealgar
results.description_short:
Red realgar alters to yellow/yellow-orange pararealgar on exposure to light.
Primary pararealgar is, however, also known.

results.name: Pararobertsite
results.description_short: Much less common than its dimorph robertsite.

results.name: Paraschoepite
results.description_short:
Finch et al. (1997) state "Powder data labeled "paraschoepite" in the Powder Diffraction File do not correspond to the mineral of that name."

Christ and Clark (1960) report a large interplanar distance (c = 15.22 Å) for single crystals of paraschoep...

results.name: Parasymplesite
results.description_short:
Vivianite Group. Forms a series with vivianite (vivianite-parasymplesite series).
The Fe2+ analogue of köttigite and erythrite.
May be intergrown with its dimorph symplesite.

Compare also ferrisymplesite.

results.name: Paratacamite
results.description_short:
Atacamite Group.
A secondary copper mineral. Easily confused with the closely related Clinoatacamite.

Derivatives are paratacamite-(Mg) and paratacamite-(Ni).

Also closely related to Herbertsmithite and Gillardite (both have halved a-axes by com...

results.name: Paravauxite
results.description_short:
The triclinic dimorph of Metavauxite.

A rare mineral in hydrothermal tin veins and in complex granitic pegmatites.

results.name: Pargasite
results.description_short: Pargasite is one of the earliest amphiboles that were described that are still a valid mineral. It was rudimentary described by von Steinheil in 1814 and more thoroughly by Nordenskiöld (1821). Nordenskiold included both chemistry, optical and physical...

results.name: Parisite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
Crystals pseudohexagonal, oscillatory and sceptered due to intergrowths parallel to the pseudo-{0001) with Bastnäsite-(Ce), Synchysite-(Ce), Röntgenite-(Ce) and Cordylite.
Polytypes 2M (very common), 3R and 6R are known or proposed.

The Ce-analogue...

results.name: Parkerite
results.description_short:
See also "lead-parkerite" and the chemically related bismutohauchecornite.
An Sb-bearing parkerite has been reported, too (Goryachev et al., 2004).

results.name: Parkinsonite
results.description_short: The Mo-dominant analogue of janchevite.

results.name: Parnauite
results.description_short:
An uncommon secondary Cu-sulphate-arsenate. Fibrous varieties and crusts may be confused with strashimirite. 

Can be distinguished from visually similar tyrolite and tangdanite by optical methods.

results.name: Parsettensite
results.description_short:
May be visually similar to ganophyllite and bementite.
Compare also the chemically similar coombsite.

results.name: Parsonsite
results.description_short:
Hallimondite-Parsonsite Series.
The phosphate analogue of Hallimondite.

results.name: Pascoite
results.description_short:
See also the closely related magnesiopascoite and recently approved hydropascoite, the latter being the higher hydrated equivalent.

A secondary mineral occurring as a leachate of near-surface vanadium oxides by ground waters and as efflorescences in...

results.name: Patrónite
results.description_short: Chemically similar to eliopoulosite.

results.name: Paulkerrite
results.description_short: Compare Mantienneite, also Benyacarite.

results.name: Pavonite
results.description_short:
Typically forms fine lamellar intergrowths with cupropavonite.
Compare also cupromakopavonite.

Difficult to distinguish from benjaminite; single-crystal XRD methods are necessary (Harris & Chen, 1975).


See also Unnamed (Se-analogue of Pavonite...

results.name: Pearceite
results.description_short:
Pearceite-Polybasite series.

Originally pearceite was thought to be an arsenic analogue of polybasite. 
"Arsenpolybasite" was, however, found to represent two different polytypes of pearceite, pearceite-T2ac and pearceite-M2a2b2c.

Pearceite form...

results.name: Pecoraite
results.description_short: Kaolinite-Serpentine Group

results.name: Pectolite
results.description_short:
Wollastonite Group. 
Pectolite-Serandite Series. The calcium analogue of Sérandite.
Constitutes serandite-schizolite-pectolite series.

results.name: Ferrotaaffeite-6N'3S
results.description_short: Taaffeite Group.

results.name: Pekoite
results.description_short: Aikinite-Bismuthinite Series.

results.name: Penfieldite
results.description_short: Soluble in water, leaving a yellowish white lead oxychloride residue.

results.name: Penikisite
results.description_short:
Kulanite-Penikisite Series.

results.name: Peprossiite-(Ce)

results.name: Rammelsbergite
results.description_short:
The high-temperature polymorph of NiAs2; pararammelsbergite is the low-temperature polymorph (Fleet, 1972).

Compare, e.g, nickeline and the (now approved / redefined) dienerite.

results.name: Ramsbeckite
results.description_short: See also Unnamed Cu-Zn Sulphate (of Schmutz et al.).

results.name: Ramsdellite
results.description_short:
Forms by inversion of pyrolusite or oxidative dehydrogenation of groutite.

The "groutellite" variety is sometimes (e.g., Bernardini et al., 2020) given as [(Mn4+0.5,Mn3+0.5)O1.5(OH)0.5].

Well-recognizable via vibrational (Raman) spectroscopy.

...

results.name: Ranciéite
results.description_short:
Ranciéite-Takanelite Series. 
The calcium analogue of takanelite.

May be confused with todorokite, but X-ray diffraction data are distinctive.

Compare lagalyite and 'UM1979-06-O:CaHMn'.

results.name: Rapidcreekite
results.description_short: Easily confused with aragonite, gypsum and several Ca-(Mg-)arsenates such as pharmacolite etc.

results.name: Raspite
results.description_short:
The monoclinic dimorph of stolzite. Heating of raspite to 395(5)°C leads to a transformation into stolzite.

A rare secondary mineral occurring in the oxidized zones of tungsten-bearing hydrothermal base metal deposits.

An unusual Te-rich variety ...

results.name: Rasvumite
results.description_short:
Partially alters to orange-brown FexSy in open air, within days or hours.

Compare bartonite, gmalimite, djerfisherite, 'Unnamed (K sulfides solid solution)', and UM1997-44-S:FeK.

results.name: Rathite
results.description_short: Berlepsch et al. (2002) note that Ag substitution is probably essential in the structure and makes the mineral different from dufrénoysite.

results.name: Rauenthalite
results.description_short: Often associated with the chemically nearly identical phaunouxite, but phaunouxite easily dehydrates to rauenthalite.

results.name: Rauvite
results.description_short: A rare and questionable mineral species occurring in the oxidized zones of U-V ores in Colorado Plateau-type deposits.

results.name: Ravatite
results.description_short:

Known in organic chemistry as phenanthrene (a well-known polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH), also known as tricyclo[8.4.0.02,7]tetradeca-1,3,5,7,9,11,13-heptaene).

results.name: Rayite
results.description_short: Compare UM1990-32-S:AgPbSb.

results.name: Realgar
results.description_short:

results.name: Rebulite
results.description_short:

Chemically, the As-dominant analogue of jankovićite (triclinic). Also compare drechslerite, gillulyite, pierrotite and gungerite.

results.name: Rectorite
results.description_short: A 1:1 regular interstratification of muscovite/illite (dioctahedral mica) and montmorillonite (dioctahedral smectite). Frequently called "rectorite-K" to distinguish it from regularly interstratified paragonite/montmorillonite = "rectorite-Na".

results.name: Reddingite
results.description_short:
Phosphoferrite Group, Phosphoferrite-Reddingite Series.

Note: Some "reddingites" may in fact be correianevesite.

results.name: Redingtonite
results.description_short: Halotrichite Group

results.name: Redledgeite
results.description_short: Ba analogue of UM1994-09-O:CrKTi. Cr analogue of mannardite.

results.name: Reederite-(Y)
results.description_short: Presently, the only known mineral with a fluorosulphate (FSO3)- anion.

results.name: Reedmergnerite
results.description_short:

results.name: Reevesite
results.description_short: Hydrotalcite Group. The Ni analogue of UM2002-02-COH:FeNi. The Fe3+ analogue of UM1998-10-CO:CoHNi.

results.name: Reichenbachite
results.description_short: May be intergrown with pseudomalachite.

results.name: Reinerite
results.description_short: A synthetic polymorph has been reported by Harrison (2010).

results.name: Reinhardbraunsite
results.description_short: Reinhardbraunsite is a mineral in the humite Group. It is the (OH)-dominant member in a series with Kumtyubeite. The Reinhardbraunite-Kumtyubeite series form the Ca-dominant equivalent of the chondrodite-hydroxylchondrodite series. A mineral with a rei...

results.name: Renierite
results.description_short:
Charge balance maintained by coupled substitution Zn+Ge = Cu+As.

Compare the Zn- and As-free member germanite.

results.name: Reppiaite
results.description_short: Related to arsenoclasite.

results.name: Retzian-(Ce)
results.description_short: The Ce analogue of Retzian-(La) and Retzian-(Nd).

results.name: Retzian-(La)
results.description_short: La analogue of Retzian-(Ce) and Retzian-(Nd).

results.name: Retzian-(Nd)
results.description_short: Nd analogue of Retzian-(Ce) and Retzian-(La).

results.name: Reyerite
results.description_short: Crystal structure related to that of gyrolite.

results.name: Rhabdophane-(Ce)
results.description_short:
Rhabdophane Group.

results.description_short: Rhabdophane Group.

results.name: Rhabdophane-(Nd)
results.description_short: Rhabdophane Group.

results.description_short:
Rhönite Group.

A Ti3+-bearing member, one of three currently known phases with essential trivalent titanium by tistarite and grossmanite, is known from Allende meteorite ('UM1971-21-SiO:AlCaMgTi').

results.name: Rhodesite
results.description_short: Related to fivegite.

results.description_short:
The potassium analogue of Londonite. Londonite-Rhodizite Series.

First described by Rose in 1834 without quantitative chemical data. A chemical analysis was made by Damour (1882) but later showed to be incomplete, lacking both Li and Be. The alkali ...

results.description_short:
Calcite Group.
Calcite-Rhodochrosite Series and Rhodochrosite-Siderite Series.

Commonly occurs as a primary gangue mineral in moderate- to low-temperature hydrothermal veins, also in high-temperature metasomatic deposits and sedimentary manganese d...

results.name: Rhodonite
results.description_short: Pyroxmangite of MnSiO3 composition is the high-pressure, low-temperature polymorph with respect to rhodonite of the same composition (Maresch & Mottana, 1976). There is also an unnamed α phase - UM1975-18-SiO:Mn - recognized in limestones from the Poli...

results.name: Rhomboclase
results.description_short: A common acidic alteration product of iron sulphides (pyrite, marcasite, pyrrhotite), frequently found as crusts and powders associated with other iron sulphates such as römerite, halotrichite etc.

results.name: Richellite
results.description_short: Occurs as a secondary (?) mineral in phosphatic sedimentary rocks.

results.name: Richetite
results.description_short: Richetite is one of three minerals with pentavalent uranium, the other two being wyartite and shinkolobweite (Plášil, 2017).

results.name: Richterite
results.description_short: Compare the chemically similar winchite and potassic-richterite.

results.description_short:

15-20% of the grains bear intergrowths with hexagonal polymorph, UM1995-23-PO:BaHMgSr.

results.name: Ringwoodite
results.description_short:
Mg analogue of ahrensite.  There is at least a partial series with ahrensite (Bindi et al., 2020).

The isometric polymorph of Wadsleyite and Forsterite. May result from prograde transformation of the latter minerals.

Experiments show that ringwoo...

results.name: Rinkite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
See also Mosandrite-(Ce).
The crystal structure  of  rinkite  was  established  by  Galli and Alberti (1971). Some authors (Fleischer 1958, 1987; Sokolova & Cámara, 2008, etc.) have argued that rinkite is identical with mosandrite. However, reinvestig...

results.name: Rittmannite
results.description_short: Whiteite Group.

results.name: Riversideite
results.description_short:
A natural occurrence of riversideite is not demonstrated unequivocally and its status should be considered as “questionable” (Biagioni et al., 2015). 

The exact structure of riversideite is not known, but a reliable model can be derived from the str...

results.name: Römerite
results.description_short:
Forms from the oxidation of iron sulphides (pyrite, marcasite, pyrrhotite) and often found with other iron sulphates such as rhomboclase.

Other ferrous-ferric sulfate minerals include bílinite and copiapite (purely Fe minerals); metavoltine, voltait...

results.name: Röntgenite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
Needs reinvestigation by modern methods. 

Cf. parisite-(Ce), synchysite-(Ce).

results.name: Robertsite
results.description_short:
Brown to dark brown coatings, usually fine-grained, but sometimes crystallized with densely packed pseudohexagonal platy, columnar, or fibrous crystals.

Much more common than its dimorph pararobertsite.

results.description_short: The structure as in case of, e.g., boulangerite, jamesonite, and zinkenite, comprises interconnected SbS3 groups.

results.name: Rockbridgeite
results.description_short:
Rockbridgeite Group. Frondelite-Rockbridgeite Series. 
The Fe2+-analogue of frondelite and plimerite.

A secondary mineral resulting from the alteration of primary phosphates.

Visually similar to dufrénite and natrodufrénite.

Compare chemicall...

results.name: Roedderite
results.description_short:
Osumilite Group. Eifelite-Roedderite Series.

Compare also almarudite, friedrichbeckeite, and UM1989-34-SiO:FeKMgMnNa.

results.name: Roggianite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group.

results.name: Rokühnite
results.description_short: The hydrated counterpart of lawrencite. Other approved ferrous-iron-bearing chlorides include droninoite and hibbingite. Compare the hydrated ferric-iron chloride minerals: 'hydromolysite', 'Unnamed (Fe Chloride Hydrate I)', and 'Unnamed (Fe Chloride H...

results.name: Romanèchite
results.description_short:
Chemically similar to hollandite.

results.name: Roquesite
results.description_short: Chalcopyrite Group.

results.description_short:

results.name: Rosasite
results.description_short:
Rosasite Group.  

Rosasite is a secondary mineral found in the oxidation zone of copper-zinc deposits.

results.description_short:
Roscherite Group.

Occurs in cavities in granite or in complex zoned granitic pegmatites. Many roscherite localities are actually greifensteinite localities.

results.name: Roscoelite
results.description_short:
Mica Group.
The V(III) analogue of muscovite.

results.name: Roselite
results.description_short:

The monoclinc dimorph of anorthoroselite (triclinic). The cobalt analogue of wendwilsonite.

results.description_short: Fairfieldite Group. Talmessite - Anorthoroselite Series. The triclinic dimorph of Roselite.

results.name: Rosemaryite
results.description_short: Wyllieite Group. Rosemaryite-Wyllieite Series. The manganese analogue of Ferrorosemaryite.
