results.description_short:
The Al analogue of topsøeite. A hydrated counterpart of oskarssonite. Probably identical to UM2008-27-F:AlHO.

Found as aggregates of minute colorless crystals.

Compare 'UM1988-02-F:AlHO' (a lower-hydrate counterpart) and 'Unnamed (Basic Aluminium...

results.name: Rosenbuschite
results.description_short: Light brown, tan, or gray brown rod-like to fibrous crystals embedded in matrix. Acicular crystals in vugs.

results.name: Rosickýite
results.description_short:
Sulphur Group.
The densest form of solid S. Can be prepared by slowly cooling molten sulfur that has been heated above 150°C.
Dimorphous with both sulphur (α-sulphur), to which it changes in time at room temperature, and β-sulphur.

results.description_short: An amorphous hydrous phosphate of Al with Pb and Cu. An anthropogenic substance, forming on old mine tunnel walls.

results.description_short:

Note that "rostite" from the type locality contains considerable F (4.25 wt.%) (Zacek & Povondra, 1988) and subsequently was identified as khademite (Zacek et al., 1995).

results.name: Routhierite
results.description_short:
The mercury analogue of stalderite.

results.name: Rouvilleite
results.description_short: Unique combination of elements (as of January 2022).

results.name: Roweite
results.description_short:

Only one specimen known is known from the type locality (all additional specimens are "crumbs" from the original single specimen).

results.name: Rowlandite-(Y)
results.description_short:
Commonly metamict.

See also the Mg analogue magnesiorowlandite-(Y) described in 2014.

results.name: Roxbyite
results.description_short: A low-temperature alteration product of djurleite.

results.name: Rozenite
results.description_short: A common alteration product of iron sulphides (pyrite, marcasite, pyrrhotite).

results.name: Rösslerite
results.description_short: Dehydrates in air to brassite.

results.description_short: Arsenopyrite Group. A possible Te analogue is known as 'UM1981-01-AsTe:Ru'.

results.description_short: The monoclinic dimorph of Pringleite.

results.name: Russellite
results.description_short:
An alteration product of primary bismuth minerals and wolframite.

The tungstate analogue of koechlinite and the Bi analogue of tungstibite.

results.name: Rustumite
results.description_short: Compare 'UM1977-03-COSiO:CaClH'.

results.description_short: Note that the name ends with -ite, altough the mineral is an arsenide.

results.description_short: The Ru analogue of osmium, hexaferrum, hexamolybdenum, and garutiite.

results.description_short:

The ferric Fe analogue of godovikovite. Chemically related to pyracmonite and ferroefremovite. Slightly hydroscopic.

results.description_short:
Autunite Group.

results.description_short: Cancrinite Group. Chemically somewhat similar to steudelite and delhayelite.

results.name: Sainfeldite
results.description_short:
Compare giftgrubeite, the ordered (Ca:Mn = 3:2) intermediate member between villyaellenite and sainfeldite.

Compare also the higher hydrates ferrarisite and its dimorph guérinite.

results.description_short:
Structurally related to harkerite with which it forms a solid solution (Sakhaite-Harkerite solid solution). Also chemically and structurally (at least in terms of the crystal system) related to UM1990-59-SiO:AlBCHMg.

results.description_short: CsCl structure type.

results.description_short: A synthetic Fe-analogue is known.

results.description_short: V analogue of braccoite.

results.name: Sanidine
results.description_short:
Feldspar Group.

The high-temperature, fully disordered (in its Al and Si distribution), form of K-feldspar; other potassium-dominant feldspars are microcline (fully ordered) and orthoclase (partly ordered).  It is metastable at room temperature, and...

results.name: Sanjuanite
results.description_short:
Sanjuanite-Destinezite Group.

Chemically related to kribergite, arangasite and mitryaevaite.

results.name: Sanmartinite

results.description_short: Needs restudy.

results.name: Sartorite
results.description_short: NOTE: the "sartorite" structurally characterised by Berlepsch et al. (2003) corresponds to enneasartorite. All "sartorite" occurrences published in the literature and based on (often) insufficient evidence should probably be reinvestigated to find out ...

results.name: Sasaite
results.description_short: Water content varies with humidity.

results.name: Satimolite
results.description_short:

results.name: Sauconite
results.description_short:
Smectite Group.

results.name: Sazhinite-(Ce)
results.description_short:

results.name: Scacchite

results.name: Schafarzikite

results.name: Schairerite
results.description_short:

results.name: Schallerite
results.description_short:
Frequently waxy brown masses, small tapered hexagonal crystals rare.
May be confused with friedelite or pyrosmalite-(Mn).

The possible As3+-equivalent is coded as 'UM1986-05-AsO:HMn'.

results.name: Schapbachite
results.description_short: Note: many specimens originally described as "schapbachite (of Kenngott)" are in fact matildite with or without admixture of galena. Modern verification of any specimen with this designation is required.

results.name: Schaurteite
results.description_short: Fleischerite Group.

results.name: Scheelite
results.description_short:
Powellite-Scheelite Series.

A primary mineral commonly found as a component of contact-metamorphic tactite; in high-temperature hydrothermal veins and greisen; in granitic pegmatites and medium-temperature hydrothermal veins; in alluvial deposits.

results.name: Schertelite
results.description_short: A phosphate mineral found in bat guano deposits.

results.name: Schieffelinite
results.description_short: A chromate-analogue of schieffelinite is mentioned in Marty et al. (2010), and was later approved as chromschieffelinite. Chemically somewhat reminds adanite, northstarite, and eztlite.

results.name: Schmiederite

results.name: Schmitterite
results.description_short: Structurally related to Moctezumite.

results.name: Schoepite

results.name: Scholzite

Chemically related to skorpionite.

results.name: Schoonerite
results.description_short: Related to flurlite.

results.name: Schorl
results.description_short:

results.name: Schorlomite
results.description_short:
Garnet Group. Compare UM1982-16-SiO:AlCaFeTi and Morimotoite.

results.name: Thermessaite-(NH4)
results.description_short:
The ammonium analogue of thermessaite.

results.name: Schreyerite
results.description_short: The V analogue of machiite. Chemically, but not structurally, the V analogue of pseudorutile.

results.name: Schröckingerite
results.description_short: The sodium analogue of UM1997-27-CO:CaHKSU.

results.name: Schubnelite
results.description_short: Structurally related to mikehowardite: both bear edge-sharing dimers of Fe3+O6 octahedra, linked by distorted VO4 tetrahedra.

results.name: Schuetteite
results.description_short:
Appears to form in two different ways, by action of sunlight and very small amounts of water on cinnabar and the reaction of sulfuric acid on native mercury (retorts, chimneys).

Compare 'Unnamed (Mercury Sulfate Sulfoxide)'.

results.name: Schulenbergite
results.description_short: Very close to hodgesmithite (also trigonal and possibly sharing the space group), in which one of the seven metal sites is Zn-dominant. Chemically and structurally related to minohlite. See also 'UM1992-30-SO:CCuHZn' (the Zn analogue of schulenbergite)...

results.name: Schultenite
results.description_short: See also Unnamed (P-analogue of Schultenite).

results.name: Schumacherite
results.description_short: Preisingerite Group. Petitjeanite-Schumacherite Series, and the Preisingerite-Schumacherite Series.

results.name: Schwartzembergite
results.description_short:
A secondary lead mineral found in oxidized zones of lead-bearing deposits in arid regions.
Schwartzembergite is a highly unusual mineral since it contains trivalent iodine.

results.name: Sclarite
results.description_short:
A very rare Zn carbonate.

At the type locality, sclarite occurs in small (<1mm) colorless crystals in cloudy grayish white crystal clusters. At low magnification, the sclarite appears smoothly spherical, but the crystals in the clusters distinctly p...

results.name: Scolecite
results.description_short: Zeolite Group. Natrolite Subgroup.

results.name: Scorodite
results.description_short:
Variscite Group; Mansfieldite-Scorodite Series. 
The orthorhombic dimorph of Parascorodite. The ferric iron analogue of Mansfieldite and Yanomamite.

A relatively common secondary mineral resulting from the oxidation of arsenopyrite or other arsenic...

results.name: Scorzalite
results.description_short: Lazulite Group. Lazulite-Scorzalite Series. The Fe2+ analogue of Lazulite.

results.name: Scotlandite
results.description_short: A very rare lead sulphite.

results.name: Scrutinyite
results.description_short:
A secondary lead oxide difficult to distinguish from plattnerite.
An oxidation product in lead piping and oil paintings.

results.name: Seamanite
results.description_short: related to Moydite-(Y) and Cahnite

results.name: Searlesite
results.description_short: The structure of Searlesite contains sheets, consisting of kinked pyroxene-like polysilicate chains that are linked by (H2BO4) tetrahedra, classifying it as a phyllo-borosilicate. The silicate chains contain two crystallographically distinct Si sites, ...

results.name: Sederholmite
results.description_short: Metallic brass yellow grains.

results.name: Sedovite
results.description_short: The mineral shows disorder of molybdenum atoms. A microporous structure.

results.name: Seelite
results.description_short: Chemically, seelite is a Mg-dominant, arsenate-bearing analogue of dymkovite.

results.name: Segnitite
results.description_short:
The arsenate analogue of kintoreite. 
Difficult to distinguish from beudantite, with which it forms a series.

Related to kolitschite.

results.name: Seidozerite
results.description_short:
Closely related to grenmarite. Visually somewhat similar to Lavenite group minerals.

Also related to the Lamprophyllite Group.

results.name: Sekaninaite
results.description_short: The Fe analogue of Cordierite. Cordierite-Sekaninaite Series.

results.name: Seligmannite
results.description_short:
Bournonite Group. Bournonite-Seligmannite Series.

The structure contains isolated and interconnected AsS3 pyramids, as, e.g., in case of baumhauerite, dufrénoysite, gratonite, and sartorite.

results.name: Semenovite-(Ce)
results.description_short: Chemically somewhat similar to letnikovite-(Ce).

results.name: Semseyite
results.description_short: Semseyite belongs to a homologous series of lead antimony sulphides. The structure contains sheets of galena, the thickness of this sheet determines the position in the homologous series. Semseyite has the thickest sheet and fülöppite the thinnest.

results.name: Senaite
results.description_short:
Crichtonite Group.
Forms a series with gramaccioliite-(Y). 

Often confused with crichtonite.

results.name: Sengierite
results.description_short:
Carnotite Group.

An uncommon secondary mineral deposited from solutions derived from altering uraninite.

Visually very similar to volborthite.

results.name: Sepiolite
results.description_short:
Commonly found as compact masses of microscopic needles resulting in a low-density masses. May be an important constituent of "mountain leather". Free-standing acicular crystals not found in many localities.

May be confused with palygorskite. Result...

results.name: Serandite
results.description_short:
Pectolite-Serandite Series. The manganese analogue of pectolite and the sodium analogue of tanohataite. Part of serandite-schizolite-pectolite series.

Many of the lighter pink "serandites" are schizolite. They can't be sorted visually. None of the d...

results.name: Serendibite
results.description_short:
Aenigmatite Group.

May be confused with sapphirine.

results.name: Serpierite
results.description_short:
Ca-analogue of aldridgeite.

Platy varieties are visually indistinguishable from orthoserpierite.

Warning: Slightly to moderately soluble in water. Avoid ultrasonic cleaning.

Note that the Serpieri mine/shaft is NOT the type locality of serpier...

results.name: Shafranovskite
results.description_short: Visually resembles zakharovite, UM1990-85-SiO:AlCaFeHMnNa, UM1990-89-SiO:CaFFeHKNa, UM1990-93-SiO:FeHNa, and UM1990-94-SiO:FFeHNaTi.

results.name: Shandite
results.description_short: See also 'Lead-parkerite'.

results.name: Shannonite
results.description_short:
A lead oxycarbonate that can form naturally under highly oxidising conditions, but also from heating cerussite (e.g., during fire-setting methods used in ore extraction underground; during mine fires).

Chemically related to grootfonteinite and UM199...

results.name: Sharpite
results.description_short: Sharpite represents a unique sheet-based structure derived from the rutherfordine topology, where one of the hexagons within that topology accomodates Ca2+.

results.name: Shattuckite
results.description_short:
A rare secondary copper silicate.
May be confused with Plancheite.

results.name: Shcherbakovite
results.description_short:
Batisite Group.
Easily confused with batisite.

Note: the "shcherbakovite" described by Mitchell (1990) is in fact noonkanbahite.

results.name: Sherwoodite
results.description_short:
This mineral contains aluminovanadate(IV,V) polyanions, consisting of 14 (VO6) octahedra condensed by edge-sharing around a central (AlO6) octahedron (Evans and Konnert, 1978).

The structure is based on [AlV4+V5+12O39]11− vanadoaluminate anion, as r...

results.name: Shigaite
results.description_short: The Mn analogue of nikischerite and poellmannite.

results.name: Shubnikovite
results.description_short: A highly questionable mineral (cf. Giester et al., 2007); probably one of the arsenate members of the Lavendulan Group.

results.name: Shuiskite-(Mg)
results.description_short:
Pumpellyite Group.
Cr analogue of Pumpellyite-(Mg).

Old note: According to Nagashima et al. (2010), it is questionable whether shuiskite is an independent mineral species - in their original description, Ivanov et al. (1981) assigned all Cr3+ ions ...

results.name: Dachiardite-K
results.description_short: The potassium-dominant member of the Dachiardite series of the Zeolite Group.

results.name: Siderotil
results.description_short:
Chalcanthite Group.
May form by dehydration of cuprian melanterite.

results.name: Siderazot
results.description_short:
Modern confirmation of the chemical composition was lacking for a long time.
It was considered by some to be a "grandfathered" species, but very inadequately described (http://www.mindat.org/mesg-7-73751.html).

Redefined as a valid species by Bette...

results.name: Siderite
results.description_short:
Calcite Group. Magnesite-Siderite Series, Rhodochrosite-Siderite Series, Siderite-Smithsonite Series.

Crystals typically found as brown to tan rhombohedrons in clusters, faces often curved or composites; more often found as medium to dark brown mass...

results.name: Sideronatrite
results.description_short:
A rare sodium-iron-sulphate found in arid regions in oxidized zones of iron-rich deposits. Also formed through pyrite oxidation by saline water in veins, coal deposits, and near-sea areas by sea spray.

Reversibly dehydrates to metasideronatrite depe...

results.name: Siderophyllite
results.description_short:
Mica Group.
Forms a series with eastonite.

results.name: Sidwillite
results.description_short: Higher-hydrate counterpart of raydemarkite (monohydrate), tianhuixinite (1/3-hydrate), and molybdite (anhydrous).

results.name: Siegenite
results.description_short:
Linnaeite Group and Thiospinel Group.
Siegenite-Violarite Series.

Formula was earlier often generally given as (Ni,Co)3S4. Note that the composition NiCo2S4 (grimmite) is a normal spinel, i.e. Ni[Co2]S4 (Knop et al., 1968), while the composition Co...

results.name: Silver
results.description_short:
Copper Group. Gold-Silver Series and Palladium-Silver Series.

Silver is used in jewelry, tableware, coins, scientific equipment and in photographic processes. Silver tarnishes black with a surface layer of acanthite (silver sulphide), especially whe...

results.name: Simferite
results.description_short:
Simferite has an olivine-type crystal structure, with a half-occupied M1 site, and is also structurally related to the Triphylite Group.

The Mg analogue of lithiophilite and triphylite.

results.name: Simonellite
results.description_short:
Chemical name: 1,1-Dimethyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-7-isopropylphenanthrene.

Conifer tree biomarker.

results.name: Simonite
results.description_short: Occurs as inclusions in rebulite.

results.name: Simonkolleite
results.description_short: In synthetic form used as a zinc nutrition supplement for animals.

results.name: Sincosite
results.description_short: A Sincosite (triclinic polytype) is known.

results.name: Sinhalite
results.description_short: Usually in irregular masses in high grade metamorphic rocks; rarely forms euhedral crystals in mineralized marbles.

results.name: Sinjarite
results.description_short: Strongly hygroscopic.

results.name: Sinnerite
results.description_short: Known as a synthetic compound.

results.name: Skinnerite
results.description_short:
(Pseudo-orthorhombic) Sb analogue of wittichenite. 
May be the Sb analogue of UM2001-13-S:AsCuSbZn (?).

Possibly polymorphous with UM2001-14-S:AsCuSbZn.

results.name: Skippenite
results.description_short: Tetradymite Group.

results.name: Sklodowskite
results.description_short: Sklodowskite Group.

results.name: Skutterudite
results.description_short:
Skutterudite Group. Nickelskutterudite-Skutterudite Series. 
The cobalt analogue of Ferroskutterudite and Nickelskutterudite.

results.name: Slawsonite
results.description_short:
Feldspar Group.

May form in course of heating of its monoclinic polymorph, UM1995-41-SiO:AlSr.

Four other polymorphic modifications: I2/c, P–3c, P63/mcm and Pm3m.

The structure has paracelsian topology; as such, the species may alternatively b...

results.name: Smithsonite
results.description_short:
Calcite Group. Siderite-Smithsonite Series.

Smithsonite is often found as a secondary mineral in the oxidation zone of zinc ore deposits. It can also be observed in sedimentary deposits and as a direct oxidation product of sphalerite.

results.name: Smythite
results.description_short:
Pyrrhotite Group.

An iron(-nickel) sulphide visually very similar to pyrrhotite and troilite.

results.name: Natroboltwoodite
results.description_short:
Uranophane Group.

The Na analogue of boltwoodite.

The crystal structure of the synthetic analog of natroboltwoodite has been published by Plášil et al. (2022); it is orthorhombic (Pbcn) with the unit-cell volume ~8 times larger as for boltwoodite...

results.name: Natrouranospinite
results.description_short: Meta-autunite Group.

results.name: Natrozippeite
results.description_short: Visually indistinguishable from zippeite. NOTE: Many of the specimens that are labeled "zippeite" are actually natrozippeite (the sodium-dominant member of the group), especially those from sedimentary deposits.

results.name: Natropharmacosiderite
results.description_short:
Pharmacosiderite Group.
Forms a series with pharmacosiderite.

Initially found on a single museum specimen, presumably a weathering product of arsenopyrite.

results.name: Sobolevskite
results.description_short:
Member of two isomorphic series: Sobolevskite-Kotulskite Series and Sobolevskite-Sudburyite Series.

A possible intermediate member of the second series is coded as 'UM1985-01-Bi:PdSb'. A potential Bi analogue is known: 'UM1974-02-Bi:AsPdPtSb'.

Kn...

results.name: Sodalite
results.description_short:
Sodalite Group. Also classed as a feldspathoid.

Ideally sodalite has Na^4Cl in the two cages in the unit cell. Unlike haüyne and nosean, sodalite is virtually CO2-free (Bellatreccia et al., 2009).

In some sodalites, the aluminosilicate cages appe...

results.name: Soddyite
results.description_short: A triclinic(?) uranyl silicate mineral with a powder XRD pattern close to soddyite was reported by Stohl & Smith (1981).

results.name: Alum-(Na)
results.description_short: Alum Group.

results.name: Metanatroautunite
results.description_short: Meta-autunite Group.

results.name: Betpakdalite-NaCa
results.description_short: Betpakdalite Group.

results.name: Sogdianite
results.description_short: Osumilite Group. The Zr analogue of berezanskite and brannockite. The only mineral with dominant K, Li and Zr combined.

results.name: Söhngeite
results.description_short:
Söhngeite Group. The Ga analogue of bernalite and dzhalindite. One of a very few approved minerals with species-defining gallium; compare gallite, tsumgallite, gallobeudantite and galloplumbogummite.

Structurally a hydroxide perovskite. The structur...

results.name: Solongoite
results.description_short: Inderite Group.

results.name: Sofiite
results.description_short: A synthetic, monoclinic polymorph is known (Johnsson & Törnroos, 2007).

results.name: Sorbyite
results.description_short: Formula redefined by Moëlo et al. (2008) as CuPb^9(Sb,As)^11S^26, but the structure has not been determined.

results.name: Součekite
results.description_short:
The S analogue of Unnamed (Pb-Cu-Bi Selenide).
Note that pure PbCuBiS^3 is aikinite.

results.name: Souzalite
results.description_short:
Gormanite-Souzalite Series. The magnesium analogue of Gormanite.

Occurs as a hydrothermal alteration product of Scorzalite in pegmatite.

results.name: Spadaite
results.description_short: Questionable species with unknown structure. No X-ray powder pattern has been published in the literature.

results.name: Spangolite
results.description_short:
A secondary mineral commonly occurring with other secondary copper minerals in oxidized zones of copper-bearing ore bodies.

Note: The exact type locality is uncertain; the original specimen found “within a radius of 200 miles of Tombstone” (probably...

results.name: Spencerite
results.description_short: An uncommon secondary mineral occurring in some zinc-bearing hydrothermal deposits.

results.name: Sperrylite
results.description_short:
Pyrite Group.

S-rich variety was once functioning in the systematics as a separate species - 'platarsite' (now discredited).

results.name: Spertiniite
results.description_short:
Chemically similar to anthonyite. Also compare 'UM1974-06-O:CuH'.

In terms of chemistry alone it is the Cu analogue of wülfingite, which is also orthorhombic but has different space group (different structure anyway).

results.name: Spessartine
results.description_short:
Garnet Group. Almandine-Spessartine Series.

Occurs in magmatic, metamorphic, and pegmatitic rocks.

An (OH,F)-rich, tetragonal-pseudocubic spessartine is described by Boiocchi et al. (2012).


Not to be confused with the rock spessartite.

results.name: Spherocobaltite
results.description_short:
Calcite Group.
Often confused with cobalt-bearing calcite or cobalt-bearing dolomite.

NOTE: This is the correct and approved IMA spelling ("sphaerocobaltite" is incorrect). Palache, Berman, and Frondel (1954) list this species as "cobaltocalite" an...

results.name: Sphalerite
results.description_short:
Sphalerite Group.

Sphalerite, also known as blende or zinc blende, is the major ore of zinc. When pure (with little or no iron) it forms clear to white crystals (known as Cleiophane). Yellow to orange sphalerite is often called "golden sphalerite." ...

results.name: Spheniscidite
results.description_short: The ammonium analogue of leucophosphite. The Fe analogue of ammoniotinsleyite.

results.name: Spinel
results.description_short:
Spinel-Hercynite Series, Gahnite-Spinel Series, and the Magnesiochromite-Spinel Series.

Intensely coloured varieties due to the incorporation of various impurity elements. A few spinels from Sri Lanka can show an alexandrite colour change effect.

results.name: Spionkopite
results.description_short:
See also the closely related yarrowite.
A typical intergrowth of yarrowite and spionkopite is called Blaubleibender Covellite.

Compare UM1976-15-S:CuSe.

results.name: Spodumene
results.description_short:
Pyroxene Group - Clinopyroxene Subgroup.

Spodumene is worked as an ore of lithium, but it is most highly prized as a gem material - the varieties Kunzite (pink) and Hiddenite (green) are especially sought after. It is usually found as a constituent ...

results.name: Spurrite
results.description_short: The Negra mine (B,Na)-enriched spurrite is isotypic with synthetic NaCa5(SiO4)2(BO3) compound.

results.name: Srebrodolskite
results.description_short:
Brownmillerite-Srebrodolskite Series. Common in metacarbonate slags, i.e., in burning coal-mining waste heaps.

Compare gorerite.

results.name: Srilankite
results.description_short: Samarskite Group.

results.name: Stibiotantalite
results.description_short: Cervantite Group

results.name: Strontiojoaquinite
results.description_short:
Found as 1M, 2O, and 4O polytypes.

Type material crystals were zoned with a joaquinite core.

results.name: Strontioginorite
results.description_short: The strontium analogue of ginorite.

results.name: Strontiowhitlockite
results.description_short: Whitlockite Group.

results.name: Stalderite
results.description_short: The zinc analogue of routhierite and ferrostalderite.

results.name: Stanfieldite
results.description_short:
Possibly represents more than a single species:

- "~Ca7(CaMg)Mg9(PO4)12 ≡ Ca4Mg5(PO4)6", that is, the "Mindat Formula" (Brahin and lots of other meteorites)
- Ca7Mg2Mg9(PO4)12 for material from Lunar "rusty rock" 66095 (Britvin et al. 2020).

results.name: Stannite
results.description_short:
Easily confused with its dimorph ferrokësterite.

Compare petrukite, 'UM1982-12-S:CuFeSn' and 'UM1984-31-S:CuFeSn'.

results.name: Stannoidite
results.description_short: See also "Ge-stannoidite."

results.name: Starkeyite
results.description_short:
Rozenite Group.
Closely related to cranswickite.

This is a rare mineral, found at only a few localities, then it is usually found as white to very pale yellow or very pale greenish white powdery efflorescences.  Good crystals are extremely rare, pe...

results.name: Staurolite
results.description_short: Staurolite Group.

results.name: Stibiopalladinite
results.description_short:
Arsenopalladinite Group. 
Compare naldrettite (Pb2Sb) and 'UM1978-21-Sb:Pd'.

results.name: Steigerite
results.description_short: A secondary mineral occurring either as impregnations in sandstones or as a weathering product from vanadium-rich schists.

results.name: Stellerite
results.description_short:
Zeolite Group.
Easily confused with the chemically similar stilbite-Ca and other members of the stilbite subgroup.
Bladed crystals may be confused with colourless prehnite.

Stellerite is a zeolite mineral in the stilbite sub-group. It is the ortho...

results.name: Stepanovite
results.description_short:
The Fe analogue of zhemchuzhnikovite. Unique combination of elements.

The originally reported unit cell is a sub-cell, with correct space group and unit cell based on weak superstructure reflections.

results.name: Stephanite
results.description_short:
A less common Ag-rich silver sulphosalt.

Stephanite is stable below 197 +/- 5°C (Keighin & Honea, 1969).

results.name: Sterlinghillite
results.description_short: Occurs as tiny light white to pale pinkish white spherules on fracture surfaces, also irregular acicular crystals. Few verified specimens known from the type locality.

results.name: Sternbergite
results.description_short: A rare mineral occurring in Pinchbeck brown (yellowish brown with metallic lustre), flexible(!), mm-sized tabular crystals. It and its dimorph argentopyrite are often pseudomorphed to iron oxides which collapse to dust when poked with a needle. On the ...

results.name: Sterryite
results.description_short:
Black, metallic rod-like crystals, also massive.

Closely related to parasterryite.
The Ag analogue of ciriottiite.

results.name: Stewartite
results.description_short: Golden yellow bladed crystals usually with an acute termination. May occasionally show a similar less acute termination similar to laueite. Note: Stewartite may have very similar appearance to laueite, but laueite is usually conspicuously striated, whi...

results.name: Piemontite-(Sr)
results.description_short:
Clinozoisite Subgroup of the Epidote Group.

Compare epidote-(Sr), Unnamed (Fe3+-analogue of Piemontite-(Sr)) and Unnamed (Fe3+-analogue of Piemontite).

results.name: Stibarsen
results.description_short: Previously regarded as a variety of "allemontite" (= synonym of stibarsen).

results.name: Stibiocolusite
results.description_short:
Forms a solid-solution series with colusite.
May grade into Sb-rich nekrasovite (type material).

results.name: Stibivanite
results.description_short:
Lime green fibrous, rod-like, or somewhat blocky crystals.

2M and 2O polytypes.

results.name: Stibnite
results.description_short:
Bismuthinite-Stibnite Series. Possibly also polymorphous with UM1996-35-S:Sb.

The most common antimony sulphide. An important Sb ore mineral.

results.name: Stichtite
results.description_short:
Hydrotalcite Group.

See also the related, visually similar woodallite. It has a polymorph Stichtite-2H (previously known as barbertonite).

results.name: Stilleite
results.description_short: Sphalerite Group.

results.name: Stillwaterite
results.description_short:
Likely polymorphous with arsenopalladinite. One of several Pd arsenide minerals, chemically comparable to isomertieite, Unnamed (Pd Arsenide), etc.

Also compare with UM1993-02-AsTe:Pd.

results.name: Stilpnomelane
results.description_short:
Compare "chalcodite".

May be confused with "biotite" and other brownish mica, also with dark chlorite.

results.name: Hydroterskite
results.description_short: Related to terskite. Chemically similar to kapustinite and litvinskite. Compare also 'UM1967-12-SiO:HNaZr'.

results.name: Stishovite
results.description_short:
Rutile Group. The Si analogue of argutite.

A high-pressure polymorph of SiO2. Found as microscopic grains in impact craters and in ultra-high pressure rocks. 

Important component of subducted oceanic basalts. May potentially incorporate large (wt...

results.name: Stistaite
results.description_short: Not the only representative of the Sn-Sb. Compare, e.g., 'Unnamed (Sn-Sb)'.

results.name: Stoiberite
results.description_short: Compare 'UM1980-18-VO:Cu'.

results.name: Stolzite
results.description_short:
Stolzite-Wulfenite Series.
The tetragonal dimorph of raspite.

A rare secondary mineral in the oxidized zones of hydrothermal tungsten-bearing lead deposits.

results.name: Stottite
results.description_short: Stottite is an iron hexahydroxogermanate, a compound with a Ge(IV) complex anion. Compare 'UM1970-16-OH:GeMn' - an unnamed natural Mn-bearing hexahydroxogermanate.

results.name: Strashimirite
results.description_short:
An uncommon secondary Cu-arsenate. Fibrous varieties and crusts of parnauite can appear visually similar.

The crystal structure has been solved very recently (2015), leading to a revision of the formula, space group and unit cell (Kolitsch & Giester...

results.name: Strelkinite
results.description_short: Carnotite Group.

results.name: Strengite
results.description_short:
Variscite-Strengite Series.
The phosphate analogue of scorodite.

results.name: Stromeyerite
results.description_short: Chemically similar to mckinstryite.

results.name: Stronalsite
results.description_short:
Feldspar Group.
Forms a solid-solution series with banalsite

results.name: Strontianite
results.description_short:
The Sr analogue of aragonite and witherite. Compare olekminskite and 'UM1989-07-CO:CaSr'.

Strontianite, strontium carbonate, is mainly found as a low-temperature mineral in limestone and also found as a gangue mineral in sulphide veins. It is almost...

results.name: Strontioborite
results.description_short: Compare tunnellite, veatchite; kurgantaite, and 'balavinskite'.

results.name: Strontiochevkinite
results.description_short:
Chevkinite Group. 

The status of this species is disputed; it "... might be an Fe-rich variety of rengeite" (Miyawaki et al., 2002).

results.name: Strätlingite
results.description_short: Known to occur also in many blended cements ("gehlenite hydrate - C2ASH8").

results.name: Strunzite
results.description_short:
Strunzite Group. Related to laueite. Compare zincostrunzite.

For discussion on the "correct" type locality, see http://www.mindat.org/mesg-23-262727.html.

results.name: Struvite
results.description_short:
Struvite Group.
The ammonium analogue of Struvite-(K).

A mineral commonly found as a product of organic decay in putrescent matter, canned foods or other bacterial action on organic compounds, and as a constituent of human kidney and bladder stones...

results.name: Stützite
results.description_short: Related to empressite.

results.name: Studtite
results.description_short:
A rare secondary uranium mineral containing a peroxide group in its crystal structure.
May dehydrate to metastudtite.

results.name: Stumpflite
results.description_short: The possible Bi analogue is coded as 'UM1974-02-Bi:AsPdPtSb', while the Rh one as 'UM1979-19-Sb:Rh'.

results.name: Sturmanite
results.description_short:
Ettringite Group.

A possible Mn4+ analogue is here coded as Unnamed (possible Mn(IV) analogue of sturmanite).

results.name: Sudburyite
results.description_short:
Member of isomorphic series Sudburyite-Sobolevskite and Sudburyite-Kotulskite.

Compare UM1976-23-Sb:BiPdTe.

results.name: Sudoite
results.description_short: A dioctahedral chlorite.

results.name: Suessite
results.description_short:

results.name: Sugilite

results.name: Sulfoborite
results.description_short: Related to Cahnite.

results.name: Sulphohalite
results.description_short:
Sulphohalite Subgroup.
Sulphohalite is an ordered double antiperovskite with the anti-elpasolite structure (Krivovichev 2008).

results.name: Sulphotsumoite
results.description_short: Similar composition, PXRD data, and microhardness quite similar to "Mineral E" reported by Gamyanin et al. (1978) from eastern Yakutia, Russia; they give the following empirical formula: (Bi2.97Sb0.02Pb0.01)(Te2.0S0.96Se0.04).

results.name: Sulphur
results.description_short:
Sulphur Group.

Crystals are usually yellow to yellowish-brown blocky dipyramids, with thick tabular and disphenoidal crystals less common. Also found more typically as powdery yellow coatings. Most native sulphur is found in sedimentary rocks, where...

results.name: Sulvanite
results.description_short:
Member of Germanite Group?

According to Cressey et al. (1993), four metal valencies characterize sulvanite: Cu+, Cu2+, V2+ (!), and V5+. This could make sulvanite the first known mineral species with divalent vanadium (compare dellagiustaite).

results.name: Sundiusite
results.description_short: Chemically related to Unnamed (Pb Sulphate-Oxychloride). Compare UM1990-25-O:ClPbS.

results.name: Surinamite
results.description_short:

Only the 1M-polytype is known in nature. A Be-free analogue is known as 'UM1988-26-SiO:AlMg'.

results.name: Surite
results.description_short:
The Al analogue of ferrisurite.

Structure of surite is based on a cerussite-like layer intercalated with a 2:1 layer of smectite.

results.name: Susannite
results.description_short:
The trigonal dimorph of leadhillite.

A mineral closely related to leadhillite and macphersonite. Tabular forms of susannite are easily confused with leadhillite.

results.name: Suzukiite
results.description_short: Haradaite Group.

results.name: Sverigeite
